definition: Fit to be applied as a plaster; glutinous; adhesive; as,emplastic applications.
The state of being ethereal; etherealness.Something of that ethereality of thought and manner which belonged toWordsworth's earlier lyrics. J. C. Shairp.
Esoteric doctrine or principles.
To a very great degree; beyond what is usual; surpassingly. Itsignifies more than very.
To exclude from participation in; to excommunicate. [Obs.]Poets . . . were excommuned Plato's common wealth Gayton.
The epithelial lining of the ventricles of the brain and thecanal of the spinal cord; endyma; ependymis.
To deliver up by one government to another, as a fugitive fromjustice. See Extradition.
A sending out; emission. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Erysipelatous.
A building up; construction. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Whatever pertains to the subject under consideration; allthings.More wise, more learned, more just, more everything. Pope.
Employed in, or designed for, exploration. "Exploring parties."Bancroft.
Same as Eisel. [Obs.] Shak.

An ethereal salt, or compound ether, consisting of an organicradical united with the residue of any oxygen acid, organic orinorganic; thus the natural fats are esters of glycerin and the fattyacids, oleic, etc.
Standing out of, or rising above, water. Gray.
To take by assault; to storm; to overcome; to vanquish; as, toexpugn cities; to expugn a person by arguments.
To drive out; to expel. [Obs.]If charity be thus excluded and expulsed. Milton.
An island in a river; an ait. [Obs.] "Osiers on their eights."Evelyn.
To become open, disclosed, or developed; to pass through aprocess of evolution. Prior.
One who extemporizes.

Uplifted; high; lofty; also, animated; noble; as, elevatedthoughts. Elevated railway, one in which the track is raisedconsiderably above the ground, especially a city railway above theline of street travel.
Full of ease; suitable for affording ease or rest; quiet;comfortable; restful. Shak.-- Ease"ful*ly, adv.-- Ease"ful*ness, n.
Having the anterior scutes extending around the tarsus on theinner side; -- said of certain birds.
Liable or deserving to be excommunicated; makingexcommunication possible or proper. "Persons excommunicable ." Bp.Hall.What offenses are excommunicable Kenle.
An overflow, or overflowing abundance. [R.] Ray.
A kind of exorcism by blowing with the breath. Jer. Taylor.
One who embosses.
To cast out; to evict; to dispossess; as, to eject tenants froman estate.
A ventral cartilaginous or bony element of the coracoid in theshoulder girdle of some vertebrates.
To exhaust or evaporate moisture from; to dry up. Sir T.Browne.
A destructive kind of waste, committed by a tenant for life, inlands, woods, or houses. Cowell.
To breathe or puff out. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To put in pawn; to pledge; to impawn.To sell, empawn, and alienate the estates. Milman.
An instrument used to change the direction of electriccurrents; a commutator. [R.]
Derived from castor oil; ricinoleic; as, elaiodic acid. [R.]
Farthest; remotest; at the very end. Tylor.
A wailing; lamentation. [Obs.] "Ejulation in the pangs ofdeath." Philips.
To bind or encircle with lace, or as with lace; to lace; toencircle; to enfold; hence, to entangle.Ropes of pearl her neck and breast enlace. P. Fletcher.
A graduated scale for measuring the duration of sounds, anddetermining their different, and the relation of their intervals. J.J. Rousseau.
A giant. [Obs.] Beau & Fl.
Erratic. "Errabund guesses." Southey.
One possessed by an evil spirit; a demoniac.

To convert into an emulsion; to form an emulsion; to reducefrom an oily substance to a milky fluid in which the fat globules arein a very finely divided state, giving it the semblance of solution;as, the pancreatic juice emulsifies the oily part of food.
the act of discharging or excreting waste products or foreignsubstances through the various emunctories.
To register in a calendar; to calendar. Drayton.
To put an equal value upon; to put (something) on a par withanother thing. W. Taylor.
Tonic spasm; -- applied generically to denote any diseasecharacterized by tonic spasms, as tetanus, trismus, etc.
Emptying; evacuative; purgative; cathartic.-- n. (Med.)
Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
A cartilaginous tumor growing from the interior of a bone.Quain.
See Endothorax.

To set free from the power of another; to liberate; as: (a) Toset free, as a minor from a parent; as, a father may emancipate achild. (b) To set free from bondage; to give freedom to; to manumit;as, to emancipate a slave, or a country.Brasidas . . . declaring that he was sent to emancipate Hellas.Jowett (Thucyd. ).
To overflow; to inundate. [Obs.] Bailey.
A mineral resin, of a blackish brown color, occurring in soft,flexible masses; -- called also mineral caoutchouc, and elasticbitumen.
To encircle or embrace. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
One who enslaves. Swift.
That excepts; including an exception; as, an exceptiveproposition. I. Watts.A particular and exceptive law. Milton.
Furnished with equipage.Well dressed, well bred. Well equipaged, is ticket good enough.Cowper.
Pertaining to exosmose.
The science or study of epigraphs.
A mass of large stones thrown into water at random to formbases of piers, breakwaters, etc.
One who expostulates. Lamb.
A yellowish coloring matter found in plants grown in darkness,which is supposed to be an antecedent condition of chlorophyll.Encyc. Brit.
See Ependyma.
External to the ethmoid; prefrontal.
To make a vassal of. [Obs.]
In an evil manner; not well; ill; badly; unhappily;injuriously; unkindly. Shak.It went evil with his house. 1 Chron. vii. 23.The Egyptians evil entreated us, and affected us. Deut. xxvi. 6.
Ephemeral.
One who eschews.
Relating to, or resulting from, experience, or experiment;following from empirical methods or data; -- opposed to nativistic.
An island. See Eyot.
Completely armed; panoplied. Tennyson.
Marriage only within the tribe; a custom restricting a man inhis choice of a wife to the tribe to which he belongs; -- opposed toexogamy.
A state which consists in total suspension of sensibility, ofvoluntary motion, and largely of mental power. The body is erect andinflexible; the pulsation and breathing are not affected. Mayne.
A condition of excessive redness. See Erythrochroism.
Characterized by, or exhibiting, excess; overmuch.Excessive grief [is] the enemy to the living. Shak.
An ancient geometrical method in which an exhaustive processwas employed. It was nearly equivalent to the modern method oflimits.
An old theory of generation similar to emboOvulist.
A small chamber or place of protection for a sentinel, usuallyin the form of a projecting turret, or the like. See Castle.
Eremitic. Bp. Hall.
To extirpate. [Obs.]It is impossible to extirp it quite, friar. Shak.
One skilled in embryology.
Ebony. [Poetic] "Framed of ebon and ivory." Sir W. Scott.
On the way or road.
Old. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The eversion or turning out of any organ, or of its innersurface; as, exstrophy of the eyelid or of the bladder.
Mutual dealings; intercourse. [Obs.]The enterdeal of princes strange. Spenser.
See Bornite.
To make external; to manifest by outward form.Thought externalizes itself in language. Soyce.
Relating to erethism.
One who composes elegies. Goldsmith.
Interminable. [Obs.] Skelton.
Exciting joy, mirth, or pleasure.-- n.
One of the natives of France who were opposed to the firstRevolution, and who left their country in consequence.
One who, or that which, weakens or makes feeble.
A funeral song or discourse; an elegy. [R.] Donne.
A magistrate; one of a body of five magistrates chosen by thepeople of ancient Sparta. They exercised control even over the king.
One who expugns.
The state of being exotic; also, anything foreign, as a word oridiom; an exotic.
Inducing to vomit; exciting the stomach to discharge itscontents by the mouth.-- n.
A mark indicating a question; a note of interrogation.
The doctrine and usages of Episcopalians; episcopacy.
The tympanum. See Illust. of Ear.
The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
One who exaggerates; one addicted to exaggeration. L. Horner.
Sexless; asexual.
Having equal angles; equiangular. [R.] Johnson.
To use strength in action; to act or operate with force orvigor; to act in producing an effect.Of all men it is true that they feel and energize first, they reflectand judge afterwards. J. C. Shairp.
Evening. See Eve, n. 1. [Poetic.] Shak.
An eruption of pustules.
To clear from spots or stains, or from any imperfection. [Obs.]Hales.
A license formerly required for the making over a bill ofexchange to another over sea. Cowell.
The earthworm. [Obs.]The earthmads and all the sorts of worms . . . are without eyes.Holland.
To boil up; to swell and rage; to be agitated. Bacon.
To kiss; especially, to kiss repeatedly or fondly. [Obs.]
The theory, held by Euhemerus, that the gods of mythology werebut deified mortals, and their deeds only the amplification inimagination of human acts.
In an especial manner; chiefly; particularly; peculiarly; in anuncommon degree.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, the Entozoa.
To infold. See Infold.
Resembling erysipelas.
A nickname for auricular confession; shrift. [Obs.] Cartwright.

An elongated fish of many genera and species. The common eelsof Europe and America belong to the genus Anguilla. The electricaleel is a species of Gymnotus. The so called vinegar eel is a minutenematode worm. See Conger eel, Electric eel, and Gymnotus.
Surpassing; exceeding; surmounting. [Obs.]
Relating to Echinodermata; echinodermal.
Act of enwrapping; a wrapping or an envelope. Shuckford.
Indicating, or characterized by, equivocation.
The nightmare. Brande & C.
See Eloign.
To give boldness or courage to; to encourage. Shak.The self-conceit which emboldened him to undertake this dangerousoffice. Sir W. Scott.
Having the quality of drying up; causing a drying up.-- n. (Med.)
Having the petals free, that is, entirely separate from eachother; -- said of both plant and flower.
Somewhat old; advanced beyond middle age; bordering on old age;as, elderly people.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, the horse-chestnut; as,esculic acid.
One who holds lands by emphyteusis.
A syllogism which assumes as one of its premises a propositionwhich was the conclusion of a preceding syllogism, called, inrelation to this, the prosyllogism.

Originally, the art of managing engines; in its modern andextended sense, the art and science by which the mechanicalproperties of matter are made useful to man in structures andmachines; the occupation and work of an engineer.
With effect; powerfully; completely; thoroughly.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, whichoverhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
In an endurable manner.

Upon or from one side only; one-sided; partial; as, an ex partestatement. Ex parte application, one made without notice oropportunity to oppose.-- Ex parte council, one that assembles at the request of only oneof the parties in dispute.-- Ex parte hearing or evidence (Law), that which is had or taken byone side or party in the absence of the other. Hearings before grandjuries, and affidavits, are ex parte. Wharton's Law Dict. Burrill.
In an equivocal manner.
Beyond the territorial limits; foreign to, or exempt from, theterritorial jurisdiction.-- Ex*ter`ri*to"ri*al*ly(#),adv.
The capacity of being expanded; as, the expansibility of air.
An elector or chooser; one of two persons appointed by a courtto return a jury or serve a writ when the sheriff and the coronersare disqualified.

The act of endearing or the state of being endeared; also, thatwhich manifests, excites, or increases, affection. "The greatendearments of prudent and temperate speech." Jer. Taylor.Her first endearments twining round the soul. Thomson.
A flattened marine univalve shell of the genus Haliotis; --called also sea-ear. See Abalone.
Same as Interplead.
An embrace. [Obs.] "Our locked embrasures."" Shak.

To exert physical or intellectual strength for the attainmentof; to use efforts to effect; to strive to achieve or reach; to try;to attempt.It is our duty to endeavor the recovery of these beneficial subjects.Ld. Chatham.To endeavor one's self, to exert one's self strenuously to thefulfillment of a duty. [Obs.] "A just man that endeavoreth himself toleave all wickedness." Latimer.
An engine of war used for throwing viretons, large stones, andother missiles; a springal.

Of or pertaining to an embryo; embryonal; rudimentary.Embryonic sac or vesicle (Bot.), the vesicle within which the embryois developed in the ovule; -- sometimes called also amnios sac, andembryonal sac.
The connective tissue framework and sheath of a nerve whichbind together the nerve bundles, each of which has its own specialsheath, or perineurium.
A large, coarse herb (Inula Helenium), with composite yellowflowers. The root, which has a pungent taste, is used as a tonic, andwas formerly of much repute as a stomachic.
Of or pertaining to ivory. "[She] read from tablet eburnine."Sir W. Scott.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall,yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
An apparatus for testing or proving the strength of gunpowder.
An elegist. [Obs.]
Without ears; hence, deaf or unwilling to hear. Pope.
The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set offeathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.
Pertaining to bishops, or government by bishops; episcopal;specifically, of or relating to the Protestant Episcopal Church.
Gomuti fiber. See Gomuti.

A special business intrusted to a messenger; something to betold or done by one sent somewhere for the purpose; often, a verbalmessage; a commission; as, the servant was sent on an errand; to doan errand. Also, one's purpose in going anywhere.I have a secret errand to thee, O king. Judg. iii. 19.I will not eat till I have told mine errand. Gen. xxiv. 33.mission.
Containing, expressing, or using exclamation; as, anexclamatory phrase or speaker. South.-- Ex*clam"a*to*ti*ly, adv.
The external or outermost layer of a fructified or ripenedovary. See Illust. under Endocarp.
See Exsiccation. [Obs.]
To give a feud, or right in land, to; to invest with a fief orfee; to invest (any one) with a freehold estate by the process offeoffment. Mozley & W.
Evenly poised; balanced. Dr. H. More.-- E`qui*lib"ri*ous*ly, adv.
Without a tail or spur.
To be equivalent or equal to; to counterbalance. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
To instruct; to educate; to teach. [Obs.]The skillful goddess there erudiates these In all she did. Fanshawe.

Taught by practice or by repeated observations; skillful orwise by means of trials, use, or observation; as, an experiencedphysician, workman, soldier; an experienced eye.The ablest and most experienced statesmen. Bancroft.
Lasting; durable; long-suffering; as, an enduring disposition."A better and enduring substance." Heb. x. 34.-- En*dur"ing*ly, adv. T. Arnold.-- En*dur"ing*ness, n.

To incite by words or advice; to animate or urge by arguments,as to a good deed or laudable conduct; to address exhortation to; tourge strongly; hence, to advise, warn, or caution.Examples gross as earth exhort me. Shak.Let me exhort you to take care of yourself. J. D. Forbes.
Like epidermis; pertaining to the epidermis.
Standing, but with the wings spread, as if about to fly; --said of a bird borne as a charge on an escutcheon.
To bastardize. [Obs.]
Relating to exogamy; marrying outside of the limits of one'sown tribe; -- opposed to endogenous.
Belonging to the Edentata.
To give assurance to. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Tendency to emission; comparative facility of emission, or rateat which emission takes place, as of heat from the surface of aheated body.
Luxation; the dislocation of a joint. Bailey.
See Inure.

A liberty, privilege, or advantage, which one proprietor has inthe estate of another proprietor, distinct from the ownership of thesoil, as a way, water course, etc. It is a species of what the civillaw calls servitude. Kent.
A polygon or plane figure with nine sides and nine angles; anonagon.
The lobe of the ear.
Evenness of mind; that calm temper or firmness of mind which isnot easily elated or depressed; patience; calmness; composure; as, tobear misfortunes with equanimity.
Of, or like, an echinite.
A tincture with more than one base; a compound tincture ormedicine, composed of various substances, held in solution by alcoholin some form.
Liable to exception or objection; objectionable.-- Ex*cep"tion*a*ble*ness, n.This passage I look upon to be the most exceptionable in the wholepoem. Addison.
The Echinodermata.
A brownish black mineral with a metallic luster, found inNorway. It contains niobium, titanium, yttrium, and uranium, withsome other metals.

Having a capacity or tendency to expand or dilate; diffusive;of much expanse; wide-extending; as, the expansive force of heat; theexpansive quality of air.A more expansive and generous compassion. Eustace.His forehead was broad and expansive. Prescott.-- Ex*pan"sive*ly, adv. -Ex*pan"sive*ness, n.
To purge away. [Obs.] Milton.
Same as Ambassadress.
Partaking of the substance or nature of copper, or of the rustcopper; resembling the trust of copper or verdigris; æruginous.
A shunning; avoidance. [Obs.] Bacon.
To stir with strong emotion; to grieve; to mourn.
Relating to the inspection of entrails for prognostication.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The sound of a patient's voice so modified as to resemble thebleating of a goat, heard on applying the ear to the chest in certaindiseases within its cavity, as in pleurisy with effusion.
Tending to prove; having the power to demonstrate;demonstrative; indicative.
Ecclesiastical. [Obs.] Milton.
The act of operation of drying; evaporation or expulsion ofmoisture; state of being dried up; dryness. Sir T. Browne.
A condition of bone cartilage occurring in certain diseases ofthese tissues, in which they acquire an unnatural density, and cometo resemble ivory.
In an essential manner or degree; in an indispensable degree;really; as, essentially different.
The property manifested by living organisms, and the elementsand tissues of which they are constituted, of responding to theaction of stimulants; irritability; as, nervous excitability.
The act of eluding or avoiding, particularly the pressure of anargument, accusation, charge, or interrogation; artful means ofeluding.Thou . . . by evasions thy crime uncoverest more. Milton.

Of or relating to the elves; elflike; implike; weird; scarcelyhuman; mischievous, as though caused by elves. "Elfish light."Coleridge.The elfish intelligence that was so familiar an expression on hersmall physiognomy. Hawthorne.
To transport with pleasure; to delight beyond measure; toenravish. Shenstone.
The act or operation of clearing of knots, or of untying;hence, also, the solution of a difficulty. [R.] Bailey.
Pertaining to the encephalon or brain.
In a strange, unearthly way.
The act of weakening; enervation; weakness.
A plant whose flowers may be dried without losing their form orcolor, as the pearly everlasting (Anaphalis margaritacea), theimmortelle of the French, the cudweeds, etc.
In a manner fitted or designed to be an example for imitationor for warning; by way of example.She is exemplarily loyal. Howell.Some he punisheth exemplarily. Hakewill.
The act of exculpating from alleged fault or crime; that whichexculpates; excuse.These robbers, however, were men who might have made out a strongcase in exculpation of themselves. Southey.
To cover or shelter, as with a sconce or fort; to place or hidesecurely; to conceal.She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the arras. Shak.
One who, or that which, expounds or explains; an expounder; acommentator. Bp. Horsley.
The primitive formative juice, from which the tissues,particularly the cellular tissue, are formed.

A plant belonging to one of the greater part of the vegetablekingdom, and which the plants are characterized by having c woodbark, and pith, the wood forming a layer between the other two, andincreasing, if at all, by the animal addition of a new layer to theoutside next to the bark. The leaves are commonly netted-veined, andthe number of cotyledons is two, or, very rarely, several in a whorl.Cf. Endogen. Gray.
One who enhances; one who, or that which, raises the amount,price, etc.
To receive, or provide entertainment for, guests; as, heentertains generously.
Dispersed in vapors. Thomson.
Tending to produce effervescence. "An effervescive force."Hickok.
Feeding on insects; insectivorous.
The act of forcing or letting out of its proper vessels orducts, as a fluid; effusion; as, an extravasation of blood after arupture of the vessels.
Wrapped up within a leaf or sheath.
To brighten. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to euhemerism.
The act of expostulating or reasoning with a person inopposition to some impropriety of conduct; remonstrance; earnest andkindly protest; dissuasion.We must use expostulation kindly. Shak.
A little epistle. Lamb.
The act of forming in resemblance; an effigy. Fuller.
Of or pertaining to the enteron, or alimentary canal;intestinal. Enteric fever (Med.), typhoid fever.
The inversion or turning in of the border of the eyelids.
To surround as with a hedge. [R.] Vicars.

A real being, whether in thought (as an ideal conception) or infact; being; essence; existence.Self-subsisting entities, such as our own personality. Shairp.Fortune is no real entity, . . . but a mere relative signification.Bentley.
Belonging to, or designed for, an epithalamium.
A good state of he blood and other fluids of the body.
Everybody; -- commonly separated, every one.
Of or pertaining to ectostosis; as, ectosteal ossification.
The act of erasing; a rubbing out; expunction; obliteration.Johnson.
Hideous; ghastly; as, an eldritch shriek or laugh. [Local,Eng.]
To free from acids, salts, or other soluble substances, bywashing; to purify. [R.]
The act of embittering; also, that which embitters.
The upper and superficial part of the head, including thescalp, muscles, etc.
Placed alone or apart, as if on an island; severed, as anisland. [R.] "In the sea of life enisled." M. Arnold.
Capable of being erected. [Obs.]
See Arrish.
The surrender or delivery of an alleged criminal by one Stateor sovereignty to another having jurisdiction to try charge.
To plow up; also, to engrave; to write. [Obs.] Blount.

An argument consisting of only two propositions, an antecedentand consequent deduced from it; a syllogism with one premise omitted;as, We are dependent; therefore we should be humble. Here the majorproposition is suppressed. The complete syllogism would be, Dependentcreatures should be humble; we are dependent creatures; therefore weshould be humble.
A detailed exposition; relation. [Obs.] Hakewill.
. Torturing; racking. "Excruciating pain." V. Knox."Excruciating fears." Bentley -- Ex*cru"ci*a`ting*ly, adv.
Paleness produced by absence of light, or by disease.Dunglison.
The outer layer of the blastoderm; the ectoderm. SeeBlastoderm, Delamination.
Same as Eagre.
A colorless, mobile, inflammable liquid, C2H5.NH2, veryvolatile and with an ammoniacal odor. It is a strong base, and is aderivative of ammonia. Called also ethyl carbamine, and amido ethane.
Capable of being expugnded.
The quality of being explicit; clearness; directness. Jer.Taylor.
Marrying within the same tribe; -- opposed to exogamous.
Able to exclude; excluding; serving to exclude.
To enliven. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Eternity. [Obs.]
One of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series, C11H24,found as a constituent of petroleum. [Written also hendecane.]
A bridle check; a jerk of one rein, given to a horse when herefuses to turn.
The act of expurgating, purging, or cleansing; purificationfrom anything noxious, offensive, sinful, or erroneous. Milton.
The act of giving out or bestowing. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
To disembogue; to discharge, as a river, its waters into thesea or another river. [R.]
One who, or that which, electrizes.
Capable of being electrolyzed, or decomposed by electricity.
A medicine made by mixing oils with sirups. John Quincy.

A figure by which one striking circumstance is added, in duegradation, to another; climax; e. g., "He not only spared hisenemies, but continued them in employment; not only continued, butadvanced them." Johnson.
The quality of being effective.
A plant Whose radicle is not inclosed or sheathed by thecotyledons or plumule. Gray.
Pertaining to, or connected with, the epiglottis.
Without echo or response.
To instruct in the gospel; to preach the gospel to; to convertto Christianity; as, to evangelize the world.His apostles whom he sends To evangelize the nations. Milton.
The small space beneath the base line of a subject engraved ona coin or medal. It usually contains the date, place, engraver'sname, etc., or other subsidiary matter. Fairholt.
The act of erasing; a scratching out; obliteration.
To graft; to fix deeply. [Obs.]
Pertaining to an episode; by way of episode; episodic.
Eldest; firstborn. Blackstone.
To deprive of the claws or the balls of the fore feet; as, toexpeditate a dog that he may not chase deer.
The act of making rich, or that which enriches; increase ofvalue by improvements, embellishment, etc.; decoration;embellishment.
Not sheathed in another leaf.
An involuntary discharge of urine; incontinence of urine.
Noble. [Obs.]
The smew.
Valuation; appraisement. J. S. Mill.
In state of expectation.
Same as Equivalence.
See Scout. [Obs.] Hayward.
A perivisceral cavity which arises as an outgrowth oroutgrowths from the digestive tract; distinguished from aschizocoele, which arises by a splitting of the mesoblast of theembryo.
The act of enucleating; elucidation; exposition.Neither sir, nor water, nor food, seem directly to contributeanything to the enucleation of this disease. Tooke.
The act or the process of making electrotypes.
Fear or timidity, especially of something supernatural.[Written also eiryness.]The sense of eariness, as twilight came on. De Quincey.
The operation performed with an écraseur.
Outside of the walls, as of a fortified or walled city.
The division of Aves which includes all the typical birds, orall living birds except the penguins and birds of ostrichlike form.

Impudence or boldness in confronting or in transgressing thebounds of duty or decorum; insulting presumptuousness; shamelessboldness; barefaced assurance.Corruption lost nothing of its effrontery. Bancroft.
Capability of shedding the skin periodically. Craig.
A block or long slat of wood, perforated for the passage of thecrowfoot, or cords by which an awning is held up. [Written alsouphroe and uvrou.] Knight.
Commotion. [Obs.] Chapman.

To change on the surface, or throughout, to a whitish, mealy,or crystalline powder, from a gradual decomposition, esp. from theloss of water, on simple exposure to the air; as, Glauber's salts,and many others, effloresce.
Damage; injury; harm. [Obs.] Shak.
One who makes expiation or atonement.
Of or pertaining to epithelium; as, epithelial cells;epithelial cancer.
Having the quality of excreting, or throwing offexcrementitious matter.
To undertake. [Obs.] Sackville.
Ethereality.
See Exsolution. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
See Emmenagogue.
Serving to excrete; connected with excretion or excrement. [R.]"The excrementive parts." Felthman.
To place or hide in a thicket; to ambush. [Obs.] Shelton.
The outer portion of a fruit, as the flesh of a peach or therind of an orange. See Illust. of Drupe.
Everlasting. Shak.
Herpetologist.
To struggle out; -- with out. [Obs.] Bp. Hacket.
Episcopal. [R.] Wood.
A rock consisting of granular red garnet, light greensmaragdite, and common hornblende; -- so called in reference to itsbeauty.
A fresh-water tortoise of the family Emydidæ.
Relating to, accompanied by, or containing, endosperm.
The inner layer of the cells of Bryozoa.
Full of expense; costly; chargeable. [R.] Sir H. Wotton.-- Ex*pense"ful*ly, adv. [R.] -- Ex*pense"ful*ness, n. [R.]
An exorcist.
Extended. [Obs.] Spenser.
To mark, as sheep, by cropping or slitting the ear.
Equal as to number. [Obs.] Arbuthnot.
Relating to time or duration. [Obs.]
Capable of being translated into, or expressed in, English.
To charge upon with reproach; to upbraid. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To tinge or dye of a purple color; to color with purple; toimpurple. "The deep empurpled ran." Philips.
Made large or larger; extended; swollen.-- En*lar"ged*ly, adv.-- En*lar"ged*ness, n.
Protuberance. [Obs.] Farindon.
To become electric.
A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height andviolence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonlycalled the bore. See Bore.
The art of riding on horseback; performance on horseback;horsemanship; as, feats equestrianism.
A variety of hephelite, usually massive, of greasy luster, andgray to reddish color. Elæolite syenite, a kind of syenitecharacterized by the presence of elæolite.
Low; grovelling; vulgar.
A game at cards, played usually by two persons, in which theplayers may discard any or all of the cards dealt and receive othersfrom the pack.
To inclose in a cyst.
The growing crop, or profits of a crop which has been sown orplanted; -- used especially in the plural. The produce of grass,trees, and the like, is not emblement. Wharton's Law Dict.
See Ecstasy. [Obs.]
Pertaining to externalism North Am. Rev.
See Erst. [Obs.] Spenser.
To describe by an epithet. [R.]Never was a town better epitheted. Sir H. Wotton.
To supply with tackle. [Obs.] Skelton.
Moving easily; hence, mild-tempered; ease-loving; inactive.
Boneless. "Exosseous animals. " Sir T. Browne.
Pertaining to, or having the character of, an exogen; -- theopposite of endogenous.
To deposit in a tomb, as a dead body; to bury; to inter; toinhume. Hooker.
Of or relating to ancient Etruria, in Italy. "Etrurian Shades."Milton, -- n.

Tending to evade, or marked by evasion; elusive; shuffling;avoiding by artifice.Thus he, though conscious of the ethereal guest, Answered evasive ofthe sly request. Pope.Stammered out a few evasive phrases. Macaulay.-- E*va"sive*ly , adv.-- E*va"sive*ness, n.
A freeing from moss. [Obs.]
An inscription, label, or the like, in a book indicating itsownership; esp., a bookplate.
See Ependyma.
A plant of the genus Eryngium.
A plant (Solanum Melongena), of East Indian origin, allied tothe tomato, and bearing a large, smooth, edible fruit, shapedsomewhat like an egg; mad-apple.
Pertaining to, or derived from, eupittone.
The fundamental forms of organic life, that are composed of twoequal and symmetrical halves. Syd. Soc. Lex.
A kind of widemouthed pitcher or jug; esp., one used to holdwater for the toilet.Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands. Shak.
One of a sect of Asiatic Gnostics of the time of the EmperorTrajan.
Pertaining to, or produced from, emulsin; as, emulsic acid.Hoblyn.
The state of a hermit; a living in seclusion from social life.
The brow or hairy arch above the eye. Shak.
The semifluid, granular interior of certain unicellularorganisms, as the inner layer of sarcode in the amoeba; entoplasm;endoplasta.
To color. [R.]
The soft, spongy wood of a species of Magnolia (M. Umbrella).
Capability of being educated.
The contents of the cranium; the brain.
A song for the evening; the evening service or form of worship(in the Church of England including vespers and compline); also, thetime of evensong. Wyclif. Milton.

The number nine or a group of nine. The Enneads, the titlegiven to the works of the philosopher Plotinus, published by hispupil Porphyry; -- so called because each of the six books into whichit is divided contains nine chapters.
Of a red color; reddish; as, the erythroid tunic (the cremastermuscle).
The science or theory of church building and decoration.
Cast skins, shells, or coverings of animals; any parts ofanimals which are shed or cast off, as the skins of snakes, theshells of lobsters, etc.
The earth. [Prov. Eng.] Wright. Erd shrew (Zoöl.), the commonEuropean shrew (Sorex vulgaris); the shrewmouse.
Same as Equerry.
Extemporaneous; unpremeditated. [Obs.] B. Jonson.-- Ex*tem"po*ral*ly, adv. [Obs.]

A fragrant gum resin obtained chiefly tropical trees of thegenera Amyris and Canarium. A. elemifera yields Mexican elemi; C.commune, the Manila elemi. It is used in the manufacture ofvarnishes, also in ointments and plasters.
The external branch of the appendages of Crustacea.
To grapple. [Obs.]
Having the form of a sword blade; sword-shaped; as, an ensiformleaf. Ensiform cartilage, and Ensiform process. (Anat.) SeeXiphisternum.
An exclamation expressing exultation or surprise, etc.
Without ease. Donne.
The art of declining and conjugating words.
A kind of fragrant wood. See Agallochum.
A palace and mausoleum of the kinds of Spain, being a vast andwonderful structure about twenty-five miles northwest of Madrid.
To damnify; to injure. [R.] Sandys.
A genus of South American amaryllidaceous plants with large andbeautiful white blossoms.
Softening; making supple; acting as an emollient. "Emollientapplications." Arbuthnot.
Removal of the kernel.

The compiler of an encyclopedia, or one who assists in suchcompilation; also, one whose knowledge embraces the whole range ofthe sciences. The Encyclopedists, the writers of the great Frenchencyclopedia which appeared in 1751-1772. The editors were Diderotand D'Alembert. Among the contributors were Voltaire and Rousseau.
To deprive of shoes. [Obs.] Chambers.
Impudently. [Obs.] R. North.
A small annual plant (Euphrasia officinalis), formerly muchused as a remedy for diseases of the eye.
One who embroiders.
One who explores; also, an apparatus with which one explores,as a diving bell.
Encomium; panegyric. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Ten and one added; as, eleven men.
A follower of Eunomius, bishop of Cyzicus (4th century A. D.),who held that Christ was not God but a created being, having a naturedifferent from that of the Father.-- a.
Let out of the veins. [Obs.] "Extravenate blood." Glanvill.
Till then or now; heretofore; formerly. [Archaic]
Of or pertaining to the church. See Ecclesiastical."Ecclesiastic government." Swift.
The hypothesis that all living things proceed from preëxistinggerms, and that these encase the germs of all future living things,inclosed one within another. Buffon.
See under Embryonic.
A tear. [Poetic] Shak.
One who encourages, incites, or helps forward; a favorer.The pope is . . . a great encourager of arts. Addison.
To boil or bubble up. [Obs.] Prynne.
The act of expiscating; a fishing. [R.] Chapman.
The wife or widow of an elector in the old German empire.Burke.
An instrument for measuring the force or amount of endosmoticaction.
The semisolid external layer of protoplasm in some unicellularorganisms, as the amoeba; ectoplasm; exoplasm.

A clergyman authorized to administer all the sacraments; as, atraveling elder. Presiding elder (Meth. Ch.), an elder commissionedby a bishop to have the oversight of the churches and preachers in acertain district.-- Ruling elder, a lay presbyter or member of a Presbyterian churchsession. Schaff.

To put a covering about; to wrap up or in; to inclose within acase, wrapper, integument or the like; to surround entirely; as, toenvelop goods or a letter; the fog envelops a ship.Nocturnal shades this world envelop. J. Philips.
A struggling out of any difficulty. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Emaciation. [Obs.]
The state or quality of being electrical.
Serving or tending to exhaust; exhibiting all the facts orarguments; as, an exhaustive method. Ex*haust"ive*ly, adv.
To chasten. [Obs.]
Not exceptional; usual. [Obs.]My general and exceptless rashness. Shak.
The brain. [Obs.]

Spurge, or bastard spurge, a genus of plants of many species,mostly shrubby, herbaceous succulents, affording an acrid, milkyjuice. Some of them are armed with thorns. Most of them yieldpowerful emetic and cathartic products.
An exactor. [R.]
The quality of being emphatic; emphasis.
Mediation. [Obs.]
White or glowing with heat. [R.] Ure.
Pertaining to that which is out of doors. "Extr occupations."Cowper.
To make womanish; to make soft and delicate; to weaken.It will not corrupt or effeminate children's minds. Locke.
In passing; in the course of any procedure; -- said specif.(Chess),
Experienced. [Obs.]The prince now ripe and full experient. Beau & Fl.
A waking up or arousing. [Obs.] Holland
, . Exuberance.
One who envies; one who desires inordinately what anotherpossesses.
Entreaty; invitation. [Obs.] Shak.
Motion excited by reflex nerves. See Excito-motory.
Exposure. [Obs.] Shak.
Capable of being done or achieved; practicable; feasible. SirT. Browne.
In an evil manner; not well; ill. [Obs.] "Good deeds evillybestowed." Shak.
To strip or lay bare, as land of wood, houses, etc.; to commitwaste.
A bivalve shell of the genus Pecten. See Scallop.
The act of embedding, or the state of being embedded.

To dig out and remove, as earth.The material excavated was usually sand. E. L. Corthell.Excavating pump, a kind of dredging apparatus for excavating underwater, in which silt and loose material mixed with water are drawn upby a pump. Knight.

Causing effects; producing results; that makes the effect to bewhat it is; actively operative; not inactive, slack, or incapable;characterized by energetic and useful activity; as, an efficientofficer, power.The efficient cause is the working cause. Wilson.
An official of the Eastern Church, resembling a sacrist in theWestern Church.

Surpassing; extraordinary; distinguished (in a bad sense); --formerly used with words importing a good quality, but now joinedwith words having a bad sense; as, an egregious rascal; an egregiousass; an egregious mistake.The egregious impudence of this fellow. Bp. Hall.His [Wyclif's] egregious labors are not to be neglected. Milton.
Surroundings; specif., collectively, one's attendants orassociates.
To fester. [Obs.] "Enfestered sores." Davies (Holy Roode).
To construct. [Obs.] Byrom.
The European smelt (Osmerus eperlanus).
E is the third tone of the model diatonic scale. E (E flat) isa tone which is intermediate between D and E.
Inclined to drink to excess; intoxicated; tipsy. [R.] M.Collins.
To void excrement. [R.] Life of A. Wood
Represented with jagged and uneven edges, as is torn off; --used esp. of the head or limb of a beast. Cf. Couped.
Same as Elench.
Banishment. [R.] Sir. H. Wotton.
An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean, and the seed ofPhysostigma venenosum; physostigmine. It is used in ophthalmicsurgery for its effect in contracting the pupil.
A prefix. See En-.
To make a drudge or slave of. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Ubiquity; omnipresence. [R.] Grew.
An extinct group of marine reptiles, embracing both theIchthyosauria and the Plesiosauria, now regarded as distinct orders.
To put in a barge. [Poetic] Drayton.
A lazy, worthless fellow; a vagrant. [Obs.] Mason.
See Pyroxanthin.

One of the segments of the transverse axis, or the so calledhomonymous parts; as, for example, one of the several segments of theextremities in vertebrates, or one of the similar segments in plants,such as the segments of a segmented leaf. Syd. Soc. Lex.
In ancient Greece, the governor or perfect of a province; inmodern Greece, the ruler of an eparchy.
One who exemplifies by following a pattern.
Extracted; descended. [Obs.]Knowing whence thou art extraught Shak.
Of, or relating to, expression; phraseological; also, vividlyrepresenting or suggesting an idea sentiment. Fized. Hall. Ruskin.
Being of the same weight.A column of air . . . equiponderant to a column of quicksilver.Locke.

Corundum in the form of grains or powder, used in the arts forgrinding and polishing hard substances. Native emery is mixed withmore or less magnetic iron. See the Note under Corundum. Emery board,cardboard pulp mixed with emery and molded into convenient.-- Emery cloth or paper, cloth or paper on which the powder of emeryis spread and glued for scouring and polishing.-- Emery wheel, a wheel containing emery, or having a surface ofemery. In machine shops, it is sometimes called a buff wheel, and bythe manufacturers of cutlery, a glazer.
Not comprehended within a rule or rules. Jer. Taylor.
The state of needing, or of suffering a natural want. [R.] J.Grote.
Growing upon, or inserted into, the leaf.
One who goes on an excursion, or pleasure trip.
The result of eliminating n variables between n homogeneousequations of any degree; -- called also resultant.
To form like pearls; to decorate with, or as with, pearls; toimpearl.
A figure in which the orator treats of things according totheir events consequences.
One who enfranchises.
A figure in which successive clauses end with the same word oraffirmation; e. g., "Are they Hebrews so am I. Are they Israelites soam I." 2 Cor. xi. 22.
A spear with barbed forks for spearing eels.
A fossil plant which is found in the lowest beds of theSilurian age.
Emanative; of the nature of an emanation. Dr. H. More.
Expecting a wish; supplicatory. [R.]Sacrifices . . . distinguished into expiatory, euctical, andeucharistical. Bp. Law.

St. Anthony's fire; a febrile disease accompanied with adiffused inflammation of the skin, which, starting usually from asingle point, spreads gradually over its surface. It is usuallyregarded as contagious, and often occurs epidemically.
; imperceptibly. Chalmers.
Age. [Obs.] Fairfax.
A chair with arms to support the elbows; an armchair. Addison.

The sovereign or supreme monarch of an empire; -- a title ofdignity superior to that of king; as, the emperor of Germany or ofAustria; the emperor or Czar of Russia. Emperor goose (Zoöl.), alarge and handsome goose (Philacte canagica), found in Alaska.-- Emperor moth (Zoöl.), one of several large and beautiful bombycidmoths, with transparent spots on the wings; as the American Cecropiamoth (Platysamia cecropia), and the European species (Saturniapavonia).-- Emperor paper. See under Paper.-- Purple emperor (Zoöl.), a large, strong British butterfly(Apatura iris).
A creeping forth. [Obs.]
One who enriches.
To vibrate. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Purpose; determination. [Obs.]
To make gloomy. [R.]
Formed or developed by education; as, an educated man.
One who calls forth. [R.]
Gilded by means of voltaic electricity.
Disposition to take cognizance of events.
The science of causes. Same as tiology.
An efflorescence or discoloration of the skin; an eruption orbreaking out, as in measles, smallpox, scarlatina, and the likediseases; -- sometimes limited to eruptions attended with fever.Dunglison.
To make black, or stain black, in imitation of ebony; as, toebonize wood.

Goods; movables; personal estate; -- sometimes used to embracereal as well as personal property; as, the people escaped from thetown with their effects. For effect, for an exaggerated impression orexcitement.-- In effect, in fact; in substance. See 8, above.-- Of no effect, Of none effect, To no effect, or Without effect,destitute of results, validity, force, and the like; vain; fruitless."Making the word of God of none effect through your tradition." Markvii. 13. "All my study be to no effect." Shak.-- To give effect to, to make valid; to carry out in practice; topush to its results.-- To take effect, to become operative, to accomplish aims. Shak.
Of or pertaining to the Elasmobranchii.-- n.
Pertaining to the time of equal day and night; -- applied tothe equinoctial line. Whewell.
Making exception.
Euchology. [R.]
The philosophical theory which attributes the origin of all ourknowledge to experience.
To invigorate. [Obs.]
One who equivocates.Here's an equivocator that could swear in both the scales againsteither scale, yet could not equivocate to heaven. Shak.
The quality of being equitable, just, or impartial; as, theequitableness of a judge, a decision, or distribution of property.

The act of communicating or ejecting; esp., an ecclesiasticalcensure whereby the person against whom it is pronounced is, for thetime, cast out of the communication of the church; exclusion fromfellowship in things spiritual.
One who exclaims.
A funeral rite (usually in the plural); the ceremonies ofburial; obsequies; funeral procession.But see his exequies fulfilled in Rouen. Shak.

One of the followers of Thomas Erastus, a German physician andtheologian of the 16th century. He held that the punishment of alloffenses should be referred to the civil power, and that holycommunion was open to all. In the present day, an Erastian is one whowould see the church placed entirely under the control of the State.Shipley.
To form into, or incorporate with, a volume. [R.]
Parley; imparlance. [Obs.] Spenser.
To make empty; to render of no effect; to humble. [Obs.] Bp.Pearson.
Relating to any disease characterized by tonic spasms.
An enthusiast; a zealot. [Obs.]
The distance of a celestial object above the horizon, or thearc of a vertical circle intercepted between it and the horizon;altitude; as, the elevation of the pole, or of a star.
A genus of cactaceous plants having flattened, jointed stems,and petals united in a tube. The flowers are very showy, and severalspecies are in cultivation.
To excel; to surmount. [Obs.]
The act or art of dissecting the brain.
The act of elapsing. [R.]
In the enharmonic style or system; in just intonation.
A depriving of bone or of fruit stones. [Obs.] Bacon.
A genus of shrubs, natives of Australia, New Zealand, etc.,having pretty white, red, or purple blossoms, and much resemblingheaths.
Inflammation of the endometrium.
An epic.
A voidable. [R.] Hooker.
To twist or wreathe round; to intwine. Shak.
See Entablature. [R.] Evelyn.
To abound; to be in great abundance. [Obs.] Boyle.
A word formerly used (as finis is now) at the conclusion of abook to indicate the end.
Act of expatiating.
An explicit declaration.
To brutify; to imbrute.All the man embruted in the swine. Cawthorn.
Having nine seeds; -- said of fruits.
The shoulder of a bastion, or the place where its face andflank meet and form the angle, called the angle of the shoulder.
Eyes. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
To shun; to avoid. [Obs.] Shak.
Away from the mesial plane of the body; lateral. Externalangles. (Geom.) See under Angle.
See Embase. [Obs.]
The act of evangelizing; the state of being evangelized.The work of Christ's ministers is evangelization. Hobbes.
Matter excreted and ejected; that which is excreted or cast outof the animal body by any of the natural emunctories; especially,alvine, discharges; dung; ordure.
Disease of the intestines.
Any one of the several complex ethers of ethyl and glycerin.
To make euphonic. [R.]
Lenient; assuaging. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being erectile.
Epidermal; connected with the skin or the bark. Epidermicadministration of medicine (Med.), the application of medicine to theskin by friction.
Strongly affected. [Obs.]The Briton Prince was sore empassionate. Spenser.
Feasting to excess. [Obs.]
See Afrit.
Terminated. [Obs.] Shak.

To bring down or lower, as in position, value, etc.; to debase;to degrade; to deteriorate. [Obs.]Embased the valleys, and embossed the hills. Sylvester.Alloy in coin of gold . . . may make the metal work the better, butit embaseth it. Bacon.Such pitiful embellishments of speech as serve for nothing but toembase divinity. South.
The condition or quality of being evil; badness; viciousness;malignity; vileness; as, evilness of heart; the evilness of sin.
The upper part of the abdomen.
The down of the ostrich. Brande & C.
To inclose with curtains.

An artificial language, intended to be universal, devised byDr. Zamenhof, a Russian, who adopted the pseudonym "Dr. Esperanto" inpublishing his first pamphlet regarding it in 1887. The vocabulary isvery largely based upon words common to the chief European languages,and sounds peculiar to any one language are eliminated. The spellingis phonetic, and the accent (stress) is always on the penult. --Es`pe*ran"tist (#), n.
Pertaining to the interior of the ear.
A grayish white zeolitic mineral, in tetragonal crystals. It isa hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta.
Serving to purify from anything noxious or erroneous;cleansing; purifying. "Expurgatory animadversions." Sir T. Browne.Expurgatory Index. See Index Expurgatorius, under Index.

A large deer, of several species. The European elk (Alcesmachlis or Cervus alces) is closely allied to the American moose. TheAmerican elk, or wapiti (Cervus Canadensis), is closely related tothe European stag. See Moose, and Wapiti. Irish elk (Paleon.), alarge, extinct, Quaternary deer (Cervus giganteus) with widelyspreading antlers. Its remains have been found beneath the peat ofswamps in Ireland and England. See Illustration in Appendix; alsoIllustration of Antler.-- Cape elk (Zoöl.), the eland.

The fraudulent appropriation of property by a person to whom ithas been intrusted; as, the embezzlement by a clerk of hisemployer's; embezzlement of public funds by the public officer havingthem in charge.
An efferent duct or stream.
An eelpot or eel basket.
To admit to the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize. [Obs.]B. Jonson.
The European perch when two years old. [Prov. Eng.]
Belonging to, or contained in, the gospel; evangelical."Evangelic truth." J. Foster.
Capable of being emulated. [R.]Some imitable and emulable good. Abp. Leighton.
Pertaining to, or containing, enunciation or utterance.
A hernial tumor whose contents are intestine.
Pertaining to the writing of letters; used in writing letters;epistolary. Epistolographic character or mode of writing, the same asDemotic character. See under Demotic.
External; outward; not inherent. [Obs.] Shak.
Pert. to, or caused by, electro-capillarity.
See Intrench.
The quotient of a unit divided by eighty; one of eighty equalparts.
To impede or bar by estoppel.A party will be estopped by his admissions, where his intent is toinfluence another, or derive an advantage to himself. Abbott.
An ornament consisting of a ring passed through the lobe of theear, with or without a pendant.
To clear from mist, clouds, or obscurity. [R.] Bailey.
The South African wart hog. See Wart hog.
Erratic.-- Er*rat"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Er*rat"ic*al*ness, n.
The art or process of examining by means of the endoscope.
Relating to the etymon; as, an etymic word.
See Entoplastron.-- En`to*ster"nal, a.
To perfume; to scent. "Essenced fops." Addison.
Eight and ten; as, eighteen pounds.
The art or science of constructing or using the electrictelegraph; the transmission of messages by means of the electrictelegraph.
Herpetology.

An agent employed to advance, in a covert manner, the interestsof his employers; one sent out by any power that is at war withanother, to create dissatisfaction among the people of the latter.Buzzing emissaries fill the ears Of listening crowds with jealousiesand fears. Dryden.
Unlimited extension. [Obs.]An . . . extendlessness of excursions. Sir. M. Hale.
Effeminacy; womanishness. [Obs.] Bacon.
A pattern; an exemplar. [Obs.]

To be in high spirits; figuratively, to leap for joy; torejoice in triumph or exceedingly; to triumph; as, an exulting heart."An exulting countenance." Bancroft.The dumb shall sing, the lame his crutch forego, And leap exultinglike the bounding roe. Pope.
Quality of being exquisite.
One that entangles.
See Scrod, a young cod.
An order of Brachiopoda; the Lyopomata. See Brachiopoda.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C20H38, of the acetylene series, obtainedfrom brown coal.
The office or rank of an examiner.
To inclose in a vault; to entomb. [R.] Swift.

In an exact manner; precisely according to a rule, standard, orfact; accurately; strictly; correctly; nicely. "Exactly wrought."Shak.His enemies were pleased, for he had acted exactly as their interestsrequired. Bancroft.
A process of bone formation in which ossification takes placein the perichondrium and either surrounds or gradually replaces thecartilage.
Same as Exanthema.
The encephalon.In man the encephalos reaches its full size about seven years of age.Sir W. Hamilton.
To give a crimson or red color to; to crimson. Shak.
Having but one cell, or cavity; not divided by a septum orpartition.
The science of improving stock, whether human or animal. F.Galton.
The act or practice of excluding being exclusive;exclusiveness.
Rapturously; ravishingly.
A smooth, white, marine, gastropod shell of the genus Ovulum,resembling an egg in form.
An order of fishes including a vast number of freshwaterspecies such as the carp, loach, chub, etc.
By experiment or experience; without science; in the manner ofquacks.
Hindrance; molestation.[Obs.] Spenser.
To pick out. [Obs.] Hales.
One who undertakes enterprises. Sir J. Hayward.
Belonging to the Entomostracans.
To dazzle. [Obs.] "Endazzled eyes." Milton.
Embryonic.
A mania or frantic zeal for freedom. [R.] Carlyle.
To go out of the track; to deviate. [Obs.] Bentley.
In the manner or character of an editor or of an editorialarticle.

One of a sect of heretics, in the first centuries of thechurch, whose doctrine was a mixture of Judaism and Christianity.They denied the divinity of Christ, regarding him as an inspiredmessenger, and rejected much of the New Testament.
Exacting or requiring immediate aid or action; pressing;critical. "At this exigent moment." Burke.
One who believes in equalizing the condition of men; a leveler.
In an eminent manner; in a high degree; conspicuously; as, tobe eminently learned.
An avenging deity; one of the Furies; sometimes, consciencepersonified. [Written also Erinnys.]
The full profits or products which ground or land yields, asthe hay of the meadows, the feed of the pasture, the grain of arablefields, the rents, services, and the like. Cowell.

The act or process of educating; the result of educating, asdetermined by the knowledge skill, or discipline of character,acquired; also, the act or process of training by a prescribed orcustomary course of study or discipline; as, an education for the baror the pulpit; he has finished his education.To prepare us for complete living is the function which education hasto discharge. H. Spenser.
Having water within; containing fluid drops; -- said of certaincrystals.
The act of eventuating or happening as a result; the outcome.R. W. Hamilton.
Having power to enact or establish as a law. Abp. Bramhall.
One of the ephemeral flies.
A contrivance for hatching eggs by artificial heat.
A fancied perception of flashes of light, a symptom ofepilepsy; hence, epilepsy itself; convulsions.
Having the same potential. Equipotential surface, a surface forwhich the potential is for all points of the surface constant. Levelsurfaces on the earth are equipotential.
Suitable for exportation; as, exportable products.
One who, or that which, elates.
One who favors etacism.
An American genus of plants, containing but a single species(E. repens), the trailing arbutus.
Acting force; elasticity. [Obs.] Ray.
The art or process of making electrical measurements.
The act of clearing from spots. [Obs.] Johnson.
A bolt which a looped head, or an opening in the head.
A writer or inventor of emblems. Sir T. Browne.
A yellow, crystalline substance, resembling aurin, and obtainedby the oxidation of pittacal; -- called also eupittonic acid.[Written also eupitton.]
The state of being effeminate; unmanly softness. Fuller.
Pertaining to an epiphyte.
Extensibility.
One who performs or carries into effect. See Executor.
A process which, among some of the lower forms of life,precedes reproduction by budding, fission, spore formation, etc.
To weaken; to enervate. [Obs.] Milton.
In an enormous degree.
To grieve; to feel sad. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A festival commemorative of the founding of a city or theconsecration of a church; also, the ceremonies (as at Oxford andCambridge, England) commemorative of founders or benefactors.
See Ectosarc, and Ectoplasm.
Expiration.He had to leave at the expiry of the term. Lamb.The Parliament . . . now approaching the expiry of its legal term. J.Morley.
Hernia of the brain.
One who ennobles.
According to; conformably to. [Obs.] Chaucer. Emforth my might,so far as lies in my power. [Obs.]
One who takes out the bowels. [Written also emboweller.]
To take in with the ears; to hear. [Sportive] "I eared herlanguage." Two Noble Kinsmen.
One who expires or is expiring.
To entertain. [Obs.]
With equal power. Barrow.
To cause to become like the Europeans in manners or character;to habituate or accustom to European usages.A state of society . . . changed and Europenized. Lubbock.
Abounding with elms.The simple spire and elmy grange. T. Warton.
Relating to, or made by means of, the electroscope.
An image or representation; a form; a phantom; an apparition.Sir W. Scott.
A name originally given to a kind of beer combining qualitiesof different kinds of beer. [Eng.] "Foker's Entire." Thackeray.
The state of being enravished or enraptured; ecstasy; rapture.Glanvill.
Experimental; of the nature of experiment. [R.]
One who, or that which, eats.

An arrangement of a body of troops when its divisions are drawnup in parallel lines each to the right or the left of the one inadvance of it, like the steps of a ladder in position for climbing.Also used adjectively; as, echelon distance. Upton (Tactics).
An inflammation of the intestines. Hoblyn.
Exodus; withdrawal. [Obs.]The time of the Jewish exody. Sir M. Hale.

Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria, esp. Somateriamollissima, which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America,and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which isan article of commerce; -- called also eider duck. The American eider(S. Dresseri), the king eider (S. spectabilis), and the spectacledeider (Arctonetta Fischeri) are related species. Eider down. Etym:[Cf. Icel. æ\'ebardun, Sw. eiderdun, Dan. ederduun.] Down of theeider duck, much sought after as an article of luxury.
Act of enlightening, or the state of being enlightened orinstructed.
The act of making blind. [Obs.] Bp. Richardson.
To institute a process against (any one) in the Court ofExchequer.
The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and aman, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or forcohabitation.
. (Math.) Same as Eccentricity.
A waking up or awakening. [Obs.]
Ephemeral. [R.] Burke.
See Eavesdrop.

Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid so called. Euthiochroicacid (Chem.), a complex derivative of hydroquinone and sulphonic(thionic) acid.-- so called because it contains sulphur, and forms brilliantlycolored (yellow) salts.
Extemporaneously.
The basal substance of the cell nucleus; a hyaline or granularsubstance, more or less fluid during life, in which the other partsof the nucleus are imbedded.
Essentiality. Ld. Digby.
To cover with a bower; to shelter with trees. [Written alsoimbower.] [Poetic] Milton.-- v. i.
Capable of being purchased.
To excite. [Obs.] Bacon.
A mark (!) used to indicate an exclamation. G. Brown.
Of or pertaining to an emphyteusis; as, emphyteutic lands.

In an express manner; in direct terms; with distinct purpose;particularly; as, a book written expressly for the young.The word of the Lord came expressly unto Ezekiel. Ezek. i. 3.I am sent expressly to your lordship. Shak.
To chafe; to enrage; to heat. [Obs.] Shak.
In conformity with expectation. [R.] Walpole.

To avoid slyly, by artifice, stratagem, or dexterity; to escapefrom in a covert manner; to mock by an unexpected escape; to baffle;as, to elude an officer; to elude detection, inquiry, search,comprehension; to elude the force of an argument or a blow.Me gentle Delia beckons from the plain, Then, hid in shades, eludeshe eager swain. Pope.The transition from fetichism to polytheism seems a gradual processof which the stages elude close definition. Tylor.
To inclose in a shrine or chest; hence, to preserve or cherishas something sacred; as, to enshrine something in memory.We will enshrine it as holy relic. Massinger.
The branch of medical science which treats of the applicationsagent.
Easy or easily. [Obs.] "Eath to move with plaints." Fairfax.
Excitomotory; as, excito-motor power or causes.
One of the main bronchi in the lungs of birds.
To ask urgently. [Obs.] Cockeram.
See Lucubrate. [Obs.] Blount.
An order of knights holding a middle place between the senateand the commonalty; members of the Roman equestrian order.
Of godlike energy; inspired.-- En`the*as"tic*al*ly, adv.
An epicede.
One of the Enaliosauria.

The science of human duty; the body of rules of duty drawn fromthis science; a particular system of principles and rules concertingduty, whether true or false; rules of practice in respect to a singleclass of human actions; as, political or social ethics; medicalethics.The completeness and consistency of its morality is the peculiarpraise of the ethics which the Bible has taught. I. Taylor.
A variant of Eddish. [Obs.] Mortimer.
Serving of tending to evacuate; cathartic; purgative.
A side work, made of gabions, fascines, or bags, filled withearth, or of earth heaped up, to afford cover from the flanking fireof an enemy.
Liable to torment. [R.] Bailey.
An annoyance to the ear. [R.]The perpetual jangling of the chimes . . . is no small earsore Sir T.Browne.
See Æolic.
Air. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The more transparent cells, which finally become external, inmany segmenting ova, as those of mammals.
Same as Eskimo.It is . . . an error to suppose that where an Esquimau can live, acivilized man can live also. McClintock.
The state of being beyond the limits of a particular territory;esp. (Internat. Law),
The act of breathing in; inspiration. [R.]The special and immediate suggestion, embreathement, and dictation ofthe Holy Ghost. W. Lee.

A six-pointed star whose rays are wavy, instead of straightlike those of a mullet. [Written also étoile.] Estoile of eightpoints, a star which has four straight and four wavy rays.-- Estoile of four points. Same as Cross estoilé, under Cross.
See Ecteron.-- Ec`der*on"ic, a.
One who emancipates.
A general fire; a conflagration. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
The act of shedding, or casting off, an outer cuticular layer,as in the case of serpents, lobsters, etc.; a coming out; as, theecdysis of the pupa from its shell; exuviation.
To give an emotional character to.Brought up in a pious family where religion was not talked aboutemotionalized, but was accepted as the rule of thought and conduct.Froude.
The quality or state of being earthy, or of containing earth;hence, grossness.
Necessary; indispensable; -- said of those tones whichconstitute a chord, in distinction from ornamental or passing tones.
To whet or sharpen. [Obs.] B. Jonson.-- Ex*ac`u*a"tion, n. [Obs.]
Seeking or going out after external objects. [R.]Their natures being almost wholly extroitive. Coleridge.
A term applied to that phase of vegetable growth in which anorgan grows more rapidly on its upper than on its under surface. SeeHyponastic.
Of or pertaining to an executive.
By experiment; by experience or trial. J. S. Mill.
Liable or subject to excise; as, tobacco in an excisablecommodity.
To indent with small curves. See Engrailed.
Coming into being; nascent. [Obs.] Bp. Warburton.
Eight times a quantity.
Imperfect fetation in some organ exterior to the uterus; extra-uterine fetation. Hoblyn.
Equal; impartial. [Obs.] Shak.
Exercising its highest influence; -- said of a planet. [Obs.]Chaucer.
The cover of the eye; that portion of movable skin with whichan animal covers or uncovers the eyeball at pleasure.
Fuel. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
The act of evolving, or the state of being evolved; evolution.
The uppermost member of the cornice of an entablature.
A small wrenlike Australian bird (Stipiturus malachurus),having the tail feathers long and loosely barbed, like emu feathers.
To clear of flesh; to excarnate. Dr. H. More.
One who expects.
Without a node. Gray.

Having a fine color. Euchroic acid (Chem.), an organic, imideacid, obtained as a colorless crystalline substance, C12H4N2O8 byheating an ammonium salt of mellitic acid. By reduction it is changedto a dark blue substance (euchrone), -- hence its name.
One of the small galleries run out in front of the glacis. Theyserve to annoy the enemy's miners.
Outside of the branchial arches; -- said of the cartilages thusplaced in some fishes.
An instrument for measuring the extension of a body, especiallyfor measuring the elongation of bars of iron, steel, or othermaterial, when subjected to a tensile force.
The office or position of an envoy.
To clothe with flesh. [Obs.]Vices which are . . . enfleshed in him. Florio.
Having the sporangium destitute of a ring; -- said of certaingenera of ferns.
A panegyric. B. Jonson.
Pertaining to the kidneys; renal; as, emulgent arteries andveins.-- n.
The payment in cash of a note, draft, etc.
Of or relating to the epicardium.
Handbook; a manual of devotions. Evelyn.
Resembling an element.

An officer of state in England who marshals and orders allgreat ceremonials, takes cognizance of matters relating to honor,arms, and pedigree, and directs the proclamation of peace and war.The court of chivalry was formerly under his jurisdiction, and he isstill the head of the herald's office or college of arms.
To surround as with a guard. [Obs.] Shak.
A foot consisting of three long syllables and one shortsyllable.
The offense committed by an officer who corruptly claims andtakes, as his fee, money, or other thing of value, that is not due,or more than is due, or before it is due. Abbott.
East. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An induced electric current circulating wholly within a mass ofmetal; -- called also Foucault current.

Not straitened as to money matters; as, the market is easy; --opposed to tight. Honors are easy (Card Playing), said when each sidehas an equal number of honors, in which case they are not counted aspoints.
The act or art of heraldic decoration; delineation of armorialbearings.
One of several species of armadillos of the genera Dasypus andEuphractus, having five toes both on the fore and hind feet.
A nonnitrogenous, crystalline body, present in small quantityin human fæces.
The bitter vetch (Ervum Ervilia).
An ulcer in the eye, upon the cornea, which causes the loss ofthe humors. Dunglison.
Introduced from a foreign country; not native; extraneous;foreign; as, an exotic plant; an exotic term or word.Nothing was so splendid and exotic as the ambassador. Evelyn.
Conducting influences from the spinal cord outward; -- said ofthe motor or efferent nerves. Opposed to esodic.
Any protuberance of a bone which is not natural; an excrescenceor morbid enlargement of a bone. Coxe.
An additional or epithet name; a nickname. [Obs.]
To ripen. [Obs.] Donne.
To engird. [R.] Collins.
To banish or expel from one's own country or home; to driveaway. "Exiled from eternal God." Tennyson.Calling home our exiled friends abroad. Shak.

To arrange in order of battle; to array for battle; also, toprepare or arm for battle; to equip as for battle.One in bright arms embattled full strong. Spenser.Here once the embattled farmers stood And fired the shot heard roundthe world. Emerson.
Liable to escheat.
To deprive of animation or of life. [Obs.]
One who makes an effort or attempt. [Written also endeavourer.]
To make safe. [Obs.] Hall.
A railing or trellis upon which fruit trees or shrubs aretrained, as upon a wall; a tree or row of trees so trained.And figs from standard and espalier join. Pope.
The profit arising from office, employment, or labor; gain;compensation; advantage; perquisites, fees, or salary.A long . . . enjoyment of the emoluments of office. Bancroft.
To expound; to explain; also, to expose; to imperil. [Old Eng.& Scotch] Drummond.
Having a red color and oily appearance; -- applied to a purplesemifluid substance said to be obtained from archil.
Same as Cologne.
Exogenous.
A projection, formed by a separate ossification, at thescapular end of the clavicle of many birds.
To come into gear with; as, the teeth of one cogwheel engagethose of another, or one part of a clutch engages the other part.
An experimenter. [R.]
One guilty of embracery.
Pertaining to the endognath.
Capable of being given off as an effluvium. "Effluviablematter." Boyle.
Serving to exhort; exhortatory; hortative. Barrow.

That order of the Crinoidea which includes most of the livingand many fossil forms, having jointed arms around the margin of theoral disk; -- also called Brachiata and Articulata. See Illusts.under Comatula and Crinoidea.
With child; pregnant. See Enceinte. [Obs.]
Destitute of expression.
Enormous. [Obs.] Spenser.
Same as Engouled.
The passing off from the sun's disk of an inferior planet, in atransit.
A genus of highly ornate and brilliantly colored birds ofAustralia, allied to the birds of Paradise.
Espousal. [Obs.] Latimer.
One who composes epigrams, or makes use of them.The brisk epigrammatist showing off his own cleverness. Holmes.
Same as Emissary, a., 2.
One who would exclude another from some right or privilege;esp., one of the anti-popish politicians of the time of Charles
The breaking out of pimples, or an efflorescence, as inmeasles, scarlatina, etc.
A compound decomposable, or subjected to decomposition, by anelectric current.
Capable of existence. Grew.
A drop from the eaves; eavesdrop. [R.] Tennyson.
Elementary. [Obs.] Skelton.
The median plate of the plastron of turtles; -- called alsoentosternum.

To reduce to slavery; to make a slave of; to subject to adominant influence.The conquer'd, also, and enslaved by war, Shall, with their freedomlost, all virtue lose. Milton.Pleasure admitted in undue degree Enslaves the will. Cowper.
Capable of rooting out, or tending to root out. Cheyne.
To bottle. [R.] Phillips.
Originally, the highest note in the scale of Guido; hence,proverbially, any extravagant saying. "Why, this is above E-la!"Beau. & Fl.
To entitle. B. Jonson.
An instrument for removing wax from the ear.
To deprive of authority or office; to depose; to discharge.[Obs.]Exauthorated for their unworthiness. Jer. Taylor.
Capable of being effaced.

A curve from which another curve, called the involute orevolvent, is described by the end of a thread gradually wound uponthe former, or unwound from it. See Involute. It is the locus of thecenters of all the circles which are osculatory to the given curve orevolvent.
Derived from, or dependent upon, vital processes; -- said ofcertain electric currents supposed by some physiologists to circulatein the nerves of animals.
Pertaining to the exordium of a discourse: introductory.The exordial paragraph of the second epistle. I. Taylor.
The quality of being emulous.
To inclose. See Inclose.
That erodes or gradually eats away; tending to erode;corrosive. Humble.
To deduce logically, as conclusions. [Obs.] Hewyt.

Having the power to produce an effect or effects; producing adecided or decisive effect; efficient; serviceable; operative; as, aneffective force, remedy, speech; the effective men in a regiment.They are not effective of anything, nor leave no work behind them.Bacon.Whosoever is an effective, real cause of doing his heighbor wrong, iscriminal. Jer. Taylor.
The rank or office of an ensign.
A yellow or greenish yellow gas, first prepared by Davy,evolved from potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid. It is supposedto consist of chlorine tetroxide with some free chlorine.
To throw into disorder; to disturb. [Obs.] "To engarboil thechurch." Bp. Montagu.
One versed in the science of exegesis or interpretation; --also called exegete.
Corrigible; amendable. [R.] Bailey.

An instrument for measuring the quantity or intensity ofelectricity; also, sometimes, and less properly, applied to aninstrument which indicates the presence of electricity (usuallycalled an electroscope). Balance electrometer. See under Balance.
An animated or passionate exclamation.The feelings by the ecphonesis are very various. Gibbs.
To form into a people or community; to inhabit; to people.[Obs.]We now know 't is very well empeopled. Sir T. Browne.
A follower of Eutyches [5th century], who held that the divineand the human in the person of Christ were blended together as toconstitute but one nature; a monophysite; -- opposed to Nestorian.
Inclosure. See Inclosure.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an epode.
The act of expilating or stripping off; plunder; pillage.[Obs.]This ravenous expiation of the state. Daniel.
To represent by epigrams; to express by epigrams.
That can be exemplified.

One who, or that which, extracts; as:(a) (Surg.) A forceps or instrument for extracting substances.(b) (Breech-loading Firearms) A device for withdrawing a cartridge orspent cartridge shell from the chamber of the barrel.
An internal parasitic organism.
Guard. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH; -- called also cetylic alcohol.See Cetylic alcohol, under Cetylic.
The act of exhuming that which has been buried; as, theexhumation of a body.

The great classes or orders of a community or state (as theclergy, the nobility, and the commonalty of England) or theirrepresentatives who administer the government; as, the estates of therealm (England), which are (1) the lords spiritual, (2) the lordstemporal, (3) the commons.
To induct, as a bishop, into the powers and privileges of avacant see.
One who embraces.
Anything lasting but a day, or a brief time; an ephemeralplant, insect, etc.
Privation or destitution of blood; -- opposed to plethora.Dunglison.

A yellow pigment imported from India and China. It has a strongodor, and is said to be obtained from the urine of herbivorousanimals when fed on the mango. It consists if a magnesium salt ofeuxanthic acid. Called also puri, purree, and Indian yellow.
Multiplied by the same number or quantity.
Capable of being eradicated.
Resembling an egg in form; ovoid.

The habit of lurking about dwelling houses, and other placeswhere persons meet fro private intercourse, secretly listening towhat is said, and then tattling it abroad. The offense is indictableat common law. Wharton.
The quality of deserving esteem or regard.
One who exhibits.
One who executes or performs; esp., a performer on a musicalinstrument.Great executants on the organ. De Quincey.
To form into ridges. Shak.
To lock; to inclose.
To be raised up; to grow larger; as, a debt enhances rapidly bycompound interest.
To strangle. [Obs.]
To confuse; to entangle.I am lost and embrangled in inextricable difficulties. Berkeley.
That branch of electrical science which treats of the effect ofan electric current upon the temperature of a conductor, or a part ofa circuit composed of two different metals.
Capable of being exhausted, drained off, or expended. Johnson.
A kind of frosted cake, containing flavored cream.
A grass plat; a lawn. Simmonds.
A term sometimes applied to the effects (tetanus) produced inthe muscles of the limbs, when a current of electricity is passedalong the spinal cord or nerves.
See Escheat. [Obs.] Spenser.
Any organ or part of the body (as the kidneys, skin, etc.,)which serves to carry off excrementitious or waste matter.
Pertaining to an edifice; structural.
Of or pertaining to the interval of the octave and the fourth.
To clasp. See Inclasp.
An intestinal concretion.
To collect specimens in the study of entomology. C. Kingsley.
Pertaining to the epipodialia or the parts of the limbs towhich they belong.
Equality. Chaucer. Tennyson.
Toward the outside or surface; -- opposed to entad. B. G.Wilder.
To give an Egyptian character or appearance to. Fairbairn.
That which is egested or thrown off from the body by thevarious excretory channels; excrements; -- opposed to ingesta.
In an emulous manner.
A metallic mineral, a selenide of copper and silver; -- socalled by Berzelius on account of its being found soon after thediscovery of the metal selenium.
Endosmotic.
A dilatation of a hollow organ or of a canal.
Capable of being enforced.
To indue or imbue (a body) with soul. [R.] Emerson.
State of being external; exteriority; (Metaph.)
A genus of fresh-water fishes, including pike and pickerel.

The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on theback. They are generally white. Among the best known species are theAmerican egret (Ardea, or Herodias, egretta); the great egret (A.alba); the little egret (A. garzetta), of Europe; and the Americansnowy egret (A. candidissima).A bunch of egrets killed for their plumage. G. W. Cable.
In a manner to please nice taste; with elegance; with duesymmetry; richly.
Without eyes; blind. "Eyeless rage." Shak.
Pertaining to, or designed for, the measurement of endosmoticaction.
Easy. [Obs.] Spenser.
A species of Spanish grass (Macrochloa tenacissima), of whichcordage, shoes, baskets, etc., are made. It is also used for makingpaper.
Elegiac; funereal.
A hard, black variety of vulcanite. It may be cut and polished,and is used for many small articles, as combs and buttons, and forinsulating material in electric apparatus.
The act or process of making ether; specifically, the processby which a large quantity of alcohol is transformed into ether by theagency of a small amount of sulphuric, or ethyl sulphuric, acid.
The neck of horse. R. Browning.
To discharge through pores or incisions, as moisture or otherliquid matter; to give out.Our forests exude turpentine in . . . abundance. Dr. T. Dwight.
The state of being everlasting; endless duration; indefiniteduration.
Striving to excel; ambitious; emulous. [Obs.] "A most emulatepride." Shak.
An exclamation expressing delight.
To some, or any, other place; as, you will have to goelsewhither for it. R. of Gloucester."For elsewhither was I bound."Carlyle.
To cover as with a dome.
Eight times twenty; a hundred and sixty.
To publish abroad. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Echinoidea.-- n.
Producing, or relating to, epipolism or fluorescence. [R.]
The external layer of the skin and mucous membranes;epithelium; ecderon.-- Ec`ter*on"ic, a.

The act of axtenuating or the state of being extenuated; theact of making thin, slender, or lean, or of palliating; diminishing,or lessening; palliation, as of a crime; mitigation, as ofpunishment.To listen . . . to every extenuation of what is evil. I. Taylor.
Rejoicing triumphantly or exceedingly; exultant.-- Ex*ult"ing*ly, adv.
Foreign; not native; exotic. [R.] -- Ex*ot"ic*al*ness, n.
One who resolves religion into prayer. [Obs.] Gauden.
The custom, or tribal law, which prohibits marriage betweenmembers of the same tribe; marriage outside of the tribe; -- opposedto endogamy. Lubbock.

To fish out; to find out by skill or laborious investigation;to search out. "To expiscate principles." [R.] Nichol.Dr.Burton has with much ingenuity endeavord to expiscate the truthwhich may be involved in them. W. L. Alexander.
Same as Epigæous.
One who estranges.
The inner layer of a ripened or fructified ovary.
One who entices; one who incites or allures to evil. Burton.
Capable of being expiated or atoned for; as, an expiableoffense; expiable guilt. Bp. Hall.
The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter edh, capital form th in asimilar word: oedher, other, dôedh, doth." March.
Having, or subject to, erythrochroism.
Capability of being exhausted.I was seriously tormented by the thought of the exhaustibility ofmusical combinations. J. S. Mill.
One who investigates ethnography.
A recapitulation, in the peroration, of the heads of anargument.
An instrument for obtaining an accurate record of the time atwhich any observed phenomenon occurs, or of its duration. It has anelectro-magnetic register connected with a clock. See Chronograph.
Hope. [Obs.] Shak.
A circular opening to recive a hook, cord, ring, or rope; aneyelet.
One who espouses; one who embraces the cause of another ormakes it his own.
A kite of the genus Elanus.
A glassy, opaque bead obtained by the blowpipe.
Filled to excess with blood or other liquid; congested.
To incrust. See Incrust.
To pierce. [Obs.] Shak.
One who manifests an exquisite attention to externalappearance; one who is overnice in dress or ornament; a fop; a dandy.
A fresh-water tortoise (Chelopus marmoratus) of California; --used as food.
A turning into a circle; round figures. [Obs.] Donne.
The tendon by which the eye is moved. Shak.
Extraction. [Obs.] Spenser.
The occurrence or production of certain capillary effects bythe action of an electrical current or charge.
Being at an equal distance from the same point or thing.-- E`qui*dis"tant*ly, adv. Sir T. Browne.
