A number, letter, or any quantity written on the right hand ofand above another quantity, and denoting how many times the latter isrepeated as a factor to produce the power indicated;
Of or pelating to eurite.
Having wheels of the same size or diameter; having equalrotation. [R.]
See Equine. "An equinal shape." Heywood.
To get more astern or parallel with the vessel's course; todraw aft; -- said of the wind.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina and manganese. It is generallyof a rose-pink color, -- whence the name.
A figure in which a harts or indelicate word or expression issoftened; a way of describing an offensive thing by an inoffensiveexpression; a mild name for something disagreeable.
A layer of cells forming a kind of cuticle inside of the propercortical layer, or surrounding an individual fibrovascular bundle.
With affection or endearment; dearly.
A compound or twin crystal made up of eight individuals.
One who goes out. [R.]
Of or pertaining to eophytes.
To cover with, or as with, a shroud; to shroud. Churchill.
A dancing tune in the Scotch style.
Healthy nutrition; soundless as regards the nutritivefunctions.
To make a monk (or wearer of a cowl) of. [R.] Drayton.
In an esoteric manner.
The commander of an enomoty. Mitford.

Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid so called.Ethionic acid (Chem.), a liquid derivative of ethylsulphuric andsulphuric (thionic) acids, obtained by the action of sulphur trioxideon absolute alcohol.
Suitableness for being eaten; edibleness.
A compound derived from ethyl alcohol by the replacement of thehydroxyl hydrogen, after the manner of a hydrate; an ethylalcoholate; as, potassium ethylate, C2H5.O.K.
To strip or wear off the skin of; to abrade; to gall; to breakand remove the cuticle of, in any manner, as by rubbing, beating, orby the action of acrid substances.
To enfeeble. [Obs.] Holland.
Having a tendency to form ulcers; rendering ulcerous.
An ambush. [Obs.]
Capable of being cast off in the form of exuviæ.
One who creates a product on his own account; whoeverundertakes on his own account an industrial enterprise in whichworkmen are employed. F. A. Walker.
Skill derived from practice; readiness; as, expertness inseamanship, or in reasoning.
The portion of a line formerly occupied by the letter m, then asquare type, used as a unit by which to measure the amount of printedmatter on a page; the square of the body of a type.
A variety of chalcedony containing water.
Coated or adorned with enamel; having a glossy or variegatedsurface; glazed. [Written also enamelled.]

Service of the shield, a species of knight service by which atenant was bound to follow his lord to war, at his own charge. It wasafterward exchanged for a pecuniary satisfaction. Called alsoscutage. Blackstone.
Connected with, or pertaining to, epidemiology.
One who esteems; one who sets a high value on any thing.The proudest esteemer of his own parts. Locke.
A fossil joint of a crinoid stem.
A woman exercising the functions of an executor.
To search into or out. [Obs.] Chapman.

The state of being effulgent; extreme brilliancy; a flood oflight; great luster or brightness; splendor.The effulgence of his glory abides. Milton.The bright and the balmy effulgence of morn. Beattie.
To braid. [Obs.] Spenser.
To lose flesh gradually and become very lean; to waste away inflesh. "He emaciated and pined away." Sir T. Browne.
The thin epithelium lining the blood vessels, lymphatics, andserous cavities. See Epithelium.
Having the quality of exhaling or evaporating.
Elimination. [R.]
Purification.
The equinoctial line.
Periodical; annual; -- applied to winds which annually blowfrom the north over the Mediterranean, esp. the eastern part, for anirregular period during July and August.
Stimulation. [Obs.]Things insipid, and without any extimulation. Bacon.
Exploratory.
ASlothful. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
The ninth segment in insects.
In an extravagant manner; wildly; excessively; profusely.
Displaced. Ogilvie.
A mythical monster of the early Anglo-Saxon literature; adragon. W. Spalding.
An exegetist.
To defend, as with a shield; to shield. [Archaic] Shak.
A mineral of a green color and pearly luster; a hydrousphosphate of copper.
To sail away or over. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Epicedial.-- n.
A horny excrescence upon the beak of birds.
The whole alimentary, or enteric, canal.
A method of etching in which the design upon the plate isproduced in relief.
Taking an exception.
Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as,the oak eggar (L. roboris) of Europe.
One of the descendants of Esau or Edom, the brother of Jacob;an Idumean.
Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, which, inmany animals, projects beyond the connection with the stapes.-- n.
To cut off; to separate or expel from union; to extirpate.Barrow.The second presbytery of Philadelphia was also exscinded by thatAssembly. Am. Cyc.
A kind of ruby. See Spinel.
Pertaining to the four evangelists; designed or fitted toevangelize; evangelical; as, evangelistic efforts.
Having existence. [Archaic] Bp. Barlow. --Ex`is*ten"tial*ly,adv. [Archaic]Existentially as well as essentially intelligent. Colerige.

Producing, or having adequate power or force to produce, anintended effect; adequate; efficient; operative; decisive. Shak.Effectual steps for the suppression of the rebellion. Macaulay.Effectual calling (Theol.), a doctrine concerning the work of theHoly Spirit in producing conviction of sin and acceptance ofsalvation by Christ, -- one of the five points of Calvinism. SeeCalvinism.
Of or pertaining to education. "His educational establishment."J. H. Newman.

Pertaining to the first in time of the three subdivisions intowhich the Tertiary formation is divided by geologists, and alludingto the approximation in its life to that of the present era; as,Eocene deposits.-- n.
Egoism. [R.] A. Baxter.

To value, as lands taken by a writ of extent in satisfaction ofa debt; to assign by writ of extent. Extended letter (Typog.), aletter, or style of type, having a broader face than is usual for aletter or type of the same height.
Pertaining to an estuary; estuary.

To make equal; to reduce to an average; to make such anallowance or correction in as will reduce to a common standard ofcomparison; to reduce to mean time or motion; as, to equate payments;to equate lines of railroad for grades or curves; equated distances.Palgrave gives both scrolle and scrowe and equates both to F[rench]rolle. Skeat (Etymol. Dict. ).Equating for grades (Railroad Engin.), adding to the measureddistance one mile for each twenty feet of ascent.-- Equating for curves, adding half a mile for each 360 degrees ofcurvature.
The passage of gases, vapors, or liquids thought membranes orporous media from within outward, in the phenomena of osmose; --opposed to endosmose. See Osmose.
One who takes exceptions or makes objections. [Obs.] Milton.
With an even, level, or smooth surface; without roughness,elevations, or depression; uniformly; equally; comfortably;impartially; serenely.
Esophageal.
A genus of Bryozoa which produce delicate corals, oftenincrusting like lichens, but sometimes branched.
Pertaining to, or producing, evaporation; as, the evaporativeprocess.
The general description of embryos.
Extuberance. [R.]
, One who practices extortion.
The state of being deeply interested; earnestness; zeal.
A glance of the eye. Shak.
Exemplary. [Obs.]The exemplar piety of the father of a family. Jer. Taylor.
Attended with eruption or efflorescence, or producing it; as,an eruptive fever.
A nesting or unfledged Lird; in falconry, a young hawk from thenest, not able to pr Shak J. H. Walsh
To strip of bark or skin; to decorticate. [Obs.] "Excorticatethe tree." Evelyn.
The art or process of depositing a coating (commonly) ofsilver, gold, or nickel on an inferior metal, by means ofelectricity.
To express by a euphemism, or in delicate language; to make useof euphemistic expressions.

Taught by use, practice, or experience, experienced; havingfacility of operation or performance from practice; knowing and readyfrom much practice; clever; skillful; as, an expert surgeon; expertin chess or archery.A valiant and most expert gentleman. Shak.What practice, howsoe'er expert In fitting aptest words to things . .. Hath power to give thee as thou wert Tennison.
The act of reducing to slavery; state of being enslaved;bondage; servitude.A fresh enslavement to their enemies. South.
An etymologist.
Esoteric.
Having eleven pistils; as, an endecagynous flower.
Pertaining to Egypt, in Africa. Egyptian bean. (Bot.) (a) Thebeanlike fruit of an aquatic plant (Nelumbium speciosum), somewhatresembling the water lily. (b) See under Bean,
In an everlasting manner.
An armichair for ease or repose. "Laugh . . . in Rabelais'easy-chair." Pope.
Separable. [Obs.] "Exemptitious from matter." Dr. H. More.
The public lectures or published writings of Aristotle. SeeEsoterics.
To think out; to find out or discover by thinking; to devise;to contrive. "Excogitate strange arts." Stirling.This evidence . . . thus excogitated out of the general theory.Whewell.
To hide in, or as in, a cave or recess. "Do but encaveyourself." Shak.
A Linnæan class of plants having nine stamens.
Tending to elude or deceive; evasive; fraudulent; fallacious;deceitful; deceptive.-- E*lu"so*ri*ness, n.
See Earnest. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Epithumetical. [Obs.]
To follow; to pursue; to follow and overtake. [Obs.] "Seekpeace, and ensue it." 1 Pet. iii. 11.To ensue his example in doing the like mischief. Golding.
To represent by an emblem; to emblematize. [R.]
The quality of being essential; the essential part. Jer.Taylor.
Serving to enforce or constrain; compulsive. Marsion.-- En*for"cive*ly, adv.
See Endoderm, and Illust. of Blastoderm.

A mammal of the order Proboscidia, of which two living species,Elephas Indicus and E. Africanus, and several fossil species, areknown. They have a proboscis or trunk, and two large ivory tusksproceeding from the extremity of the upper jaw, and curving upwards.The molar teeth are large and have transverse folds. Elephants arethe largest land animals now existing.
Having a mind devoted to earthly things; worldly-minded; --opposed to spiritual-minded.-- Earth"ly-mind`ed*ness, n.
The leaving of the disease principally to the efforts of natureto effect a cure. Expectation of life, the mean or average durationof the life individuals after any specified age.
To render cold. [Obs.]
Exophthalmia.
To dig out of the ground; to take out of a place of burial; todisinter. Mantell.
An earthquake.
Covered with moss; mossed. Keats.
A discharge of saliva by spitting. [R.] E. Darwin.
Overlapping each other; -- said of leaves whose bases arefolded so as to overlap and bestride the leaves within or above them,as in the iris.
Capable of being expanded or spread out widely.Bodies are not expansible in proposition to their weight.Ex*pab"si*ble*ness ,n. -Ex*pan"si*bly ,adv.
A prefix, meaning equally; as, equidistant; equiangular.
To grieve. [Obs.] Spenser.
To bring to pass; to effect; to achieve; to accomplish; tofulfill.A fit instrument to effectuate his desire. Sir P. Sidney.In order to effectuate the thorough reform. G. T. Curtis.
An iron-black mineral of metallic luster, occurring in smallorthorhombic crystals, also massive. It contains sulphur, arsenic,copper, and often silver.
To dislocate; to luxate.
To render empyreumatic. [R.]
The act of envisaging.
The formation of an embryo.
Epicene. [R.] Hadley.
The imaginary great circle on the earth's surface, everywhereequally distant from the two poles, and dividing the earth's surfaceinto two hemispheres.

Relating to an eponym; giving one's name to a tribe, people,country, and the like.What becomes . . . of the Herakleid genealogy of the Spartan kings,when it is admitted that eponymous persons are to be canceled asfictions Grote.
To plow. [Obs.] See Ear, v. t. Chaucer.
The act of notching or indenting the margin, or the state ofbeing so notched; also, a notch or shallow sinus in a margin.

A rare mineral, containing chiefly niobium, titanium, thorium,and cerium. It was so called by Berzelius on account of the inabilityof chemical science, at the time of its discovery, to separate someof its constituents.
In an eleemosynary manner; by charity; charitably.

That may be excused, forgiven, justified, or acquitted ofblame; pardonable; as, the man is excusable; an excusable action.-- Ex*cus"a*ble*ness, n.-- Ex*cus"a*bly, adv.The excusableness of my dissatisfaction. Boyle.
Spreading or extending outwardly in a flat form.

The state of being exigent; urgent or exacting want; pressingnecessity or distress; need; a case demanding immediate action,supply, or remedy; as, an unforeseen exigency. "The present exigencyof his affairs." Ludlow.
Extravagance.
To freeze; to congeal. [Obs.]Thou hast enfrozened her disdainful breast. Spenser.
Producing heat. [R.] Smart.
A genus of elegant, glassy sponges, consisting of interwovensiliceous fibers, and growing in the form of a cornucopia; -- calledalso Venus's flower-basket.
Of or pertaining to extermination; tending to exterminate."Exterminatory war." Burke.
Surmountable; superable. [Obs.] Johnson.
The state or quality of being earnest; intentness; anxiety.An honest earnestness in the young man's manner. W. Irving.
To rove. Bp. Warburton.
To place in the sky or in heaven. [R.] "A thing enskied andsainted." Shak.
n. [L. exinanitio.] An emptying; an enfeebling; exhaustion;humiliation. [Obs.]Fastings to the exinanition of spirits. Jer. Taylor.
One who makes experiments; one skilled in experiments. Faraday.
The tissue which fills the interspaces between the costæ ofmany madreporarian corals, usually consisting of small transverse oroblique septa.
A kind of posset made of eggs, brandy, sugar, and ale. Lamb.
Hazard; peril. Milton.
By episcopal authority; in an episcopal manner.
One who enrolls or registers.
Resembling the material of the brain; cerebriform. Encephaloidcancer (Med.), a very malignant form of cancer of brainlikeconsistency. See under Cancer.
That may be expected or looked for. Sir T. Browne.
Capable of being enjoyed or of giving joy; yielding enjoyment.Milton.

A gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H6, forming a constituent of ordinaryilluminating gas. It is the second member of the paraffin series, andits most important derivatives are common alcohol, aldehyde, ether,and acetic acid. Called also dimethyl.
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, erythrin.
Of or pertaining to a feast or banquet. [Obs.] Smart.
Vessels and other utensils, ornaments, or the like, made ofbaked clay. See Crockery, Pottery, Stoneware, and Porcelain.
That which is formed as a crust; incrustment; incrustation.Disengaging truth from its encrustment of error. I. Taylor.
An earthquake. [Obs.]
Caused by a morbifie virus implanted in the system; as, anenthetic disease like syphilis.
To darken. [Obs.] Feltham.
One who, or that which, echoes.
So as to throw into ecstasy.

Pertaining, or the abode of the blessed after death; hence,yielding the highest pleasures; exceedingly delightful; beatific."Elysian shades." Massinger. "Elysian age." Beattie.This life of mortal breath Is but a suburb of the life elysian.Longfellow.
Embryonic; undeveloped. [R.]
Elegiac.
In an eclectic manner; by an eclectic method.
One who makes experiments; an experimenter. Whaterly.
A public storehouse.
The granule within the nucleolus or entoblast of a nucleatedcell. Agassiz.
See Inquiry.
Any unusual outgrowth from the surface of a thing, as of apetal; also, the capacity or act of producing such an outgrowth.
To encircle. [R.]The Muses and the Graces, grouped in threes, Enringed a billowingfountain in the midst. Tennyson.
The angular distance of a planet from the sun; as, theelongation of Venus or Mercury.
An hexameter. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To balance two scales, sides, or ends; to keep even with equalweight on each side; to keep in equipoise. H. Spenser.
Elevated; raised aloft. [Poetic] Milton.
Equicrural. [Obs.]
To eject from the trachea or lungs; to discharge, as phlegm orother matter, by coughing, hawking, and spitting; to spit forth.

To form and occupy a camp; to prepare and settle in temporaryhabitations, as tents or huts; to halt on a march, pitch tents, orform huts, and remain for the night or for a longer time, as an armyor a company traveling.The host of the Philistines encamped in the valley of Rephaim. 1Chron. xi. 15.
A genus of shrubs or small trees, having the foliage coveredwith small silvery scales; oleaster.
The clearing up of anything which is obscure or not easilyunderstood; an explanation.The eclaircissement ended in the discovery of the informer.Clarendon.
The part of each apodeme derived from the intersternal membranein Crustacea and insects.
The outer, nonsensitive layer of the skin; cuticle; scarfskin.See Dermis.
Pertaining to the Muse Erato who presided over amatory poetry.Stormonth.
In an ethereal manner.
An unfermentable sugar, obtained as an uncrystallizable sirupby the decomposition of melitose; also obtained from a Tasmanianeucalyptus, -- whence its name.
Given to eating; voracious; devouring.Swallowed in the depths of edacious Time. Carlyle.-- E*da"cious*ly, adv.-- E*da"cious*ness, n.
Having the power of excreting, or promoting excretion. Harvey.
The state of being an enclave. [Recent]
. A shutting out from communion; excommunication. [Obs.]Excommunication is the utmost of ecclesiastical judicature. Milton.

Necessaries or supples; an allowance to a person out of anestate or other thing for support; as of wood to a tenant for life,etc., of sustenance to a man confined for felony of his estate, oralimony to a woman divorced out of her husband's estate. Blackstone.Common of estovers. See under Common, n.
Out of or beyond the proper authority of a court or judge;beyond jurisdiction; not legally required. "An extrajudicialopinion." Hallam.-- Ex`tra*ju*di"cial*ly, adv.
To carnalize; to make gross. [R.] "Encarnalize their spirits."Tennyson.
In an estimable manner.
Relating to the Eastern Islands; East Indian. [R.] Ogilvie.

Capable of being erected; susceptible of being erected ofdilated. Erectile tissue (Anat.), a tissue which is capable of beinggreatly dilated and made rigid by the distension of the numerousblood vessels which it contains.

Having external ears; having tufts of feathers resembling ears.Eared owl (Zoöl.), an owl having earlike tufts of feathers, as thelong-eared owl, and short-eared owl.-- Eared seal (Zoöl.), any seal of the family Otariidæ, includingthe fur seals and hair seals. See Seal.
Worthy of esteem; estimable. [R.] "Esteemable qualities." Pope.
Nobleness of birth. [Obs.]
Pertaining to egoism. [R.]
Of or pertaining to the endoderm.
Foreign; unnatural; unusual; -- said of forms of crystals notnatural to the substances in which they are found.
The small aperture or foremen in the outer coat of the ovule ofa plant.
The membrane lining the cavities of the heart.
The act of exploring; exploration. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Bestowing praise; eulogistic; laudatory. [Obs.] E. Phillips.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, emmetropia.The normal or emmetropic eye adjusts itself perfectly for alldistances. J. Le Conte.
Having sword-shaped leaves, or appendages; ensiform.
See Exsuscitate [Obs.] T. Adams.
Epicurean. [Obs.]
A building; a structure; an architectural fabric; -- chieflyapplied to elegant houses, and other large buildings; as, a palace, achurch, a statehouse.
A purgative.
Pertaining to the epimera.
A small oval porcelain or glass cup, having a rim curved to fitthe orbit of the eye. it is used in the application of liquidremedies to eyes; -- called also eyeglass.
To endow with the qualities of a woman. [R.] Daniel.
The inner lining of an another cell.
Of or pertaining to entophytes; as, an entophytic disease.
To throw up a bank so as to confine or to defend; to protect bya bank of earth or stone.
The act of exulting; lively joy at success or victory, or atany advantage gained; rapturous delight; triumph.His bosom swelled with exultation. Prescott.
One of the first pair of lateral plates in the plastron ofturtles.
Pacific. See Irenic.

Clear to the vision; especially, clear to the understanding,and satisfactory to the judgment; as, the figure or color of a bodyis evident to the senses; the guilt of an offender can not always bemade evident.Your honor and your goodness is so evident. Shak.And in our faces evident the sings Of foul concupiscence. Milton.
A genus of umbelliferous plants somewhat like thistles inappearance. Eryngium maritimum, or sea holly, has been highlyesteemed as an aphrodisiac, the roots being formerly candied.
To twine, twist, or wreathe together or round. [Written alsointwine.]Entwined in duskier wreaths her braided locks. Shelley.Thy glorious household stuff did me entwine. Herbert.
To ail. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Any worm of the genus Lumbricus and allied genera, found indamp soil. One of the largest and most abundant species in Europe andAmerica is L. terrestris; many others are known; -- called alsoangleworm and dewworm.
A group of Crustacea in which the eyes are without stalks; theArthrostraca. [Written also Edriophthalmata.]
Same as Æsthesiometer.
In an ethnographical manner.
Of or pertaining to electrogenesis; as, an electrogeniccondition.
An equal sounding; the consonance of the unison and itsoctaves.
Sameness of signification of two or more propositions whichdiffer in language.
A steep descent or declivity; steep face or edge of a ridge;ground about a fortified place, cut away nearly vertically to preventhostile approach. See Scarp.
A figure by which a word is repeated with vehemence oremphasis, as in the following lines: -Alone, alone, all all alone, Alone on a wide wide sea. Coleridge.
Like, or pertaining to, the genus Eschara, or family Escharidæ.
A firing in the direction of the length of a trench, or a lineof parapet or troops, etc.; a raking fire.
One who employs another; as, an employer of workmen.
Therefore; consequently; -- often used in a jocular way. Shak.
Capable of being expressed, squeezed out, shown, represented,or uttered.-- Express"i*bly,adv.
To harden. [Obs.]It will embrawn and iron-crust his flesh. Nash.
One who, or that which, equalizes anything.
Resembling an insect.-- n.
The thickish outer coat of certain spores.
Of or pertaining to an editor; written or sanctioned by aneditor; as, editorial labors; editorial remarks. editorial content
Without an edge; not sharp; blunt; obtuse; as, an edgelesssword or weapon.
That can be sustained or made available or effective in a courtof equity, or upon principles of equity jurisprudence; as, anequitable estate; equitable assets, assignment, mortgage, etc.Abbott.
That branch of physical science which treats of the phenomenaof electricity and its properties.
Made of or relating to ivory.
Missouri; -- a nickname.
One of the lateral lobes of the foot in certain gastropods.
One of a tribe of tortoises, including the terrapins, etc., inwhich the head and neck can be withdrawn.
Excommunicated; interdicted from the rites of the church.-- n.
To polish thoroughly. [Obs.] Heywood.
Serving or intended to explore; searching; examining;explorative. Sir H. Wotton.
One who entreats; one who asks earnestly; a beseecher.

Pouring out; pouring forth freely. "Washed with the effusivewave." Pope. Effusive rocks (Geol.), volcanic rocks, in distinctionfrom so-called intrusive, or plutonic, rocks.-- Ef*fu"sive*ly, adv.-- Ef*fu"sive*ness, n.
A canine tooth of the upper jaw. See Teeth. To cut one'seyeteeth, to become acute or knowing. [Colloq.]

Having equal angles; as, an equiangular figure; a square isequiangular. Equiangular spiral. (Math.) See under Spiral, n.-- Mutually equiangular, applied to two figures, when every angle ofthe one has its equal among the angles of the other.
A cartilaginous lidlike appendage which closes the glottiswhile food or drink is passing while food or drink is passing throughthe pharynx.
To bend like a bow; to curve. "Embowed arches." [Obs. or R.]Sir W. Scott.With gilded horns embowed like the moon. Spenser.
To eliminate, as unknown quantities. [R.]

To attend with a view to guard and protect; to accompany assafeguard; to give honorable or ceremonious attendance to; -- usedesp. with reference to journeys or excursions on land; as, to escorta public functionary, or a lady; to escort a baggage wagon.
Containing expostulation or remonstrance; as, an expostulatorydiscourse or letter.
A depression in the sphenoid bone; the pituitary fossa.
A solid, all plane sections of which are ellipses or circles.See Conoid, n., 2 (a).

Related to Euclid, or to the geometry of Euclid. Euclidianspace (Geom.), the kind of space to which the axioms and definitionsof Euclid, relative to straight lines and parallel lines, apply; --called also flat space, and homaloidal space.
One who encounters; an opponent; an antagonist. Atterbury.
One who emigrates, or quits one country or region to settle inanother.
Exhaustion. Wraxall.
A bank or mound of earth.
One who electroplates.
Fitted to excite envy; capable of awakening an ardent desire toposses or to resemble.One of most enviable of human beings. Macaulay.-- En"vi*a*ble*ness, n.-- En"vi*a*bly, adv.
The name of King Arthur's mythical sword. [Written alsoExcalibar, Excalibor, Escalibar, and Caliburn.] Tennyson.
One of the movable peduncles which, in the decapod Crustacea,bear the eyes at the tip.
Epidermal. [R.]
Growing out.
Increase of irritation or violence, particularly the increaseof a fever or disease.
To absorb or swallow up as in a gulf.It quite engulfs all human thought. Young.
Scantiness; smallness; thinness. [R.] Boyle.
The earwig.
Same as Æsculapius.
To shoot forth, as rays of light; to beam; to radiate. Dr. H.More.

Connected with, or having its origin upon, the external surfaceof the body; -- especially applied to the feelings which originate atthe extremities of nerves distributed on the outer surface, as thesensation produced by touching an object with the finger; -- opposedto entoperipheral. H. Spenser.
One who has a pension or allowance granted for support.A youth who had as an exhibitioner from Christ's Hospital. G. Eliot.
The red-breasted merganser (Merganser serrator).
One who evacuates; a nullifier. "Evacuators of the law."Hammond.
Somewhat old; elderly. [R.]
See Encumber. [Obs.]
Growing upon flowers; -- said of certain species of fungi.
Having an edge planed, -- said of a board. Knight.
Pertaining Euler, a German mathematician of the 18th century.Eulerian integrals, certain definite integrals whose properties werefirst investigated by Euler.

A lighted coal, smoldering amid ashes; -- used chiefly in theplural, to signify mingled coals and ashes; the smoldering remains ofa fire. "He rakes hot embers." Dryden.He takes a lighted ember out of the covered vessel. Colebrooke.
The blue buck.

Composed, performed, or uttered on the spur of the moment, orwithout previous study; unpremeditated; off-hand; extempore;extemporary; as, an extemporaneous address or production.-- Ex*tem`po*ra"ne*ous*ly, adv.-- Ex*tem`po*ra"ne*ous*ness,n.

Any liquid preparation of a color and consistency resemblingmilk; as: (a) In pharmacy, an extract of seeds, or a mixture of oiland water united by a mucilaginous substance. (b) In photography, aliquid preparation of collodion holding salt of silver, used in thephotographic process.
A woman affected with ennui. Mrs. Jameson.
An extinct marine reptile from the coal measures of NovaScotia; -- so named because supposed to be of the earliest knownreptiles.
Eyes. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who enunciates or proclaims.
French name for brandy. Cf. Aqua vitæ, under Aqua. Bescherelle.
Belonging to the Equisetaceæ, or Horsetail family.
An emblazoning.
Containing the combustible principle of coal. Kirwan.
The stingfish, or lesser weever (Tranchinus vipera).
A tract of land or a territory inclosed within anotherterritory of which it is independent. See Exclave. [Recent]

That which is expanded or spread out; a wide extent of space orbody; especially, the arch of the sky. "The green expanse." Savage.Lights . . . high in the expanse of heaven. Milton.The smooth expanse of crystal lakes. Pope.
Capable of being erected; as, an erectable feather. Col. G.Montagu.
Of or pertaining to an expedition; as, an expeditionary force.
The act of naturalizing. [R.]
To cause to be extinct. [Obs.] Shak.
Characterized by, or causing, a morbid redness of the skin;relating to erythema.
Having no granules, as chlorophyll in certain conditions. R.Brown.
A jet jump for lifting water or withdrawing air from a space.Ejector condenser (Steam Engine), a condenser in which the vacuum ismaintained by a jet pump.
One who embalms.
The act of electrifying, or the state of being charged withelectricity.
Spreading loosely, especially on one side; as, an effuseinflorescence. Loudon.

A portion of the floor of a room raised above the generallevel, as a place for a bed or a throne; a platform; a dais.He [the teacher] himself should have his desk on a mounted estrade orplatform. J. G. Fitch.
The tubers of Colocasia antiquorum. See Taro.
To dispute. [R.] B. Jonson.
A piece of furniture having a number of uninclosed shelves orstages, one above another, for receiving articles of elegance or use.Fairholt.
Issuing or flowing forth; emanating; passing forth into an act,or making itself apparent by an effect; -- said of mental acts; as,an emanant volition.
A Latin prefix meaning out, out of, from; also, without. SeeEx-.
In an eventual manner; finally; ultimately.
An apparatus for condensing vegetable juices, or for dryingfruit by heat.
The act of exploiting or utilizing. J. D. Whitney.
By means of an elench.
A kind of sour cherry. Bacon.
Not prescribed by official duty.
The process of producing electrotype plates. See Note underElectrotype, n.

The act of banishing, or the state of banishment; especially,the forsaking of one's own country with a renunciation of allegiance.Expatriation was a heavy ransom to pay for the rights of their mindsand souls. Palfrey.
A panegyrical funeral oration.
In the direction of the edge. [Obs.]Three hundred thousand pieces have you stuck Edgelong into theground. B. Jonson.

The exclamation attributed to Archimedes, who is said to havecried out "Eureka! eureka!" (I have found it! I have found it!), uponsuddenly discovering a method of finding out how much the gold ofKing Hiero's crown had been alloyed. Hence, an expression of triumphconcerning a discovery.

Of or pertaining to the church; relating to the organization orgovernment of the church; not secular; as, ecclesiastical affairs orhistory; ecclesiastical courts.Every circumstance of ecclesiastical order and discipline was anabomination. Cowper.Ecclesiastical commissioners for England, a permanent commissionestablished by Parliament in 1836, to consider and report upon theaffairs of the Established Church.-- Ecclesiastical courts, courts for maintaining the discipline ofthe Established Church; -- called also Christian courts. [Eng.] --Ecclesiastical law, a combination of civil and canon law asadministered in ecclesiastical courts. [Eng.] -- Ecclesiastical modes(Mus.), the church modes, or the scales anciently used.-- Ecclesiastical States, the territory formerly subject to the Popeof Rome as its temporal ruler; -- called also States of the Church.
To let blood [Obs.] Burton.
The derivation of the name of a race, tribe, etc., from that ofa fabulous hero, progenitor, etc.
A mineral, commonly of a yellowish green (pistachio) color,occurring granular, massive, columnar, and in monoclinic crystals. Itis a silicate of alumina, lime, and oxide of iron, or manganese.
An actuality; a conception completely actualized, indistinction from mere potential existence.
A lifting up by success; exaltation; inriation with pride ofprosperity. "Felt the elation of triumph." Sir W. Scott.
An attorney who sufficiently excuses the absence of another.
That exhilarates; cheering; gladdening.-- Ex*hil"a*ra`ting*ly, adv.
Exertion. [R.]
Ember days. [Obs.]
The science which treats of the division of mankind into races,their origin, distribution, and relations, and the peculiaritieswhich characterize them.
The science which treats of the viscera of the body.
Same as Indorsee.
See Eloignate.
Exciting nutrition; said of the reflex influence by which thenutritional processes are either excited or modified.
Relating to an effigy.
Practicing; professional. [Obs.] "Every exercent advocate."Ayliffe.
One who enlightens or illuminates; one who, or that which,communicates light to the eye, or clear views to the mind.
The recognition by an animal body of the electrical conditionof external objects.
The east wind.
The quality of being elevated.
Having a head; -- said of most Mollusca; -- opposed toacephalous.
An instrument for ascertaining the quantity of a fluidevaporated in a given time; an atmometer.
Having but one joint; -- said of certain insects.
One who enters into an engagement or agreement; a surety.Several sufficient citizens were engagers. Wood.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an epicondyle.
The red gurnard or cuckoo fish. [Prov. Eng.]
One who emends.
To form like a bowl; to give a globular shape to. [Obs.] Sir P.Sidney.
The adducing of particular examples so as to lead to auniversal conclusion; the argument by induction.

The first rudiments of an organism, whether animal or plant;as:(a) The young of an animal in the womb, or more specifically, beforeits parts are developed and it becomes a fetus (see Fetus).(b) The germ of the plant, which is inclosed in the seed and which isdeveloped by germination. In embryo, in an incipient or undevelopedstate; in conception, but not yet executed. "The company littlesuspected what a noble work I had then in embryo." Swift.
One who, or that which, excites.Hope is the grand exciter of industry. Dr. H. More.
Rendered fierce or frantic. [Obs.] "Like one enfeloned ordistraught." Spenser.
To whirl hither and thither. [Obs.]
Designating, made of, or relating to, flour including aconsiderable part of the bran.
A plane figure of eleven sides and angles.
Eighteenth. [Obs.]
A small sandglass, running about three minutes, for markingtime in boiling eggs; also, a small glass for holding an egg, attable.
A crystal of one species inclosed within one of another, as oneof rutile inclosed in quartz.
Same as Ambassadorial.
Theory or practice of an eclectic.
Making clear; tending to elucidate; as, an elucidative note.

A valuable fur-bearing animal of the genus Mustela (M.erminea), allied to the weasel; the stoat. It is found in thenorthern parts of Asia, Europe, and America. In summer it is brown,but in winter it becomes white, except the tip of the tail, which isalways black.
A white crystalline alkaloid, extracted from sassy bark(Erythrophleum Guineense).
An adder or serpent. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
Act of spitting out. [Obs.] Cockeram.
A treatise upon, or description of, the intestinal glands.
To make beautiful or elegant by ornaments; to decorate; toadorn; as, to embellish a book with pictures, a garden with shrubsand flowers, a narrative with striking anecdotes, or style withmetaphors.
To turn into a forest.
A kind of reflecting microscope. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or consisting of, entrochites, or the joints ofencrinites; -- used of a kind of stone or marble.
One who subsists on charity; a dependent. South.
A boiling up; effervescence. [Obs.] Boyle.
Having no extremes; infinite.
Bloodless. [R.]
The branch of medical science which teaches the method ofacquiring a good habit of body. [Obs.]
A formal recital or exposition of facts; exposure, orrevelation, of something which some one wished to keep concealed.
To speak or write in commendation of (another); to extol inspeech or writing; to praise.
The outside covering of the Bryozoa.
Vinegar; verjuice. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
Having nine sides.
Eternal; everlasting. [Obs.] -- Ev`i*ter"nal*ly, adv. Bp. Hall.
To enfranchise.
Of or pertaining to Eden; paradisaic. "Edenic joys." Mrs.Browning.
The refinement or subtilization of a body, or the increasing ofits virtue or principal property.
See Chitin.
Gradually; gingerly. [R.]

Not belonging to, or dependent upon, a thing; without or beyonda thing; not essential or intrinsic; foreign; as, to separate goldfrom extraneous matter.Nothing is admitted extraneous from the indictment. Landor.-- Ex*tra"ne*ous*ly, adv.
Having the edge worn away so as to be jagged or irregularlytoothed.
Consisting not in words, but in realities. [Obs.]Of these extradictionary and real fallacies, Aristotle and logiciansmake in number six. Sir T. Browne.
An epitomist. Sir W. Hamilton.
To turn into cash; to cash. Sat. Rev.
Relating to epexegesis; explanatory; exegetical.
To make clear; to clear up what is obscure or not understood;to explain.
Scanty; small; slender; diminutive. [R.] "Exiguous resources."Carlyle.-- Ex*ig"uous*ness, n. [R.]
Warm or high praise; panegyric; strong commendation.His encomiums awakened all my ardor. W. Irving.
To contract a rheum. [Obs.] Harvey.
A principle or mixture of principles derived from Euonymusatropurpureus, or spindle tree.
The act of buying. [R.] Arbuthnot.
The alderman or chief officer of an ancient guild. [Obs.]
A pupil; a student.
To sear; to dry up. [Obs.]Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb. Shak.
Same as oedema.
Attracting the humors to the skin; exciting action in the skin;blistering.
Having the capacity of becoming organizable in a high degree,as the matter forming the false membranes which sometimes result fromacute inflammation in a healthy person. Dunglison.
To boil; to seethe; hence, to extract by boiling or seething.[Obs.] Cockeram.
An apparatus for drying substances or preserving them frommoisture; a desiccator; also, less frequently, an agent employed toabsorb moisture, as calcium chloride, or concentrated sulphuric acid.

The lens, or combination of lenses, at the eye end of atelescope or other optical instrument, through which the image formedby the mirror or object glass is viewed. Collimating eyepiece. Seeunder Collimate.-- Negative, or Huyghenian, eyepiece, an eyepiece consisting of twoplano-convex lenses with their curved surfaces turned toward theobject glass, and separated from each other by about half the sum oftheir focal distances, the image viewed by the eye being formedbetween the two lenses. it was devised by Huyghens, who applied it tothe telescope. Campani applied it to the microscope, whence it issometimes called Campani's eyepiece.-- Positive eyepiece, an eyepiece consisting of two plano-convexlenses placed with their curved surfaces toward each other, andseparated by a distance somewhat less than the focal distance of theone nearest eye, the image of the object viewed being beyond bothlenses; -- called also, from the name of the inventor, Ramsden'seyepiece.-- terrestrial, or Erecting eyepiece, an eyepiece used in telescopesfor viewing terrestrial objects, consisting of three, or usuallyfour, lenses, so arranged as to present the image of the objectviewed in an erect position.
That may be exercised, used, or exerted.

Narrated in a grand style; pertaining to or designating a kindof narrative poem, usually called an heroic poem, in which real orfictitious events, usually the achievements of some hero, arenarrated in an elevated style.The epic poem treats of one great, complex action, in a grand styleand with fullness of detail. T. Arnold.
To coat with clay; to lute. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To imbrue; to stain with blood. [Obs.] Spenser.

Of or pertaining to electrical tension; -- said of a supposedpeculiar condition of a conducting circuit during its exposure to theaction of another conducting circuit traversed by a uniform electriccurrent when both circuits remain stationary. Faraday.
Exhibiting; publicly showing. J. Warton.
A red substance obtained from litmus.
Hook-billed; having the upper mandible longer than the lower.
State of being enslaved.

A nymph, the daughter of Air and Earth, who, for love ofNarcissus, pined away until nothing was left of her but her voice.Compelled me to awake the courteous Echo To give me answer from hermossy couch. Milton.Echo organ (Mus.), a set organ pipes inclosed in a box so as toproduce a soft, distant effect; -- generally superseded by the swell.-- Echo stop (Mus.), a stop upon a harpsichord contrived forproducing the soft effect of distant sound.-- To applaud to the echo, to give loud and continuous applause. M.Arnold.I would applaud thee to the very echo, That should applaud again.Shak.
The act of freeing from acids or any soluble substances, byaffusions of water. [R.] Ure.
The distance measured toward the east between two meridiansdrawn through the extremities of a course; distance of departureeastward made by a vessel.
A grazing; a country house. [Spanish America]
To deprive or clear of flesh. Grew.
Pertaining to electrical results produced through physiologicalagencies, or by change of action in a living organism.
Greatly; enormously; shamefully; as, egregiously cheated.
Am entrance. [Obs.]So great an entryng and so large. Chaucer.
Spoliation. [Obs. or R.] Bp. Hall.

A swelling produced by gas or air diffused in the cellulartissue. Emphysema of the lungs, Pulmonary emphysema (Med.), a commondisease of the lungs in which the air cells are distended and theirpartition walls ruptured by an abnormal pressure of the air containedin them.
Capable of being excited, or roused into action; susceptible ofexcitement; easily stirred up, or stimulated.
A hunter's name for the grizzly bear.
An extinct order of Merostomata, of which the genus Eurypterusis the type. They are found only in Paleozoic rocks. [Written alsoEurypterida.]
The state of being balanced; equality of weight. [R.] J.Gregory.
Away from the leaves, or inserted in a different place fromthem; as, extrafoliaceous prickles. Loudon.
The state of being early or forward; promptness.
To fill with breath; to puff up. Sir T. Herbert.
Anything which causes expansion esp. (Mech.) a tool forstretching open or expanding a tube, etc.
Outwardly; externally; on the exterior. Shak.They are exteriorly lifelike. J. H. Morse.
A draught or model from which to build; especially, one of thefull size of the work to be done; a detailed drawing.

That branch of knowledge which has for its subject thecharacteristics of the human family, developing the details withwhich ethnology as a comparative science deals; descriptiveethnology. See Ethnology.
Of or pertaining to an escritoire.
Having the surface covered with irregular, impressed lines.
The reappearance of a heavenly body after an eclipse oroccultation; as, the emersion of the moon from the shadow of theearth; the emersion of a star from behind the moon.
To investigate. [Obs.] Bailey.
One who embezzles.
The part of a plow, or other implement, that turns over theearth; the moldboard.

To give courage to; to inspire with courage, spirit, or hope;to raise, or to increase, the confidence of; to animate; enhearten;to incite; to help forward; -- the opposite of discourage.David encouraged himself in the Lord. 1 Sam. xxx. 6.
One who makes, or is authorized to make, an excuse; anapologist. [Obs.] Hume.
Above or outside of the endoskeleton; epaxial.
To take away the margin of.
Belonging to, or resembling, the Embiotocidæ.-- n.
Spit out, or as if spit out. "Exsputory lines." Cowper.
A selection of passages from the Gospels, as a lesson in divineservice. Porson.
A prefix signifying out of, outside; as in exocarp, exogen,exoskeleton.
Ethylidene. [Obs.]

An inflammatory disease of the skin, characterized by thepresence of redness and itching, an eruption of small vesicles, andthe discharge of a watery exudation, which often dries up, leavingthe skin covered with crusts; -- called also tetter, milk crust, andsalt rheum.
A hydrous arseniate of copper, of an emerald-green color; -- socalled from Erin, or Ireland, where it occurs.
Heating; burning. [Obs.]The wicked enchaufing or ardure of this sin [lust]. Chaucer.
A genus of mytraceous plants, mostly of tropical countries, andincluding several aromatic trees and shrubs, among which are thetrees which produce allspice and cloves of commerce.
A disinheriting; disherisor. [R.]
In a skillful or dexterous manner; adroitly; with readiness andaccuracy.
Lifeless; dead. [Obs.] Johnson.
Oppressive or unreasonably severe in making demands orrequiring the exact fulfillment of obligations; harsh; severe. "Atemper so exacting." T. Arnold -- Ex*act"ing*ly, adv.-- Ex*act"ing*ness, n.
To fasten on, as armor. [Obs.] Spenser.
According to, in harmony with, moral principles or character.
Growth from within; multiplication of cells by endogenousdivision, as in the development of one or more cells in the interiorof a parent cell.
To remove the epidermis of (a skin) with a concave knife, bluntin its middle part, -- as in making chamois leather.
A solid isomeric modification of olein.
An error or mistake in writing or printing.A single erratum may knock out the brains of a whole passage. Cowper.
Pertaining to the epicranium; as epicranial muscles.

The exhibition or depositing of a ship's papers at thecustomhouse, to procure license to land goods; or the giving anaccount of a ship's cargo to the officer of the customs, andobtaining his permission to land the goods. See Enter, v. t., 8, andEntrance, n.,
To shut up in a cloister; to cloister.
Effectively. [Obs.]
To furnish or surround with a collar. [R.]
Relating to or resembling an enigma; not easily explained oraccounted for; darkly expressed; obscure; puzzling; as, anenigmatical answer.
Encystment.
Relating to the endoblast; as, the endoblastic layer.
To separate and throw off; to excrete urine. "The mucus thusexcreted." Hooper.
To accuse; to indict. See Implead.
Serving or tending to emasculate.

Serving or tending to elaborate; constructing with labor andminute attention to details. Elaborative faculty (Metaph.), theintellectual power of discerning relations and of viewing objects bymeans of, or in, relations; the discursive faculty; thought.
State of being entangled; intricate and confused involution;that which entangles; intricacy; perplexity.
Excess. [R.]
Strong attachment to ecclesiastical usages, forms, etc.
To plunge; to implunge. [Obs.] Spenser.
State of being evident.
By the endermic method; as, applied endermically.
The sacrament of the Lord's Supper; the solemn act of ceremonyof commemorating the death of Christ, in the use of bread and wine,as the appointed emblems; the communion.-- See Sacrament.
A genus of leguminous plants growing in the tropics; coraltree; -- so called from its red flowers.
An order of insects, including the earwig. The anterior wingsare short, in the form of elytra, while the posterior wings fold upbeneath them. See Earwig.
Having equal differences; as, the terms of arithmeticalprogression are equidifferent.
A Latin preposition, denoting beyond, outside of; -- often usedin composition as a prefix signifying outside of, beyond, besides, orin addition to what is denoted by the word to which it is prefixed.
Same as Episodic.
Ornament; decoration; embellishment. [Obs.]Hyperbolical exornations . . . many much affect. Burton.
The act of inclosing in a capsule; the growth of a membranearound (any part) so as to inclose it in a capsule.
State of being evangelical.
See Exode.
. See Evil eye under Evil, a.
To encircle with a garland, or with garlands. Sir P. Sidney.
The act of enabling, or the state of being enabled; ability.Bacon.
Capable of being expelled or driven out. "Expellable by heat."Kirwan.
Having equal moments of inertia.
Pertaining to a bone or region on each side of the greatforemen of the skull.-- n.
Performing with speed. [Obs.] Bacon.

Of such a nature relatively to some other associated body orbodies, as to tend to the negative pole of a voltaic battery, inelectrolysis, while the associated body tends to the positive pole; -- the converse or correlative of electro-negative.
Pertaining to the exoskeleton; as exoskeletal muscles.
Having equivalent signification and reach; expressing the samething, but differently.
A leaping out. [R.] Latham.
An instrument for examining the interior of the rectum, theurethra, and the bladder.
See Intrust.
The common newt; -- called also asker, eft, evat, and ewt.
Sending forth; emissive. Boyle.
A cutaneous eruption, consisting of large, round pustules, uponan indurated and inflamed base. Dunglison.
One who entertains.
Characteristic quality of a woman, such as softness,luxuriousness, delicacy, or weakness, which is unbecoming a man;womanish delicacy or softness; -- used reproachfully of men. Milton.
Having the edge broken like battlements; -- said of a bearingsuch as a fess, bend, or the like.
Relating to victory. "An epinicial song." T. Warton.
Quality of being exclusive.
Æsculapian.
A breaking out with some interjectional particle.
To make, or talk in, enigmas; to deal in riddles.
Flowing out; as, effluent beams. Parnell.
Having a tendency to prevent the development of anything,especially of a disease.
Of or pertaining to the continents of Europe and Asia combined.

A male of the human species castrated; commonly, one of a classof such persons, in Oriental countries, having charge of the women'sapartments. Some of them, in former times, gained high official rank.
To catch in a snare. See Insnare.

To form into a body; to invest with a body; to collect into abody, a united mass, or a whole; to incorporate; as, to embody one'sideas in a treatise. [Written also imbody.]Devils embodied and disembodied. Sir W. Scott.The soul, while it is embodied, can no more be divided from sin.South.
That may expire; capable of being brought to an end.
Conveying impressions from the surface of the body to thespinal cord; -- said of certain nerves. Opposed to exodic.
To sew up; to inclose by a seam; hence, to include; to contain.Camden.
Hellebore. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To drop or distill. [Obs.] Johnson.
Worthy of being wished for; desirable. [Obs.] Puller.
The religious or mythological book of the old Scandinaviantribes of German origin, containing two collections of Sagas(legends, myths) of the old northern gods and heroes.
To empty. [Obs.] Harvey.
Pertaining to an embryo, or the initial state of any organ;embryonic.
Right feeling. [R.] Harris.
One who exhibits; one who presents a petition, charge or bill.Shak.
That branch of science which treats of the relation ofelectricity to chemical changes.
See Exauthoration.
A colorless oil (quickly becoming brown), with a pleasant odor,obtained by the decomposition of ericolin.
Possessed of the supposed evil eye; also, looking with envy,jealousy, or bad design; malicious. Shak.
The state of being extensive; wideness; largeness; extent;diffusiveness.
See Effigy. Dryden.
The theory that the heathen divinities originated in thepersonification of elemental powers.
Evangel. [Obs.]The sacred pledge of Christ's evangely. Spenser.
The charge for carrying a parcel by express.
To deposit in the grave; to bury. [Obs.] "Their corses toengrave." Spenser.
A writing. [Obs.]
One who embodies.

A limpid, oily liquid obtained by the destructive distillationof various vegetable and animal substances; -- specifically, an oilconsisting largely of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series.[Written also eupion.]
The range or reach of the eye; eyeshot. "A seat in eyereach ofhim." B. Jonson.
A woman versed in magical arts; a sorceress; also, a woman whofascinates. Shak.
A heating or warming; calefaction. [Obs.] Blount.
To split into scales, especially to become converted intoscales at the result of heat or decomposition.
Same as Elatrometer.
A bar with an eye at one or both ends.

Pertaining to the region of the vomer and the base of theethmoid in the skull. Ethmovomerine plate (Anat.), a cartilaginousplate beneath the front of the fetal brain which the ethmoid regionof the skull is developed.
Pleasing or sweet in sound; euphonic; smooth-sounding. Hallam.-- Eu*pho"ni*ous*ly, adv.
Fair or impartial; unbiased. "Evenhanded justice." Shak.-- E"ven*hand`ed*ly, adv.-- E"ven*hand`ed*ness, n.
A measure for cloth; -- now rarely used. It is of differentlengths in different countries; the English ell being 45 inches, theDutch or Flemish ell 27, the Scotch about 37.
To pierce; to thrill. [Obs.] Sackville.
Extrorse.
A combining form signifying within; as, entoblast.
To interweave; to intertwine. [Obs.] Spenser.
A subclass of fishes, comprising the sharks, the rays, and theChimæra. The skeleton is mainly cartilaginous.
Inclined to eat; hungry; voracious. [R.] Bailey. "Poor, butesurient." Carlyle.
Act of exenterating. [R.]
A boxlike structure with funnel-shaped traps for catching eels;an eelbuck.
One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system. Carlyle.
See Escalop.
To journey or pass thought. [R.]
To place on a throne; hence, to induct into office, as abishop.There openly enthronized as the very elected king. Knolles.
Loneliness; misery. [Obs.]

A game at cards, that may be played by two, three, or fourpersons, the highest card (except when an extra card called the Jokeris used) being the knave of the same suit as the trump, and calledright bower, the lowest card used being the seven, or frequently, intwo-handed euchre, the nine spot. See Bower.
Pertaining to endosmose; of the nature endosmose; osmotic.Carpenter.
One who exalts or raises to dignity.
An earthquake.
To hold in thrall; to enslave. See Inthrall.The bars survive the captive they enthrall. Byron.
A word which is joined to another so closely as to lose itsproper accent, as the pronoun thee in prithee (pray thee).
An ventriloquist. [Obs.]

Lengthwise; along. [Archaic]The doors were all of adamants eterne, I-clenched overthwart andendelong With iron tough. Chaucer.He pricketh endelong the large space. Chaucer.To thrust the raft endlong across the moat. Sir W. Scott.
The upper and outer element of periotic bone, -- in man forminga part of the temporal bone.
See Emplecton.
A pronged fork for turning up the earth.
To widen. [Obs.]
A personification, in German and Scandinavian mythology, of aspirit natural power supposed to work mischief and ruin, esp. tochildren.
Elementariness. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A kind of masonry in which the outer faces of the wall areashlar, the space between being filled with broken stone and mortar.Cross layers of stone are interlaid as binders. [R.] Weale.
One who is versed in ethics, or has written on ethics.
Relating to endostosis; as, endosteal ossification.

Power to produce effects; operation or energy of an agent orforce; production of the effect intended; as, the efficacy ofmedicine in counteracting disease; the efficacy of prayer. "Ofnoxious efficacy." Milton.
Eatable growth of grass for horses and cattle, esp. that ofaftermath.
The public legislative assembly of the Athenians.
See Perigee. [Obs.]
Flowering, or state of flowering; the blooming of flowers;blowth.
To disentangle. [R.]
The state of a part which, from having been soft, has becomehard and swollen by the accumulation of blood in the erectile tissue.
As the eighth in order.
One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.Atterbury.
To seat in a chair. Tennyson.
An external parasitic organism.
So as to have motion or direction parallel to the equator.
To make eternal. Shelton.
The layer of vascular connective tissue lining the medullarycavities of bone.

To superintend the publication of; to revise and prepare forpublication; to select, correct, arrange, etc., the matter of, forpublication; as, to edit a newspaper.Philosophical treatises which have never been edited. Enfield.
A projection on the inner side of the distal end of thenumerus; the internal condyle.
To make froward, perverse, or ungovernable. [Obs.] Sir E.Sandys.
That entices; alluring.
Sized by a machine, and not while in the pulp; -- said ofpaper. Knight.
An eruption of the skin; cutaneous efflorescence.
Having the food yolk, at the commencement of segmentation, in aperipheral position, and the cleavage process confined to the centerof the egg; as, ectolecithal ova.
To imbibe. [Obs.] Skelton.
The cutting a fetus into pieces within the womb, so as toeffect its removal.
With attachment; with interest; earnestly.
The quality of being elastic; elasticity.
A solid preparation obtained by evaporating a solution of adrug, etc., or the fresh juice of a plant; -- distinguished from anabstract. See Abstract, n., 4.
To rise or be given off, as vapor; to pass off, or vanish.Their inspiration exhaled in elegies. Prescott.
Disinterred. [Obs.]
Composed of eleven leaflets; -- said of a leaf.
A writer of an essay, or of essays. B. Jonson.
The doctrine or the practices of the Essenes. De Quincey.
Belonging to elms. [Obs.]
An instrument for intensifying sounds produced by percussion ofthe thorax. Knight.
Explanatory.

A certain property of a body, expressed as a measurablequantity, such that when there is no communication of heat thequantity remains constant, but when heat enters or leaves the bodythe quantity increases or diminishes. If a small amount, h, of heatenters the body when its temperature is t in the thermodynamic scalethe entropy of the body is increased by h . The entropy is regardedas measured from some standard temperature and pressure. Sometimescalled the thermodynamic function.The entropy of the universe tends towards a maximum. Clausius.
One from whom a race, tribe, city, or the like, took its name;an eponym.
A bass instrument of the saxhorn family.

Partly swallowed; disappearing in the jaws of anything; as, aninfant engouled by a serpent; said also of an ordinary, when its twoends to issue from the mouths of lions, or the like; as, a bendengouled.
Exigency. Hooker.
See Empress. [Obs.]
Pertaining to the esophagus. [Written also .]
Relating to the Entomophaga.-- n.
Chosen as the object of mercy or divine favor; set apart toeternal life. "The elect angels." 1 Tim. v. 21.
To transport with delight; to enrapture; to fascinate. Spenser.
In an extraordinary manner or degree.
To soften; to render effeminate.Emolliated by four centuries of Roman domination, the Belgic colonieshad forgotten their pristine valor. Pinkerton.
The thin inner coat of certain spores.
See Impoverish.
A swimming out. [Obs.] Bailey.
Equivocalness.
Marked by impudence. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
An indication.

Pertaining to the elephant, or resembling an elephant(commonly, in size); hence, huge; immense; heavy; as, of elephantineproportions; an elephantine step or tread. Elephantine epoch (Geol.),the epoch distinguished by the existence of large pachyderms.Mantell.-- Elephantine tortoise (Zoöl.), a huge land tortoise; esp., Testudoelephantina, from islands in the Indian Ocean; and T. elephantopus,from the Galapagos Islands.
To tame. [Obs.] Shak.
Having to do with inlaid work; -- especially used withreference to work of the ancient Greeks.
An equitable claim; an equity of redemption; as, an equity to asettlement, or wife's equity, etc.I consider the wife's equity to be too well settled to be shaken.Kent.
To place in a niche. Sterne.
To emasculate; to dispossess of manhood. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
See Indict.
Incorporation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Like, or pertaining to, the genus Euryperus.
A disease of the skin, in which it become enormously thickened,and is rough, hard, and fissured, like an elephant's hide.

The class Echinodermata which includes the sea urchins. Theyhave a calcareous, usually more or less spheroidal or disk-shaped,composed of many united plates, and covered with movable spines. SeeSpatangoid, Clypeastroid. [Written also Echinidea, and Echinoida.]
A genus of perennial, composite herbs including hemp agrimony,boneset, throughwort, etc.
Exhalation. [R.]
Subtile or invisible emanation; exhalation perceived by thesense of smell; especially, noisome or noxious exhalation; as, theeffluvium from diseased or putrefying bodies, or from ill drainage.

Exact agreement between two expressions or magnitudes withrespect to quantity; -- denoted by the symbol =; thus, a = xsignifies that a contains the same number and kind of units ofmeasure that x does. Confessional equality. See under Confessional.
An isopod crustacean, parasitic on shrimps.
Possessing the quality of being effective; productive of, orpowerful to produce, the effect intended; as, an efficacious law.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.
Same as Entropium.
Esteem; opinion; reputation. [Obs.] Steele.

A black substance; -- formerly applied to various preparationsof a black or very dark color. [Written also Æthiops.] [Obs.] Ethiopsmartial (Old Chem.), black oxide of iron.-- Ethiops mineral (Old Chem.), black sulphide of mercury, obtainedby triturating mercury with sulphur.-- Ethiops per se (Old Chem.), mercury in finely divided state,having the appearance of a dark powder, obtained by shaking it up orby exposure to the air.
One who expounds or explains; an interpreter.
See Implore. [Obs.]
developed or executed with care and in minute detail; as, thecarefully elaborated theme.Syn. -- detailed, elaborate.[WordNet 1.5]
To revert, or become forfeited, to the lord, the crown, or theState, as lands by the failure of persons entitled to hold the same,or by forfeiture.
The unlawful permission, by a jailer or other custodian, of aprisoner's departure from custody.
To poison; to impoison. Shak.
A quadrilateral, tailless kite, with convex surfaces exposed tothe wind. This kite was extensively used by Eddy in his famousmeteorological experiments. It is now generally superseded by the boxkite.
The act of extemporizing; the act of doing anything extempore.
See Exsiccate. [Obs.] Holland.
Disposed or apt to take exceptions, or to object; captious.[Obs.]At least effectually silence the doubtful and exceptious. South.-- Ex*cep"tious*ness, n. [Obs.] Barrow.
The act of exaugurating; desecration. [Obs.]

During eternity; always; forever; for an indefinite period; atall times; -- often used substantively with for.Seek the Lord . . . Seek his face evermore. Ps. cv. 4.And, behold, I am alive for evermore. Rev. i. 18.Which flow from the presence of God for evermore. Tillotson.I evermore did love you, Hermia. Shak.
A mineral consisting of both the chloride and the bromide ofsilver.
Pertaining to emancipation, or tending to effect emancipation."Emancipatory laws." G. Eliot.
An instrument for producing sound by means of electriccurrents.
The act of enthroning; hence, the admission of a bishop to hisstall or throne in his cathedral.
Any monocotyledonous plant; -- so named because manymonocotyledons have an endorhizal embryo.
A genus of extinct Cretaceous fishes; -- so named from theirspear-shaped teeth. They were allied to the pike (Esox).
To break forth. [Obs.] B. Jonson.

A parasite of man and of many domestic and wild animals,forming compound cysts or tumors (called hydatid cysts) in variousorgans, but especially in the liver and lungs, which often causedeath. It is the larval stage of the Tænia echinococcus, a smalltapeworm peculiar to the dog.
Each. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Applied to books or editions (esp. of the Greek New Testamentand the classics) printed and published by the Elzevir family atAmsterdam, Leyden, etc., from about 1592 to 1680; also, applied to around open type introduced by them.The Elzevir editions are valued for their neatness, and the elegantsmall types used. Brande & C.
A piece of furniture used as a writing table, commonly withdrawers, pigeonholes, and the like; a secretary or writing desk.
In an ethnical manner.
Mad for freedom. [R.]
A green compound used as a dyestuff, produced from aniline bluewhen acted upon by acid.
A muscle which raises any part.
To emblossom. Savage.
A freed convict. [Australia]

The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community orpeople, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuatesmanners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of aninstitution or social organization.

The doctrine that experience, either that ourselves or ofothers, is the test or criterion of general knowledge; -- opposed tointuitionists.Experientialism is in short, a philosophical or logical theory, not aphilosophical one. G. C. Robertson.
Capable of being thrust out or protruded. J. Fleming.
= Encenia.
Reach of the ear; distance at which words may be heard. Dryden.
To aggravate; to make worse; to lie heavy on. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To make run in a channel. "Its waters were enchanneled." Sir D.Brewster.
Evolved; unfolded. Jer. Taylor.

Designed for, and understood by, the specially initiated alone;not communicated, or not intelligible, to the general body offollowers; private; interior; acroamatic; -- said of the private andmore recondite instructions and doctrines of philosophers. Opposed toexoteric.Enough if every age produce two or three critics of this esotericclass, with here and there a reader to understand them. De Quincey.
Soon; in good season; seasonably; betimes; as, come early.Those that me early shall find me. Prov. viii. 17.You must wake and call me early. Tennyson.
To bring loss or damage to; to harm; to injure. [R.]The trial hath endamaged thee no way. Milton.
Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from itsforming an oil combining with chlorine. [Written also elayle.] SeeEthylene.
One who edits; esp., a person who prepares, superintends,revises, and corrects a book, magazine, or newspaper, etc., forpublication.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cloves; as, eugenic acid.
To render emblematic; as, to emblematicize a picture. [R.]Walpole.
Evangelical principles; evangelism.
Mutual talk or conversation; conference. [Obs.] Sir J. Hayward.
See Ellwand.
See Exigenter.
With egotism.
Tending to facilitate expectoration or to promote discharges ofmucus, etc., from the lungs or throat.-- n.
The quality of being eligible; eligibleness; as, theeligibility of a candidate; the eligibility of an offer of marriage.
One who stands under the eaves, or near the window or door of ahouse, to listen; hence, a secret listener.
See Endogenous.
The science of inscriptions; the art of engraving inscriptionsor of deciphering them.
Capable of being examined or inquired into. Bacon.
A depriving of teeth. [R.] Cockeram.
One who follows an eclectic method.

To use words of equivocal or doubtful signification; to expressone's opinions in terms which admit of different senses, with intentto deceive; to use ambiguous expressions with a view to mislead; as,to equivocate is the work of duplicity.All that Garnet had to say for him was that he supposed he meant toequivocate. Bp. Stillingfleet.

To count; to tell by numbers; to count over, or tell off oneafter another; to number; to reckon up; to mention one by one; toname over; to make a special and separate account of; to recount; as,to enumerate the stars in a constellation.Enumerating the services he had done. Ludlow.
Inclined to emulation; aspiring to competition; rivaling; as,an emulative person or effort. "Emulative zeal." Hoole.
Addiction to drink; habitual drunkenness.
Hard-hearted; sordid; gross. [Poetic] Lowell.
See Exspoliation. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An empty box, crate, cask, etc.; -- used in commerce, esp. intransportation of freight; as, "special rates for empties."
Pertaining to, or like, the genus Etheostoma.-- n.
Capable of being uttered or explained; utterable. Barrow.
An archdeacon. [Obs.]
Capable of being explained or made plain to the understanding;capable of being interpreted. Sir. T. Browne.
Equiangular. [Obs.] Boyle.
Arising from the neurapophysis of a vertebra.
To cover over with, or as with, a mantle; to put about as aprotection. [Obs.] Holland.
To form or constitute the essence or being of. [Obs.] Boyle.
A remedy which promotes discharges, as an emetic, or acathartic.
A twining or twisting together or round; union. Bp. Hacket.
An elastic woven fabric, as a belt, braces or suspenders, etc.,made in part of India rubber. [Colloq.]
A heathen; a pagan. [Obs.]No better reported than impure ethnic and lay dogs. Milton.
Act of drawing out ; exhaustion. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Contaminated with illegality. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Raised; lifted up; -- a term applied to what is also called theabsolute superlative, denoting a high or intense degree of a quality,but not excluding the idea that an equal degree may exist in othercases.
Endermic.
Having one's mental imagery prevailingly of the visual type;having one's thoughts and memories mainly in the form of visualimages. -- Eye"-mind`ed*ness, n.
Embarkation. [R.] Middleton.
A genus of small European and American trees; the spindle tree.The bark is used as a cathartic.
The act of cutting off from the church; excommunication.
One who extols; one who praises.
Deafening; disagreeably loud or shrill; as, ear-splittingstrains.
Capable of being exercised, employed, or enforced; as, theauthority of a magistrate is exercisible within his jurisdiction.
The act of expelling or ejecting a fetus or an egg from thewomb.
Affected with the ergot fungus; as, ergotized rye.
Before the ere long.A man, . . . following the stag, erelong slew him. Spenser.The world, erelong, a world of tears must weep. Milton.
To represent by, or as by, an emblem; to symbolize.Anciently the sun was commonly emblematized by a starry or radiatefigure. Bp. Hurd.

To set an example for; to give a precedent for; to exemplify;to give an instance of; to instance. [Obs.] "I may example mydigression by some mighty precedent." Shak.Burke devoted himself to this duty with a fervid assiduity that hasnot often been exampled, and has never been surpassed. J. Morley.
A tribe of Ophiuroidea, including the genera Euryale,Astrophyton, etc. They generally have the arms branched. SeeAstrophyton.
Tending to extenuate or palliate. Croker.
The act of heaping up. [Obs.] Bailey.
Without a beak.
The watery fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of theinternal ear.
Pertaining to Eleusis, in Greece, or to secret rites in honorof Ceres, there celebrated; as, Eleusinian mysteries or festivals.
See Escurial.
1. An original form; primitive word; root.
The act of sucking out.
A group of chætopod annelids, including those that are notconfined to tubes. See Chætopoda. [Written also Errantes.]
Having a form intermediate between elliptic and lanceolate.
Inspiration; enthusiasm. [R.] "Religious entheasm." Byron.
A side dish; a dainty or relishing dish usually eaten after thejoints or principal dish; also, a sweetmeat, served with a dinner.
See Etern.
The act or art precipitating a metal electro-chemical action,by which a coating is deposited, on a prepared surface, as inelectroplating and electrotyping; galvanoplasty.
A hawk gradually changing the color of its feathers, commonlyin the second year.
To teach; to indoctrinate. [Obs.] Donne.
To cut off, as a vowel or a syllable, usually the final one; tosubject to elision.
Having great extent.

The natural process of formation or assimilation, performed bythe living organs in animals and vegetables, by which a crudesubstance is changed into something of a higher order; as, theelaboration of food into chyme; the elaboration of chyle, or sap, ortissues.
A group which includes the typical copepods and the lerneans.
One of the lateral pieces next to the sternum in the thorax ofinsects.
With expression.
Exposure. Swift.
The quality of being endless; perpetuity.
An unnatural eversion of the eyelids.
Equal law, or a well-adjusted constitution of government. [R.]Mitford.
The outer branch of the legs in certain Crustacea. SeeMaxilliped.
The act of calling out or forth. Sir. T. Browne.The evocation of that better spirit. M. Arnold.
Lying outside of the domain of logic.-- Ex`tra*log"ic*al*ly, adv.
Eager to discover or learn; curious. [Obs.] Todd.-- Ex*quis"i*tive*ly, adv. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A figure of speech by which what is to be understoodaffirmatively is stated negatively, and the contrary; affirmation bycontraries.
An inhabitant of the earth; a mortal.Earthings oft her deemed a deity. Drummond.
To make clear or manifest; to render more intelligible; toillustrate; as, an example will elucidate the subject.
Situated upon or above an artery; -- applied esp. to thebranches of the bronchi given off above the point where the pulmonaryartery crosses the bronchus.
See Lucubration. [Obs.] Evelyn.
To cause or produce electrotonus.
Pertaining to electro-ballistics.
Space. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In an earnest manner.
They go out, or retire from the scene; as, exeunt all exceptHamlet. See 1st Exit.
To take out the entrails of; to disembowel; to gut.
Equal weight; equiponderance.
Relaxation. [R.] Richardson (Dict. ).
Pertaining to exile or banishment, esp. to that of the Jews inBabylon. Encyc. Dict.
To deprive of bones; to take out the bones of; to bone. [Obs.]Bailey.
One of evangelical principles.
Alderman. [Obs.]
To make eternal. [Obs.]Fame . . . eternifies the name. Mir. for Mag.
Elephantiasis. [Obs.] Holland.
To put in a coffin. [R.]
An instrument for measuring the diameters of minute particlesor fibers, from the size of the colored rings produced by thediffraction of the light in which the objects are viewed.
See Escheator. [Obs.]
Existence. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
Without previous study or meditation; without preparation; onthe spur of the moment; suddenly; extemporaneously; as, to write orspeak extempore. Shak.-- a.
Earnest money. Same as Arles penny. [Obs.]
A wandering beyond limits; excess. [Obs.] Smollett.
See Elæoptene.
That degree of softness in a body beginning to melt whichalters its shape; the first or lowest degree of fusibility.
In an eligible manner.
The clear, viscid fluid secreted by the poison glands ofcertain serpents; also, a nitrogenous base contained in this, andsupposed to be the active poisonous principle of the virus. Brande &C.
Just or harmonious proportion or movement, as in thecomposition of a poem, an edifice, a painting, or a statue.
An investigator of electricity; one versed in the science ofelectricity.
Weak or lame in the loins. [Obs.]
The theory that the functions of living organisms are dependentupon electricity or a kindred force.
See Embroilment.
A fold of the endoderm, which projects into the blood cavity ofascidians. See Tunicata.
Relating to, or causing, erythema.
Of or pertaining to electro-kinetics.
Pertaining to the Enaliosauria.-- n.
In an exquisite manner or degree; as, lace exquisitely wrought.To a sensitive observer there was something exquisitely painful init. Hawthorne.
To loose; to pay. [Obs.]
The act of experimenting; practice by experiment. J. S. Mill.
Same as Incumbrance.
Matter ejected; material thrown out; as, the ejecta of avolcano; the ejecta, or excreta, of the body.
Same as Epiglottic.
To extract. [Obs.] Marston.
The rejecting or casting off of some part, more particularly,the outer cuticular layer, as the shells of crustaceans, skins ofsnakes, etc.; molting; ecdysis.
The art or practice of writing epistles.
Poisoner. [Obs.] Bacon.
A writer of epitaphs. Nash.
Receiving by the ear. [Obs.] Hewyt.
Belonging to, or relating to, the East Indies.-- n.
By an emanation.
An instrument for measuring energy in ergs.
Arising; coming to light. [Obs.]
In an enticing manner; charmingly. "She . . . sings mostenticingly." Addison.
Good or established order or arrangement. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
To earn. [Obs.] See Addle, to earn. Boucher.
Having the form, appearance, or nature, of an extract.
An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.
Admitted to a state of paradisaic happiness. [R.] Davies (Wit'sPilgr. ).
Erythrolein.
A mover or exciter of electricity; as apparatus for generatinga current of electricity.
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the OldWorld. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.

To cry out from earnestness or passion; to utter withvehemence; to call out or declare loudly; to protest vehemently; tovociferate; to shout; as, to exclaim against oppression with wonderor astonishment; "The field is won!" he exclaimed.
Capable of being exhaled or evaporated. Boyle.
One who, or that which, emasculates.
An officer in the Court of King's Bench and Common Pleas whoseduty it was make out exigents. The office in now abolished. Cowell.
See Arrish.
One who pronounces an éloge.
Having the ear perforated.
One who extenuates.
To a great extent; widely; largely; as, a story is extensivelycirculated.
To turn to marble; to harden. [Obs.]Thou dost emmarble the proud heart. Spenser.
Growing or developing within cartilage; -- applied esp. todeveloping bone.

To demand or require authoritatively or peremptorily, as aright; to enforce the payment of, or a yielding of; to compel toyield or to furnish; hence, to wrest, as a fee or reward when none isdue; -- followed by from or of before the one subjected to exaction;as, to exact tribute, fees, obedience, etc., from or of some one.He said into them, Exact no more than that which is appointed you.Luke. iii. 13.Years of servise past From grateful souls exact reward at lastDryden.My designs Exact me in another place. Massinger.
The act of vomiting. [Obs.] Swift.
Divination by the use of a mirror.
Tending to excite; exciting.
Quality or state of being equable.

An excrescent appendage, as, a wart or tumor; anything growingout unnaturally from anything else; a preternatural or morbiddevelopment; hence, a troublesome superfluity; an incumbrance; as, anexcrescence on the body, or on a plant. "Excrescences of joy." Jer.Taylor.The excrescences of the Spanish monarchy. Addison.
One who, or that which, brings forth, elicits, or extracts.Stimulus must be called an eductor of vital ether. E. Darwin.
An erector; one who raises or builds.
The sixth month of the Jewish year, by the sacred reckoning, orthe twelfth, by the civil reckoning, corresponding nearly to themonth of September.
Having no excuse; not admitting of excuse or apology. Whillock.

A kind of natural ebullition; that commotion of a fluid whichtakes place when some part of the mass flies off in a gaseous form,producing innumerable small bubbles; as, the effervescence of acarbonate with citric acid.
The theory of generation which holds that the germ is createdentirely new, not merely expanded, by the procreative power of theparents. It is opposed to the theory of evolution, also tosyngenesis.
Sickness; ailment; sorrow. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
To come out finally or in conclusion; to result; to come topass.
Having a power of enchantment; charming; fascinating.-- En*chant"ing*ly, adv.
Having the color or appearance of unbleached stuff, as silk,linen, or the like.
A native or a naturalized inhabitant of England.
That may be ended; terminable.
Extirpative.
Edible. [Obs.] "Edulious pulses." Sir T. Browne.
A cathartic substance obtained, in the form of yellowish orgreenish cakes, as the dried residue of the juice of the wild orsquirting cucumber (Ecballium agreste, formerly called MomordicaElaterium).
Like a wild beast; fierce. [Obs.]
To garrison; to put in garrison, or to protect by a garrison.Bp. Hall.
Avoidable.
Amber; also, the alloy of gold and silver, called electrum.
Having the same form; uniform.-- E`qui*for"mi*ty, n. Sir T. Browne.
An epigrammatist. Jer. Taylor.
Same as Expectorant. Harvey.
A method of determining the presence or absence of life in ananimal organism with a current of electricity, by noting the presenceor absence of muscular contraction.
To take exception; to object; -- usually followed by to,sometimes by against; as, to except to a witness or his testimony.Except thou wilt except against my love. Shak.
One who embroils.
Capable of being quenched, destroyed, or suppressed.
A sudden springing or leaping out. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A euphemistic name for the Furies of Erinyes.
A cap or cover to protect the ear from cold.

To submit, as a document, to a court or officer, in course ofproceedings; also, to present or offer officially or in legal form;to bring, as a charge.He suffered his attorney-general to exhibit a charge of high treasonagainst the earl. Clarendon.
Capable of being enunciated or expressed.
The rank or office of an emperor.
One versed in ethnology; a student of ethnology.
Pertaining to the epigastrium, or to the epigastric region.
