The state of being enormous.
Act of endeavoring; endeavor. [Obs.] Spenser.
A phantom or specter. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.

To remove from one country or State to another, for the purposeof residence; to migrate from home.Forced to emigrate in a body to America. Macaulay.They [the Huns] were emigrating from Tartary into Europe in the timeof the Goths. J. H. Newman.
To enroot; to implant. [Obs.] Spenser.
Extortionate.
To be equal in weight; to weigh as much as another thing. Bp.Wilkins.
The female of the sheep, and of sheeplike animals.
A furious attack made by troops on a fortified place, in whichladders are used to pass a ditch or mount a rampart.Sin enters, not by escalade, but by cunning or treachery.Buckminster.
Serving or tending to form an eschar;; producing a scar;caustic.
To call forth or increase the vital activity of an organism, orany of its parts.

To get away from by artifice; to avoid by dexterity,subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to escape from cleverly;as, to evade a blow, a pursuer, a punishment; to evade the force ofan argument.The heathen had a method, more truly their own, of evading theChristian miracles. Trench.
A device for measuring, or an instrument for indicating, energyexpended or work done; a dynamometer. -- Er`go*met"ric (#), a.
The state of being eunuch. Bp. Hall.
Room to extend the elbows on each side; ample room for motionor action; free scope. "My soul hath elbowroom." Shak.Then came a stretch of grass and a little more elbowroom. W. G.Norris.
The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwardsdiscovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missinganalogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekkabor.
An electrotype.
Capable of imparting or exercising energy.Those nobler exercises of energizing love. Bp. Horsley.
The dominion of an ethnarch; principality and rule. Wright.
The act of equalizing, or state of being equalized.Their equalization with the rest of their fellow subjects. Burke.
Disposed to embrace; fond of caressing. [R.] Thackeray.
Same as Electrotype.
Act of enduing; induement.
A fungus of the genus Geoglossum.
To look or search narrowly; to look about; to watch; to takenotice; to spy.Stand by the way, and espy. Jer. xlviii. 19.
The act of expressing; expression; utterance; representation.[Obs.]An operation more divine Than breath or pen can give expressure to.Shak.
Same as Impalement.
One of the yarns of the worsted warp in a Brussels carpet.

The act of exempting; the state of being exempt; freedom fromany charge, burden, evil, etc., to which others are subject;immunity; privilege; as, exemption of certain articles from seizure;exemption from military service; exemption from anxiety, suffering,etc.
Comparable. [Obs. or R.]
A person subjected to examination. [Obs.] Bacon.
Tending to exaggerate; involving exaggeration. "Exaggerativelanguage." Geddes. "Exaggerative pictures." W. J. Linton.-- Ex*ag"ger*a*tive*ly, adv. Carlyle.
In an equable manner.
See Eddish. [Obs.]
Endogenous.
Having a tendency to purify or to sweeten by removing orcorrecting acidity and acrimony.
To inclose as in a case. See Incase. Beau. & Fl.

To involve in difficulties concerning money matters; toincumber with debt; to beset with urgent claims or demands; -- saidof a person or his affairs; as, a man or his business is embarrassedwhen he can not meet his pecuniary engagements.
The act of eternizing; the act of rendering immortal or famous.
Rendering thanks for favors.
A mark, record, or tracing, made by the action of electricity.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, ethyl; as, ethylicalcohol.
In an endemic manner.
The more liquid or volatile portion of certain oily substance,as distinguished from stearoptene, the more solid parts. [Writtenalso elaoptene.]
An officer in attendance upon a hospital, but not residing init; esp., one who cares for the out-patients.

Pertaining to, or derived from, gallnuts or gallic acid; as,ellagic acid. Ellagic acid (Chem.), a white crystalline substance,C14H8O9, found in bezoar stones, and obtained by the oxidation ofgallic acid.
A fossil resin, so called from its strong, peculiar, pleasantodor.

Pertaining to the epicycloid, or having its properties.Epicycloidal wheel, a device for producing straight-line motion fromcircular motion, on the principle that a pin fastened in theperiphery of a gear wheel will describe a straight line when thewheel rolls around inside a fixed internal gear of twice itsdiameter.
See Imbrue, Embrew. [Obs.]
The prince of the evil spirits; Satan. [Written also Eblees.]
Having the wings of an eagle; swift, or soaring high, like aneagle. Shak.
A little, perennial, white, woolly plant (Leontopodiumalpinum), growing at high elevations in the Alps.
One who makes an entrance or beginning. A. Seward.
The treatment of disease by electricity.
Embolic invagination. See under Invagination.

To draw on, by exciting hope or desire; to allure; to attract;as, the bait enticed the fishes. Often in a bad sense: To leadastray; to induce to evil; to tempt; as, the sirens enticed them tolisten.Roses blushing as they blow, And enticing men to pull. Beau. & Fl.My son, if sinners entice thee, consent thou not. Prov. i. 10.Go, and thine erring brother gain, Entice him home to be forgiven.Keble.
A species of tern, esp. the sooty tern (Sterna fuliginosa) ofthe West Indies. In the Bahama Islands the name is applied to thetropic bird, Phaëthon flavirostris.
According to elements; literally; as, the words, "Take, eat;this is my body," elementally understood.
One who accepts the doctrine of experientialism. Also usedadjectively.
To cover with scales.
A nursery of snails. [Obs.] Addison.
Serving to explain; expository. Bp. Pearson.
That branch of physiology which treats of electric phenomenaproduced through physiological agencies.

Satisfying desire; giving content; adequate to meet the want;sufficient; -- usually, and more elegantly, following the noun towhich it belongs.How many hired servants of my father's have bread enough and tospare! Luke xv. 17.
A genus of vascular, cryptogamic, herbaceous plants; -- alsocalled horsetails.
A strait; a narrow tract of water, where the tide, or acurrent, flows and reflows with violence, as the ancient fright ofthis name between Eubæa and Bæotia. Hence, a flux and reflux. Burke.
Without luster, or dull and roughish to the touch; as, anearthy fracture.
A copy; a transcript. [Obs.] Bailey.
Capable of being executed; feasible; as, an executable project.[R.]
To explore. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
See Inwreathe. Shelton.
Without exception.A universal, . . . exceptionless disqualification. Bancroft.
One who explains; an expounder or expositor; a commentator; aninterpreter.
A hedgehog.
Having no stipules. Martyn.
A study; an exercise; a piece for practice of some specialpoint of technical execution.
To make a bishop of by consecration. Southey.
To swell out. [Obs.] Cockeram.
One who, or that which, erases; esp., a sharp instrument or apiece of rubber used to erase writings, drawings, etc.
See Exsanguious.
Designating, or pert. to, a reaction which occurs withabsorption of heat; formed by such a reaction; as, an endothermicsubstance; -- opposed to exothermic.

The cutting off or suppression of a vowel or syllable, for thesake of meter or euphony; esp., in poetry, the dropping of a finalvowel standing before an initial vowel in the following word, whenthe two words are drawn together.

The unit of work or energy in the C. G. S. system, being theamount of work done by a dyne working through a distance of onecentimeter; the amount of energy expended in moving a body onecentimeter against a force of one dyne. One foot pound is equal to13,560,000 ergs.
A place where eggs are deposited (as by sea birds) or kept; anest of eggs. [R.]
Full of anxiety or yearning. [Obs.] P. Fletcher.
The act of going; egress. [R.] B. Jonson.
A white, crystalline hydrocarbon, regarded as a polymericvariety of ethylene, obtained in heavy oil of wine, the residue leftafter making ether; -- formerly called also concrete oil of wine.
Any parasite which lives on the exterior of animals; -- opposedto endoparasite.-- Ec`to*par`a*sit"ic, a.
To pour out. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
To cover or adorn with blossoms.On the white emblossomed spray. J. Cunningham.
See Epencephalon.
An ornament on a frieze or capital, consisting of festoons offruit, flowers, leaves, etc. [Written also encarpa.]
Same as Imparadise.
Increasing by equal increments; as, an equicrescent variable.
Ethereality.
The act of disburdening, discharging, or freeing morally from acharge or imputation; also, the state of being disburdened or freedfrom a charge.
The act of excogitating; a devising in the thoughts; invention;contrivance.
Freeing from a burden or obligation; tending to exonerate.
An exclamatory sentence, or striking reflection, which sums upor concludes a discourse.
One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom. By manywriters it was formerly included in the Radiata. [Written alsoEchinoderma.]
Heaving (such or so many) eyes; -- used in composition; assharp-eyed; dull-eyed; sad-eyed; ox-eyed Juno; myriad-eyed.
Towards the equinox.
The quality of being effectual.
Diverging from, or lacking conformity to, a type.
A book of the Apocrypha.
The addition of a letter at the end of a word, without changingits sense; as, numb for num, whilst for whiles.
One who, or that which, exhausts or draws out.
In an erect manner or posture.
Capable of being eluded; evadible.
See Nucleolus.
One of a sect among the Jews in the time of our Savior,remarkable for their strictness and abstinence.
Otherwise. [R.]
An unusual redness, esp. in the plumage of birds, or hair ofmammals, independently of age, sex, or season.
The garden where Adam and Eve first dwelt; hence, a delightfulregion or residence.
Having power or a tendency to exert; using exertion.
To throw as a lance; to hurl; to dart. [R.]While thy unerring hand elanced . . . a dart. Prior.
A precious stone of a rich green color, a variety of beryl. SeeBeryl.
One employed by another.
Applause. [Obs.] Hammond.
To invest or adorn with a robe; to attire.
The state of rising above others; a projection. Evelyn. Boyle.

An instrument intended to replace the knife in many operations,the parts operated on being severed by the crushing effect producedby the gradual tightening of a steel chain, so that hemorrhage rarelyfollows.
Forced out at the surface; as, extrusive rocks; -- contrastedwith intrusive.
A formal eulogy. Smollett.
The scaling off of a bone, a rock, or a mineral, etc.; thestate of being exfoliated.
Pertaining to embolism; intercalary; as, embolismal months.
An issue.
Mystery; esoterics; -- opposed to exotery. A. Tucker.
In an elfish manner.
Clothed or adorned with the fur of the ermine. Pope.
The art or process of determining he constituents of a gaseousmixture by means of the eudiometer, or for ascertaining the purity ofthe air or the amount of oxygen in it.
Affected with elephantiasis; characteristic of elephantiasis.
A name given by Lestiboudois to dicotyledons; -- so calledbecause the plumule is naked.
Explicative. Barrow.
Pertaining to eczema; having the characteristic of eczema.
To talk or write as an egotist. Cowper.
Same as Intertissued.
Greediness; voracity; ravenousness; rapacity. Bacon.
A drink consisting of eggs beaten up with sugar, milk, and(usually) wine or spirits.
One who emblazons; also, one who publishes and displaysanything with pomp.
Bound with a kerchief; draped; hooded; covered. Milton.That soft, enkerchiefed hair. M. Arnold.
The art or science of measuring the force or velocity ofprojectiles by means of electricity.
Without bracts.

Any large, rapacious bird of the Falcon family, esp. of thegenera Aquila and Haliæetus. The eagle is remarkable for strength,size, graceful figure, keenness of vision, and extraordinary flight.The most noted species are the golden eagle (Aquila chrysaëtus); theimperial eagle of Europe (A. mogilnik or imperialis); the Americanbald eagle (Haliæetus leucocephalus); the European sea eagle (H.albicilla); and the great harpy eagle (Thrasaetus harpyia). Thefigure of the eagle, as the king of birds, is commonly used as anheraldic emblem, and also for standards and emblematic devices. SeeBald eagle, Harpy, and Golden eagle.
Exampleless. [Wrongly formed.] B. Jonson.

The act of exuding; sweating; a discharge of humors, moisture,juice, or gum, as through pores or incisions; also, the substanceexuded.Resins, a class of proximate principles, existing in almost allplants and appearing on the external surface of many of them in theform of exudations. Am. Cyc.
An order of mammals including the armadillos, sloths, andanteaters; -- called also Bruta. The incisor teeth are rarelydeveloped, and in some groups all the teeth are lacking.
Capacity for performing work.
The highest heaven, where the pure element of fire was supposedby the ancients to subsist.The empyrean rung With hallelujahs. Milton.
See Eccentric.
Having power to examine; appointed to examine; as, an examiningcommittee.
Freed from wrinkles; smooth.
The epidermal cells of rootlets, specially adapted to absorbliquids. Goodale.
Out of the center.
Of or pertaining to the equator; as, equatorial climates; also,pertaining to an equatorial instrument.
Endogeny.
Ardor inspired by passion or enthusiasm.
To move. [Obs.] Thomson.
Belonging to, or resembling, egophony.
Distillation. [Obs.]An exudation or extillation of petrifying juices. Derham.
A justice of the peace; irenarch.

An instrument for detecting the presence of electricity, orchanges in the electric state of bodies, or the species ofelectricity present, as by means of pith balls, and the like.Condensing electroscope (Physics), a form of electroscope in which anincrease of sensibility is obtained by the use of a condenser.
See Interlace.
To utter or pronounce with a particular stress of voice; tomake emphatic; as, to emphasize a word or a phrase.
A tempestuous northeast wind which blows in the Mediterranean.See Levanter.A tempestuous wind called Euroclydon. Acts xxvii. 14.
A person examined.
One who investigates the derivation of words.

The forms required by good breeding, or prescribed byauthority, to be observed in social or official life; observance ofthe proprieties of rank and occasion; conventional decorum;ceremonial code of polite society.The pompous etiquette to the court of Louis the Fourteenth. Prescott.
Accomplishment; fulfillment. [Obs.] Killingbeck.
A medicine composed of powders, or other ingredients,incorporated with some convserve, honey, or sirup; a confection. Seethe note under Confection.
Of or pertaining to good digestion; easy of digestion; having agood digestion; as, eupeptic food; an eupeptic man.Wrapt in lazy eupeptic fat. Carlyle.
An air plant which grows on other plants, but does not deriveits nourishment from them. See Air plant.
Toothless.
An eyelash. [A child's word.]
Jagged or irregularly toothed, as if nibbled out or gnawed.-- E*rose"ly, adv.
Beyond what is due, usual, expected, or necessary; additional;supernumerary; also, extraordinarily good; superior; as, extra work;extra pay. "By working extra hours." H. Spencer.
Extension. [R.] Drayton.

A plug of some substance lodged in a blood vessel, beingbrought thither by the blood current. It consists most frequently ofa clot of fibrin, a detached shred of a morbid growth, a globule offat, or a microscopic organism.
Any disease or symptoms of disease referable to disorders ofthe brain; as, lead encephalopathy, the cerebral symptoms attendingchronic lead poisoning.

Acting through the skin, or by direct application to the skin.Endermic method, that in which the medicine enters the system throughthe skin, being applied either to the sound skin, or to the surfacedenuded of the cuticle by a blister.
Capable of being converted into vapor, or dissipated byevaporation.
To inclose in a brothel. [Obs.] Donne.
Entity, being, or existence; an actually existing being; also,God, as the Being of Beings.
Select; choice; hence, extraordinary, excellent. [Obs.]The eximious and arcane science of physic. Fuller.
An early, and now a poetic, name of Ireland.
To excuse for nonappearance in court. "I 'll not essoin thee."Quarles.
See Ædile.
An island. See Eyot.
Washington; -- a nickname alluding to the abundance ofevergreen trees.
See Nucleus.
Danewort.
An offering to a church in fulfillment of a vow.
A ferment extracted from madder root, possessing the power ofinducing alcoholic fermentation in solutions of sugar.
Superiority; superfluity. [Obs.] Sir K. Digby.
Epic.-- Ep"ic*al*ly, adv.Poems which have an epical character. Brande & C.His [Wordsworth's] longer poems (miscalled epical). Lowell.
The office or charge of an editor; care and superintendence ofa publication.
See Estoile.

The state of being ven, level, or disturbed; smoothness;horizontal position; uniformity; impartiality; calmness; equanimity;appropriate place or level; as, evenness of surface, of a fluid atrest, of motion, of dealings, of temper, of condition.It had need be something extraordinary, that must warrant an ordinaryperson to rise higher than his own evenness. Jer. Taylor.
Unbridled license; unruliness. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Looking, or narrowly examining; prying. [Obs.] "Thoseemissitious eyes." Bp. Hall.
Forming an exception; not ordinary; uncommon; rare; hence,better than the average; superior. Lyell.This particular spot had exceptional advantages. Jowett (Th. )-- Ex*cep"tion*al*ly(#), adv.
Having power, or a tendency, to enervate; weakening. [R.]
One who educates; a teacher.
To cause to shine with abundance of light; to radiate; to beam.[R.]His eyes effulging a peculiar fire. Thomson.
A student of, or one versed in, epigraphy.
The more granular cells, which finally become internal, in manysegmenting ova, as those of mammals.
The herb agrimony. [Obs.]
See Plaster. [Obs.] Wiseman.
One who believes in, or advocates the theory of, epigenesis.
The act of exploring, penetrating, or ranging over for purposesof discovery, especially of geographical discovery; examination; as,the exploration of unknown countries; (Med.)
Same as Indorsement.
A massive piece of stone or wood laid immediately on the abacusof the capital of a column or pillar; -- now called architrave.
In an eternal manner.That which is morally good or evil at any time or in any case, mustbe also eternally and unchangeably so. South.Where western gales eternally reside. Addison.
The time of evening; evening. [Poetic.] Spenser.

A real right, susceptible of assignment and of descent, chargedon productive real estate, the right being coupled with the enjoymentof the property on condition of taking care of the estate and payingtaxes, and sometimes a small rent. Heumann.

A concretionary nodule of clay ironstone, of the size of awalnut or larger, so called by the ancients, who believed that theeagle transported these stones to her nest to facilitate the layingof her eggs; aëtites.
Like or pertaining to the Elapidæ, a family of poisonousserpents, including the cobras. See Ophidia.
To stimulate. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A continuous and, usually, structureless layer which coversmore or less of the exterior of many corals.
To exorcise or renounce by blowing.
A keeping watch. [Obs.] Bailey.
See Epi-.
Pertaining the reaction (contraction) of the muscles underelectricity, or their sensibility to it.
To act as a bishop; to fill the office of a prelate. [Obs.]Feeding the flock episcopating. Milton.
Having the power of driving out or away; serving to expel.The expulsive power of a new affection. Chalmers.
A contrivance used to supply small quantities of sweetenedliquid, water, etc., to any mixture, or to test tubes, etc.; adropping bottle.

Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, ether; as, etherealsalts. Ethereal oil. (Chem.) See Essential oil, under Essential.-- Ethereal oil of wine (Chem.), a heavy, yellow, oily liquidconsisting essentially of etherin, etherol, and ethyl sulphate. It isthe oily residuum left after etherification. Called also heavy oil ofwine (distinguished from oil of wine, or oenanthic ether).-- Ethereal salt (Chem.), a salt of some organic radical as a base;an ester.
The watery eye; a disease in which the tears accumulate in theeye, and trickle over the cheek.

Calling or rousing into action; producing excitement; as,exciting events; an exciting story.-- Ex*cit"ing*ly, adv. Exciting causes (Med.), those whichimmediately produce disease, or those which excite the action ofpredisposing causes.
A membranaceous or calcareous septum with which some mollusksclose the aperture of the shell during the time of hibernation, oræstivation.
That which is earned; wages gained by work or services; moneyearned; -- used commonly in the plural.As to the common people, their stock is in their persons and in theirearnings. Burke.
Pertaining to, affected with, or of the nature of, epilepsy.
The act of enswathing, or the state of being enswathed.
One who escapes.
A species of mixed action, which lies for the recovery ofpossession of real property, and damages and costs for the wrongfulwithholding of it. Wharton.
Heathenism; paganism; idolatry. [Obs.] "Taint of ethnicism." B.Jonson.

Raised to lofty height; elevated; extolled; refined; dignified;sublime.Wiser far than Solomon, Of more exalted mind. Milton.Time never fails to bring every exalted reputation to a strictscrutiny. Ames.-- Ex*alt"ed*ly, adv.-- Ex*alt"ed*ness, n. "The exaltedness of some minds." T. Gray.
A shoemaker's awl. [Prov. Eng.]
A riding, or the act of riding, on horseback; horsemanship.The pretender to equitation mounted. W. Irving.

Exciting motion; -- said of that portion of the nervous systemconcerned in reflex action, by which impressions are transmitted to anerve center and then reflected back so as to produce muscularcontraction without sensation or volition.
An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, andrarely for a work of art.
To vanish.Or like the rainbow's lovely form, Evanishing amid the storm. Burns.
To bring forth, as young; to yean. "In eaning time." Shak.
The act if effacing; also, the result of the act.
Having a bad countenance or appearance; ill-favored; blemished;deformed. Bacon.-- E"vil-fa`vored*ness, n. Deut. xvi. 1.
One who regards the Church primarily as an establishment formedby the State, and overlooks its intrinsic spiritual character.Shipley.
The science which treats of endemic affections.
Bloodless. [Obs.] See Exsanguious. Sir T. Browne.

An objection, oral or written, taken, in the course of anaction, as to bail or security; or as to the decision of a judge, inthe course of a trail, or in his charge to a jury; or as to lapse oftime, or scandal, impertinence, or insufficiency in a pleading; also,as in conveyancing, a clause by which the grantor excepts somethingbefore granted. Burrill.
Having the form of the equisetum.
Beyond the limits of a parish.-- Ex`tra*pa*ro"chi*al*ly, adv.
The act of expropriating; the surrender of a claim to exclusiveproperty; the act of depriving of ownership or proprietary rights. W.Montagu.The expropriation of bad landlords. M. Arnold.
, but properly a participle. With rejection or exception of;excluding; except. "Excepting your worship's presence." Shak.No one was ever yet made utterly miserable, excepting by himself.Lubbock.
Situated outside of a joint.
One who exists.

That branch of science which treats of the laws governing thephysical or mechanical, in distinction from the vital, forces, andwhich comprehends the consideration and general investigation of thewhole range of the forces concerned in physical phenomena. [R.]
Relating to, or consisting of, edicts; as, the Roman edictallaw.
One who affects excessive refinement and elegance of language;-- applied esp. to a class of writers, in the age of Elizabeth, whoseproductions are marked by affected conceits and high-flown diction.
To interpret (mythology) on the theory of euhemerism.
Of European and Asiatic descent; of or pertaining to bothEurope and Asia; as, the great Eurasian plain.
That may be exempted.
See . Shenstone.
The office or status of an elector.
An affectation of excessive elegance and refinement oflanguage; high-flown diction.
An empress. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A woman who is an exactor. [R.] B. Jonson.
A deformity in which the urethra opens upon the top of thepenis, instead of at its extremity.
Above, or on the dorsal side of, the axis of the skeleton;episkeletal.
Of or pertaining to certain veins of feldspathic or porphyriticrock crossing metalliferous veins in the mining districts ofCornwall; as, an elvan course.
The state of being exuberant; an overflowing quantity; acopious or excessive production or supply; superabundance; richness;as, an exuberance of joy, of fancy, or of foliage.
The name given to a hypothetical element, -- later discoveredand called gallium. See Gallium, and cf. Ekabor.
To thrust out; to force, press, or push out; to expel; to driveoff or away. "Parentheses thrown into notes or extruded to themargin." Coleridge.
One who extirpates or roots out; a destroyer.
Tending to edification. Bp. Hall.
Used in entreaty; pleading. [R.] "Entreative phrase." A.Brewer.
Excruciated; tortured.And here my heart long time excruciate. Chapman.
Funereal. [Obs.] Drayton.
Making erect or upright; raising; tending to erect.
One who, or that which, enlivens, animates, or invigorates.
In an eloquent manner.

A church festival celebrated on the 6th of January, the twelfthday after Christmas, in commemoration of the visit of the Magi of theEast to Bethlehem, to see and worship the child Jesus; or, as othersmaintain, to commemorate the appearance of the star to the Magi,symbolizing the manifestation of Christ to the Gentles; Twelfthtide.
Rising; relating to the east. [R.]
To look in the face of; to apprehend; to regard. [R.] Keats.From the very dawn of existence the infant must envisage self, andbody acting on self. McCosh.

A particular stress of utterance, or force of voice, given inreading and speaking to one or more words whose signification thespeaker intends to impress specially upon his audience.The province of emphasis is so much more important than accent, thatthe customary seat of the latter is changed, when the claims ofemphasis require it. E. Porter.
Same as Anaphora. Gibbs.
A defense for the shoulder, composed of flexible overlappingplates of metal, used in the 15th century; -- the origin of themodern epaulette. Fairholt.
Pertaining to, derived from. or resembling, ethene or ethylene;as, ethenic ether.

A true copy, duplicate, or extract of an original writing orrecord, esp. of amercements or penalties set down in the rolls ofcourt to be levied by the bailiff, or other officer. Cowell. Estreatof a recognizance, the extracting or taking out a forfeitedrecognizance from among the other records of the court, for thepurpose of a prosecution in another court, or it may be in the samecourt. Burrill.
The newt.
A morbid degree of excitement or irritation in an organ.Hoblyn.
Acetylene.
A term applied by Brücke to a substance present in small amountin starch granules, colored red by iodine.
An order of holothurians mostly found in the deep sea. They areremarkable for their bilateral symmetry and curious forms. [Writtenalso Elasmopoda.]
Relating to the epipubis.
One who, or that which, endures or lasts; one who bears,suffers, or sustains.
Incision of the intestines, especially in reducing certaincases of hernia.
See Emerods. [Obs.]
To deprive of the tongue. [Obs.] Davies (Holy Roode).
The act of softening or relaxing; relaxation. Bacon.
The act of eliciting. [Obs.] Abp. Bramhall.
In an explicit manner; clearly; plainly; without disguise orreservation of meaning; not by inference or implication; as, heexplicitly avows his intention.
Same as Equivalve or Equivalved.
To inclose, as in a frame.
One who estimates or values; a valuer. Jer. Taylor.

The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or thenumber of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginningof the year. Annual epact, the excess of the solar year over thelunar year, -- being eleven days.-- Menstrual epact, or Monthly epact, the excess of a calendar monthover a lunar.
To wind about; to encircle.In the circle of his arms Enwound us both. Tennyson.
See Octodecimo.

A valuing or rating by the mind, without actually measuring,weighing, or the like; rough or approximate calculation; as, anestimate of the cost of a building, or of the quantity of water in apond.Weigh success in a moral balance, and our whole estimate is changed.J. C. Shairp.
Of an even, composed frame of mind; of a steady temper; noteasily elated or depressed. Bp. Gauden.
a mineral, consisting chiefly of the silicate of bismuth, foundat Freiberg; -- called also culytine.
To excite fever in. [R.] A. Seward.
In an eccentric manner.Drove eccentrically here and there. Lew Wallace.
That branch of science which treats of epidemics.
A morbid condition characterized by automatic and purposelessrepetition of words or imitation of actions.

The practice of too frequently using the word I; hence, aspeaking or writing overmuch of one's self; self-exaltation; self-praise; the act or practice of magnifying one's self or paradingone's own doings. The word is also used in the sense of egoism.His excessive egotism, which filled all objects with himself.Hazlitt.
To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as theindigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete bythe lungs, skin, or kidneys.
A disease in wheat, in which the blackened and contractedgrain, or ear, is filled with minute worms.
Calling forth; serving to evoke; developing.Evocative power over all that is eloquent and expressive in thebetter soul of man. W. Pater.
pl. of Elf.
To adorn by illuminating or ornamenting with colored anddecorated letters and figures, as a book or manuscript. [R.]Palsgrave.
Protruded, or grown out, as an evagination; turned inside out;unsheathed; evaginated; as, an evaginate membrane.
Pertaining to a small Wormian bone sometimes present in thehuman skull between the parietal and the great wing of the sphenoid.-- n.
In an emarginate manner.
See Imprison.

A prefix signifying in or into, used in many English words,chiefly those borrowed from the French. Some English words arewritten indifferently with en- or in-. For ease of pronunciation itis commonly changed to em- before p, b, and m, as in employ, embody,emmew. It is sometimes used to give a causal force, as in enable,enfeeble, to cause to be, or to make, able, or feeble; and sometimesmerely gives an intensive force, as in enchasten. See In-.
The office of ædile. T. Arnold.

To lay out, apply, or employ in any way; to consume by use; touse up or distribute, either in payment or in donations; to spend;as, they expend money for food or in charity; to expend time labor,and thought; to expend hay in feeding cattle, oil in a lamp, water inmechanical operations.If my death might make this island happy . . . I would expend it withall willingness. Shak.
Heat. [Obs.]
In expedite manner; expeditiously.
To canker. [Obs.]
A rock occurring in the Alps, consisting of saussurite andsmaragdite; -- sometimes called gabbro.
One who favors or advocates extension.
The common newt or eft. In America often applied to severalspecies of aquatic salamanders. [Written also evat.]
To make brilliant with beams. [R.] G. Fletcher.
The science which treats of the glands of the alimentary canal.
That which engages or occupies a person; fixed or regularservice or business; employment.The whole employ of body and of mind. Pope.In one's employ, in one's service.
That may be evaded. [R.]
The act of eschewing. [R.]
Liable to be taken by a writ of extent.
Each one. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or derived from, a genus of cruciferousMediterranean herbs (Eruca or Brassica); as, erucic acid, a fattyacid resembling oleic acid, and found in colza oil, mustard oil, etc.
Foreign; belonging to, or coming from, abroad.
Toward, or in the direction of, the east.
Half an em, that is, half of the unit of space in measuringprinted matter. See Em.
The oval or roundish body laid by domestic poultry and otherbirds, tortoises, etc. It consists of a yolk, usually surrounded bythe "white" or albumen, and inclosed in a shell or strong membrane.
A segment next above the ceratohyal in the hyoidean arch.
An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine,or to impart nourishment. Hoblyn.
The albumen of a seed; -- limited by recent writers to thatformed within the embryo sac.
See Immanuel. Matt. i. 23.
One who. or that which, expels.
The act of enlacing, or state of being enlaced; a surroundingas with a lace.
Pertaining, or belonging, to the episperm, or covering of aseed.

The act of extirpating or rooting out, or the state of beingextirpated; eradication; excision; total destruction; as, theextirpation of weeds from land, of evil from the heart, of a race ofmen, of heresy.
Growing or covering over; -- said of a kind of invagination.See under Invagination.
The pronunciation of the Greek ê (eta) like the Italian e long,that is like a in the English word ate. See Itacism.
A metallic element of the rare-earth group, discoveredspectroscopically by Demarcay in 1896. Symbol, Eu; at. wt., 152.0.

A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action ofbromine on fluoresceïn, and named from the fine rose-red which itimparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Itssolution is fluorescent.
A dry slough, crust, or scab, which separates from the healthypart of the body, as that produced by a burn, or the application ofcaustics.

Of, Pertaining to, or produced by, magnetism which is developedby the passage of an electric current. Electro-magnetic engine, anengine in which the motive force is electro-magnetism.-- Electro-magnetic theory of light (Physics), a theory of lightwhich makes it consist in the rapid alternation of transient electriccurrents moving transversely to the direction of the ray.
See Turbinal.-- n.

A beginning; an introduction; especially, the introductory partof a discourse or written composition, which prepares the audiencefor the main subject; the opening part of an oration. "The exordiumof repentance." Jer. Taylor. "Long prefaces and exordiums. " Addison.
The material from which an embryo is formed and nourished.
Pertaining to, or composed of, entoplasm; as, the entoplasticproducts of some Protozoa, or the entoplastic modification of thecell protoplasm, by which a nucleus is produced.
A name sometimes given to that dialect of the Celtic which isspoken in the Highlands of Scotland; -- called, by the Highlanders,Gaelic.
To overthrow or subvert. [Obs.] Glanvill.
Having a position intermediate between erect and patent, orspreading.
A figure by which a speaker recalls a word or words, in orderto substitute something else stronger or more significant; as, Mostbrave! Brave, did I say most heroic act!
A prefix used frequently in composition, signifying well, good,advantageous; -- the opposite of dys-.
One who has the power of choosing; an elector. [R.]

An interception or obscuration of the light of the sun, moon,or other luminous body, by the intervention of some other body,either between it and the eye, or between the luminous body and thatilluminated by it. A lunar eclipse is caused by the moon passingthrough the earth's shadow; a solar eclipse, by the moon comingbetween the sun and the observer. A satellite is eclipsed by enteringthe shadow of its primary. The obscuration of a planet or star by themoon or a planet, though of the nature of an eclipse, is called anoccultation. The eclipse of a small portion of the sun by Mercury orVenus is called a transit of the planet.
Capable of being discharged by spitting. [Obs.] Swift.
A species of pea (Amphicarpæa monoica). It is a climbingleguminous plant, with hairy underground pods.
An oblong vermiform mass on the dorsal side of the testicle,composed of numerous convolutions of the excretory duct of thatorgan.-- Ep`i*did"y*mal, a.
A witness by means of his ears; one who is within hearing anddoes hear; a hearer. Fuller.
A plant (Zostera marina), with very long and narrow leaves,growing abundantly in shallow bays along the North Atlantic coast.
Expectative. [R.] Shipley.
Not in accordance with the doctrines of Scripture;unscriptural.
Suited for, or capable of, extension; extensible. Owen.
Making dear or beloved; causing love.-- En*dear"ing*ly, adv.
One of the principal names by which God is designated in theHebrew Scriptures.
Attentive; zealous. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who excommunicates.
The inner coating of a seed. See Tegmen.

A composition treating of any particular subject; -- usuallyshorter and less methodical than a formal, finished treatise; as, anessay on the life and writings of Homer; an essay on fossils, or oncommerce.
Eyes. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The process by which animal and vegetable organisms preserve aphysiological balance. H. Spenser.
See Inlay.
To trammel; to entangle. Bp. Hacket.

A nitrogenous substance, somewhat resembling albumin, whichforms the chemical basis of elastic tissue. It is very insoluble inmost fluids, but is gradually dissolved when digested with eitherpepsin or trypsin.

The act or process of breathing out, or forcing air from thelungs through the nose or mouth; as, respiration consists ofinspiration and expiration; -- opposed to Ant: inspiration.(b) Emission of volatile matter; exhalation.The true cause of cold is an expiration from the globe of the earth.Bacon.
Capable of exceeding or surpassing. [Obs.] Sherwood.
Matters to be excreted.
To pluck up by the stem or root; to root out; to eradicate,literally or figuratively; to destroy wholly; as, to extirpate weeds;to extirpate a tumor; to extirpate a sect; to extirpate error orheresy.

To run away, or escape privately, from the place or station towhich one is bound by duty; -- said especially of a woman or a man,either married or unmarried, who runs away with a paramour or asweetheart.Great numbers of them [the women] have eloped from their allegiance.Addison.
Used or fit for every day; common; usual; as, an everyday suitor clothes.The mechanical drudgery of his everyday employment. Sir. J. Herchel.
Entreaty. [Obs.] Ford.
Epiphonema. [R.]
Not subject to physical laws or methods.
A wild cat (Felis eyra) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas.It is reddish yellow and about the size of the domestic cat, but witha more slender body and shorter legs.
An instrument for measuring the strength of electro-dynamiccurrents.

To deprive of nerve, force, strength, or courage; to renderfeeble or impotent; to make effeminate; to impair the moral powersof.A man . . . enervated by licentiousness. Macaulay.And rhyme began t' enervate poetry. Dryden.
To weigh equally; to esteem alike. [Obs.]
See Epoch. J. Adams.
Of or pertaining to epilogue; of the nature of an epilogue. T.Warton.
Lifeless matter deposited in the form of minute granules withinthe protoplasm of living cells.
One of the ephemeral flies.
A writer of epistles.
The doctrine of the last or final things, as death, judgment,and the events therewith connected.
exercise; practice; use. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A digging out or up. [R.] "The effossion of coins." Arbuthnot.
Instruction in the elements or first principles. [R.]
An Arabian tree (Trichilia emetica). The fruit, which isemetic, is sometimes employed in the composition of an ointment forthe cure of the itch.

One hostile to another; one who hates, and desires or attemptsthe injury of, another; a foe; an adversary; as, an enemy of or to aperson; an enemy to truth, or to falsehood.To all good he enemy was still. Spenser.I say unto you, Love your enemies. Matt. v. 44.The enemy (Mil.), the hostile force. In this sense it is construedwith the verb and pronoun either in the singular or the plural, butmore commonly in the singular; as, we have met the enemy and he isours or they are ours.It was difficult in such a country to track the enemy. It wasimpossible to drive him to bay. Macaulay.
A kind of chronogram. [R.] B. Jonson.
An instrument for measuring and recording the work done by asingle muscle or set of muscles, the rate of fatigue, etc. --Er`go*graph"ic (#), a.
A glance of eye.
To boil out; to produce by boiling. [Obs.] Bacon.
Coming into ear, as corn.
Expressing character. [Obs.] Urquhart.
To envelop in clouds; to cloud. [R.] Spenser.
To make hard as marble; to harden. [Obs.] Spenser.
A stable.

To subject to the action of various solvents in order to removeall soluble substances or extractives; as, to exhaust a drugsuccessively with water, alcohol, and ether. Exhausted receiver.(Physics) See under Receiver.
Capable of being educated. "Men are educable." M. Arnold.
A genus of extinct Merostomata, found in Silurian rocks. Someof the species are more than three feet long.
Excrescence. [Obs.]
An officer who inspects and rates articles liable to exciseduty. Macaulay.
An instrument for the volumetric measurement of gases; -- sonamed because frequently used to determine the purity of the air.
Formerly, a railroad train run expressly for the occasion; aspecial train; now, a train run at express or special speed andmaking few stops.

One of a peculiar race inhabiting Arctic America and Greenland.In many respects the Eskimos resemble the Mongolian race. [Writtenalso Esquimau.] Eskimo dog (Zoöl.), one of breed of large andpowerful dogs used by the Eskimos to draw sledges. It closelyresembles the gray wolf, with which it is often crossed.
Expanse. [Obs.] "Night's rich expansure."
The language of ancient Ethiopia; the language of the ancientAbyssinian empire (in Ethiopia), now used only in the Abyssinianchurch. It is of Semitic origin, and is also called Geez.
Pertaining to, resembling, or characteristic of, the stag, orCervus elaphus.
The character, manner, or principles of an exclusionist.
To make to foam at the mouth, like a hunted animal. [Obs.]
See Epimeron.
A large division of gastropod molluske, including thePulmonifera and Opisthobranchiata.
Government of the church by bishops; church government by threedistinct orders of ministers -- bishops, priests, and deacons -- ofwhom the bishops have an authority superior and of a different kind.
With elation.
In an elective manner; by choice.
Arising from the centrum of a vertebra. Owen.
Act or process of egesting; a voiding. Sir M. Hale.
See Entirety. [Obs.]
The side of the ditch next the parapet; -- same as scarp, andopposed to counterscarp.
To get by the offense of extortion. See Extortion, 2.
An extract made from ergot.
A dextrin which gives a red color with iodine. See Dextrin.

A group of wormlike invertebrates having, along the sides ofthe body, branchial openings for the branchial sacs, which are formedby diverticula of the alimentary canal. Balanoglossus is the onlyknown genus. See Illustration in Appendix.
See Ingraftment. [Obs.]
Consisting of enamel; resembling enamel; smooth; glossy. [R.]Craig.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, meshes. Shak.My doubts enmesh me if I try. Lowell.
To run out; to flow forth; to pass away. [Obs.] Boyle.
The lengthening of a syllable from short to long.
Adherence to evangelical doctrines; evangelism. G. Eliot.
A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It isvalued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing inthe settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
One who espies. Harmar.
The state of being extravagant or in excess; excess;extravagance.
Arable; tillable. [Archaic]
A hermit.Thou art my heaven, and I thy eremite. Keats.
Agrimony (Agrimonia Eupatoria). [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to an elench.
Beyond the limits of a territory or particular jurisdiction;exterritorial.-- Ex`tra*ter`ri*to"ri*al*ly(#), adv.

One of the subclasses of Crustacea, including a large number ofspecies, many of them minute. The group embraces several orders; asthe Phyllopoda, Ostracoda, Copepoda, and Pectostraca. See Copepoda,Phyllopoda, and Cladocera.
Any compound of ethyl of a binary type; as, potassium ethide.
A copy or transcript attested to be correct by the seal of anofficer having custody of the original.
One who praises; a panegyrist. Locke.
The practice or employment of spies; the practice of watchingthe words and conduct of others, to make discoveries, as spies orsecret emissaries; secret watching.
The killing of a bishop.
A swallowing up as if in a gulf. [R.]
One who essays. Addison.
A citation from some author, or a sentence framed for thepurpose, placed at the beginning of a work or of its separatedivisions; a motto.
Pertaining to an eccentric; as, the eccentric rod in a steamengine.
A treatise upon, or history of, epidemic diseases.
Capable of being educed.
A servant who attends faithfully to his duty only when watched.
Not be exhausted; inexhaustible; as, an exhaustless fund orstore.
Same as Ellipsograph.
One of a sect in the 2d century who abstained from marriage,wine, and animal food; -- called also Continent.
The operation of sewing up a rent in the intestinal canal.
Anointed. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Eager, and Eagre. [Obs.]
In French usage, a dish served at the beginning of dinner togive zest to the appetite; in English usage, a side dish, served witha joint, or between the courses, as a cutlet, scalloped oysters, etc.
To veer to the east; -- said of the wind. Russell.
An amorous composition or poem.
A powerful astringent alkaloid extracted from ergot as a brown,amorphous, bitter substance. It is used to produce contraction of theuterus.
Having no corners; without angles. [R.]
To stamp; to mark asIt is the motive . . . which enstamps the character. Gogan.
A summing up in a brief account. [Obs.] Udall.
The inner or principal branch of the oral appendages ofCrustacea. See Maxilla.
Upon or above the notochord; -- applied esp. to a vertebralcolumn which develops upon the dorsal side of the notochord, asdistinguished from a perichordal column, which develops around it.
That excerpts, selects, or chooses. D. L. Mackenzie.
One who, or that which, gives energy, or acts in producing aneffect.

Pertaining to, resembling, or having the motion of, anepicycle. Epicyclic train (Mach.), a train of mechanism in whichepicyclic motion is involved; esp., a train of spur wheels, bevelwheels, or belt pulleys, in which an arm, carrying one or more of thewheels, sweeps around a center lying in an axis common to the otherwheels.
Efficacy. [R.] J. Fryth.
A division of Annelida which includes the genus Echiurus andallies. They are often classed among the Gephyrea, and called thearmed Gephyreans.
Inserted exterior to the eyes; -- said of the antennæ ofcertain insects.
To harden; to embolden. [Obs.] Howell.
The portion of each apodeme developed from the interepimeralmembrane in certain crustaceans.
A centerpiece for table decoration, usually consisting ofseveral dishes or receptacles of different sizes grouped together inan ornamental design.
An instrument for observing the boiling point of liquids,especially for determining the alcoholic strength of a mixture by thetemperature at which it boils.
One who writes in an affectedly pointed style.Epigrammatizers of our English prose style. Coleridge.
Arising or growing from without; exogenous.
Producing mathematically perfect harmony or concord; sweetly orperfectly harmonious.
One who expurgates or purifies.
Beyond or outside of the tropics. Whewell.
Entoblast; endoplast. See Nucleus,
The conscious and permanent subject of all psychicalexperiences, whether held to be directly known or the product ofreflective thought; -- opposed to non-ego.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor ofspirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium. T. Gray.
Prone to make excursions; wandering; roving; exploring; as, anexcursive fancy.The course of excursive . . . understandings. I. Taylor.-- Ex*cur"sive*ly, adv.-- Ex*cur"sive*ness, , n.

Originally, a shield-bearer or armor-bearer, an attendant on aknight; in modern times, a title of dignity next in degree belowknight and above gentleman; also, a title of office and courtesy; --often shortened to squire.
Increasing by internal growth and elongation at the summit,instead of externally, and having no distinction of pith, wood, andbark, as the rattan, the palm, the cornstalk.
A genus of shrubs or small trees of the Flax family, growing intropical countries. E. Coca is the source of cocaine. See Coca.
That part of the alimentary canal between the pharynx and thestomach; the gullet. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, underDigestive. [Written also .]

A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, ornearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.Easel picture, Easel piece, a painting of moderate size such as ismade while resting on an easel, as distinguished from a painting on awall or ceiling.
To join or close fast together, as with glue; as, a coffer wellenglued. Gower.
Brainless. [R.]
See Elæolite.

A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; theproclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by thevery act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Romanemperors; the edicts of the French monarch.It stands as an edict in destiny. Shak.Edict of Nantes (French Hist.), an edict issued by Henry IV. (A. D.1598), giving toleration to Protestants. Its revocation by Louis XIV.(A. D. 1685) was followed by terrible persecutions and theexpatriation of thousands of French Protestants.
Having the quality of closing the pores of the skin.
Serving or tending to extort. [R.] Johnson.-- Ex*tor"sive*ly, adv. [R.]
Mysterious or hidden doctrines; secret science.
The parts or places which surround another place, or lie in itsneighborhood; suburbs; as, the environs of a city or town.Chesterfield.
The involute of a curve. See Involute, and Evolute.
An expeller. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
An etching or a print from an etched plate.
To enlarge in the way of bulk. [R.] Latham.
An epizoön.
Having being or existence; existing; being; occurring now;taking place.The eyes and mind are fastened on objects which have no real being,as if they were truly existent. Dryden.
Bearing a sword.
An easy death; a mode of dying to be desired. "An euthanasia ofall thought." Hazlitt.The kindest wish of my friends is euthanasia. Arbuthnot.

An expression of the condition of equality between twoalgebraic quantities or sets of quantities, the sign = being placedbetween them; as, a binomial equation; a quadratic equation; analgebraic equation; a transcendental equation; an exponentialequation; a logarithmic equation; a differential equation, etc.
Good tidings; evangel. [R.]Above all, the Servians . . . read, with much avidity, the evangileof their freedom. Londor.
To utilize; to make available; to get the value or usefulnessout of; as, to exploit a mine or agricultural lands; to exploitpublic opinion. [Recent]
Having the form, or structure, of an elytron.
Full of, or rich in, events or incidents; as, an eventfuljourney; an eventful period of history; an eventful period of life.
See Eloignment.
Pertaining to the last or final things.

To increase; to add to; to augment; -- now commonly used without, the notion conveyed being to add to, or piece out by alaborious, inferior, or scanty addition; as, to eke out a scantysupply of one kind with some other. "To eke my pain." Spenser.He eked out by his wits an income of barely fifty pounds. Macaulay.
One of the canonical books of the Old Testament.
A process of bone formation in which ossification takes placewithin the substance of the cartilage.
Pertaining to, or derived from, ergot; as, ergotic acid.

The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; thestate of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained byextensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature orcriticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship.The management of a young lady's person is not be overlooked, but theerudition of her mind is much more to be regarded. Steele.The gay young gentleman whose erudition sat so easily upon him.Macaulay.
Same as Echinoid.
At any or all times; every instant. [R.] "Eternal law issilently present everywhere and everywhen." Carlyle.
The act or state of vanishing away; disappearance; as, theevanescence of vapor, of a dream, of earthly plants or hopes.Rambler.
To pierce; to impierce. [Obs.] Spenser.
Characterized by extortion; oppressive; hard.
A divulging. [Obs.]
To happen. [Obs.] Hewyt.
Same as Emir.
A wandering; state of being in error.
The act of removing or beating out the brains.
The delicate bands of connective tissue interspersed amongmuscular fibers.
The old plural of Eye.And eke with fatness swollen were his een. Spenser.
Resembling erysipelas, or partaking of its nature.
A substance obtained from euchroic acid. See Eychroic.
The act of eating out or through. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
See Ecstatic, a.
The science or study of Egyptian antiquities, esp. thehieroglyphics.

One who, or that which, raises or lifts up anything; as:(a) A mechanical contrivance, usually an endless belt or chain with aseries of scoops or buckets, for transferring grain to an upper loftfor storage.(b) A cage or platform and the hoisting machinery in a hotel,warehouse, mine, etc., for conveying persons, goods, etc., to or fromdifferent floors or levels; -- called in England a lift; the cage orplatform itself.(c) A building for elevating, storing, and discharging, grain.(d) (Anat.) A muscle which serves to raise a part of the body, as theleg or the eye.(e) (Surg.) An instrument for raising a depressed portion of a bone.Elevator head, leg, and boot, the boxes in which the upper pulley,belt, and lower pulley, respectively, run in a grain elevator.
A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.
Without, or apparently without, a scutellum; -- said of certaininsects.
Of or pertaining to Elasmobranchii.-- n.
A contriver; an inventor; a contriver of engines. [Obs.] Shak.
A colorless, crystalline, nitrogenous base, obtained by thedecomposition of cocaine.
To form; to fashion. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Impugn.
Pertaining to the segments above the epibranchial in thebranchial arches of fishes.-- n.
The act of thrusting or pushing out; a driving out; expulsion.
The act of taking by assault; conquest. [R.] Sandys.
To write epistles.
An orange-red crystalline substance, C15H10O5, obtained fromthe buckthorn, rhubarb, etc., and regarded as a derivative ofanthraquinone; -- so called from a species of rhubarb (Rheum emodei).
A drinking up; a quaffing. [Obs.] Feltham.
Eleven. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Belonging to an epoch; of the nature of an epoch. "Epochalpoints." Shedd.

The act of exerting, or putting into motion or action; theactive exercise of any power or faculty; an effort, esp. a laboriousor perceptible effort; as, an exertion of strength or power; anexertion of the limbs or of the mind; it is an exertion for him tomove, to-day.
The application of a plaster or salve.
To quicken; to make alive. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Relating or belonging to the echinoderms.

Derived from, or pertaining to, experience. Coleridge.It is called empirical or experiential . . . because it is divan tous by experience or observation, and not obtained as the result ofinference or reasoning. Sir. W. Hamiltion.-- Ex*pe`ri*en"tial*ly, adv. DR. H. More.
Affected with emotion. [R.] "The emotioned soul." Sir W. Scott.
The period of violence in a fever or disease; paroxysm.Dunglison.
To speak extempore; especially, to discourse without specialpreparation; to make an offhand address.
Embassy. [Obs.] Leland.
Tending to elaborate.
In an extreme manner or state; in the utmost degree; to theutmost point; exceedingly; as, extremely hot or cold.
Tending or serving to expurgate; expurgatory. Milman.
A café, or room in a café, in which smoking is allowed.

That which is legally submitted to competent tribunal, as ameans of ascertaining the truth of any alleged matter of fact underinvestigation before it; means of making proof; -- the latter,strictly speaking, not being synonymous with evidence, but rather theeffect of it. Greenleaf. Circumstantial evidence, Conclusiveevidence, etc. See under Circumstantial, Conclusive, etc.-- Crown's, King's, or Queen's evidence, evidence for the crown.[Eng.] -- State's evidence, evidence for the government or thepeople. [U. S. ] -- To turn King's, Queen's or State's evidence, toconfess a crime and give evidence against one's accomplices.
To muffle up.
One who unfolds or explains; an expounder; an explainer.
In the manner of an expletive.
See Instate.
The quality of being explanatory.
One who holds the existence of matter to be from eternity. T.Burnet.
A follower of Eusebius, bishop of Cæsarea, who was a friend andprotector of Arius.
To decorate with a diaper pattern.

A viceroy; in Ravenna, the title of the viceroys of theByzantine emperors; in the Eastern Church, the superior over severalmonasteries; in the modern Greek Church, a deputy of the patriarch ,who visits the clergy, investigates ecclesiastical cases, etc.

Producing electro-motion; producing, or tending to produce,electricity or an electric current; causing electrical action oreffects. Electro-motive force (Physics), the force which produces, ortends to produce, electricity, or an electric current; sometimes usedto express the degree of electrification as equivalent to potential,or more properly difference of potential.
Serving to show forth, explain, or exhibit; -- applied by theGreeks to a kind of oratory, which, by full amplification, seeks topersuade.
Growing on the sepals or adnate to them.

A separate incident, story, or action, introduced for thepurpose of giving a greater variety to the events related; anincidental narrative, or digression, separable from the main subject,but naturally arising from it.
A plain suit in which a player (or side) could, except fortrumping, take tricks with all his remaining cards.
To compare. [R.]
The outer membrane of the grains of pollen of flowering plants.
A nonconductor of electricity, as amber, glass, resin, etc.,employed to excite or accumulate electricity.
Belonging to, or formed in, an estuary; as, estuary strata.Lyell.
The exposing of a sensitized plate to the action of light.

The tissue which partially fills the interior of theinterseptal chambers of most madreporarian corals. It usuallyconsists of a series of oblique tranverse septa, one above another.-- En`do*the"cal, a.
Fixed; settled; fastened. [Obs.] Spenser.
An emerald. [Obs.] Spenser.
A fossil crinoid, esp. one belonging to, or resembling, thegenus Encrinus. Sometimes used in a general sense for any crinoid.
An attempt to influence a court, jury, etc., corruptly, bypromises, entreaties, money, entertainments, threats, or otherimproper inducements.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, emphysema; swelled;bloated.
A small, sharp-pointed instrument used in piercing eyeletholes; a stiletto.
An extinct, long-necked, marine, cretaceous reptile fromKansas, allied to Plesiosaurus.
Empty; frivolous. [A Shakespearean word only once used.]Such exsufflicate and blown surmises. Shak. (Oth. iii. 3, 182).
One who takes exceptions. T. Burnet.
Very sore; ulcerated. [Obs.] Bacon.
See Exauthorate. [Obs.]
Embryonic.
That which is educed, as by analysis. Sir W. Hamilton.
Inclosed in a cyst, or a sac, bladder, or vesicle; as, anencysted tumor.The encysted venom, or poison bag, beneath the adder's fang.Coleridge.
A muscle which serves to extend or straighten any part of thebody, as an arm or a finger; -- opposed to flexor.
To expedite; to hasten. [Obs.]
Made of earth; made of burnt or baked clay, or other likesubstances; as, an earthen vessel or pipe.
Bent into a curve; -- said of a bend or other ordinary.
A monatomic, hydrocarbon radical, C2H5 of the paraffin series,forming the essential radical of ethane, and of common alcohol andether. Ethyl aldehyde. (Chem.) See Aldehyde.
See Erratum.
The process of finding the roots of an equation. [Obs.]
The act of enchaining, or state of being enchained.
Pertaining to elocution.
To lengthen. [Obs.]
A fossil insect.
To give heart to; to fill with courage; to embolden.The enemy exults and is enheartened. I. Taylor.
Mixed with, or emitting, lightning. [Obs.] "With foulenfouldred smoke." Spenser.
A seditious tumult; an outbreak.
The lees of beer, cider, etc.; yeast. [U.S.]
Any external topical application to the body, except ointmentsand plasters, as a poultice, lotion, etc.
A song of triumph. [Obs.] T. Warton.
Pertaining to, or connected with, the endoskeleton; as,endoskeletal muscles.
To slip or glide away; to pass away silently, as time; -- usedchiefly in reference to time.Eight days elapsed; at length a pilgrim came. Hoole.

Designed or fitted for execution, or carrying into effect; as,executive talent; qualifying for, concerned with, or pertaining to,the execution of the laws or the conduct of affairs; as, executivepower or authority; executive duties, officer, department, etc.
Of or pertaining to, or characterized by, exophthalmia.Exophthalmic golter. Same as Rasedow's disease.

To bring or draw out; to cause to appear; to produce againstcounter agency or influence; to extract; to evolve; as, to educe aform from matter.The eternal art educing good from ill. Pope.They want to educe and cultivate what is best and noblest inthemselves. M. Arnold.
Fit to be eaten as food; eatable; esculent; as, edible fishes.Bacon.-- n.
One who exhorts or incites.

The process of setting accounts or debts between partiesresiding at a distance from each other, without the intervention ofmoney, by exchanging orders or drafts, called bills of exchange.These may be drawn in one country and payable in another, in whichcase they are called foreign bills; or they may be drawn and madepayable in the same country, in which case they are called inlandbills. The term bill of exchange is often abbreviated into exchange;as, to buy or sell exchange.
A branching frame, often of ornamental design, to supportelectric illuminating lamps.
To shed an old covering or condition preliminary to taking on anew one; to molt.There is reason to suppose that very old crayfish do not exuviateevery year. Huxley.
Enactment; resolution. [Obs.] Shak.
To arch. [Obs.] Lydgate.
An example; a pattern or model for imitation. [Obs.] Tyndale.Being ensamples to the flock.
An effecter. Derham.
To execute or put to death by electricity.-- E*lec`tro*cu"tion, n.
A composition of dust of ivory or of bone with a cement; --used for imitations of valuable stones and in making moldings, seals,etc. Knight.
To ambush. [Obs.]
Deprived of virility or vigor; unmanned; weak. "Emasculateslave." Hammond.
To lay out, as money; to deal out; to expend. [Obs.]
Epidermoid. Owen.
Of or pertaining to exuviæ. "Exuvial layers." "Exuvialdeposits."
A journey in circuit of certain judges called justices in eyre(or in itinere).
Same as Embarkation.
Perished; decayed. [Obs.]I deem thy brain emperished be. Spenser.
Related to, resembling, or containing epidote; as, an epidoticgranite.
A prefix, meaning upon, beside, among, on the outside, above,over. It becomes ep- before a vowel, as in epoch, and eph- before aGreek aspirate, as in ephemeral.
To set free. [Obs.] "The enfreed Antenor." Shak.
Drawn outside of; -- used to designate a circle that touchesone of the sides of a given triangle, and also the other two sidesproduced.
See Squad,
Like an embryo in form.
The conversion of certain substances into others which have theappearance or characteristics of ivory.
To rouse; to excite. [Obs.] Johnson.
A light textile fabric, like a fine bunting.
Lacking nerve or force; enervated. [R.]
Of or pertaining to the endophragma.
Exciting secretion; -- said of the influence exerted by reflexaction on the function of secretion, by which the various glands areexcited to action.
A volatile, terpenelike oil extracted from the eucalyptus, andconsisting largely of cymene.
A charming; state of being bewitched or deluded. [Obs.]
An action; a fight; a battle.In hot engagement with the Moors. Dryden.
An epitapher.
To restore. [Obs.] Wyclif.
That philosophy or doctrine which recognizes or deals only withexternals, or objects of sense perception; positivism; phenomenalism.
The act of depriving or divesting of shoes. [Obs.] Chambers.
A disburser; especially, one of the disbursers of taxes for therepair of sewers. Mozley & W.
Indentation in curved lines, as of a line of division or theedge of an ordinary.
In the way of executing or performing.
A great circle of the celestial sphere, making an angle withthe equinoctial of about 23º 28'. It is the apparent path of the sun,or the real path of the earth as seen from the sun.
To perform, as a piece of music, either on an instrument orwith the voice; as, to execute a difficult part brilliantly.
The process of separating a fusible substance from one lessfusible, by means of a degree of heat sufficient to melt the one andnot the other, as an alloy of copper and lead; liquation. Ure.
In an equitable manner; justly; as, the laws should beequitably administered.

Possessed of, or characterized by, expedition, or efficiencyand rapidity in action; performed with, or acting with, expedition;quick; having celerity; speedily; as, an expeditious march ormessenger.-- Ex`pe*di"tious*ly, adv.-- Ex`pe*di"tious*ness, n.
Most eastern.
The annihilation or extinction of a right or obligation.Abbott.
See Enarthrosis.-- En`ar*thro"di*al, a.
Without bracteoles, or little bracts; -- said of a pedicel orflower stalk.
A little elf.
A group of Bryozoa in which the anus is within the circle oftentacles. See Pedicellina.
The condition of being composed of elements, or a thing socomposed.
To bathe; to soothe or lull as by bathing. [Obs.] Spenser.
A dike of piles in the sea, a river, etc., to check theapproach of an enemy.
One who practices entomotomy.
Liability to error. Dr. H. More.
Fem. of Englishman. Shak.
A brood; as, an eye of pheasants.
A variety of amphibole. See Amphibole.
The act of stripping off bark, or the state of being thusstripped; decortication.
The foramen or passage through the inner integument of anovule.

Pertaining to exponents; involving variable exponents; as, anexponential expression; exponential calculus; an exponentialfunction. Exponential curve, a curve whose nature is defined by meansof an exponential equation.-- Exponential equation, an equation which contains an exponentialquantity, or in which the unknown quantity enters as an exponent.-- Exponential quantity (Math.), a quantity whose exponent isunknown or variable, as ax.-- Exponential series, a series derived from the development ofexponential equations or quantities.

Pertaining to an election or to electors.In favor of the electoral and other princes. Burke.Electoral college, the body of princes formerly entitled to elect theEmperor of Germany; also, a name sometimes given, in the UnitedStates, to the body of electors chosen by the people to elect thePresident and Vice President.

Thinking chiefly or most readily through, or in terms relatedto, the sense of hearing; specif., thinking words as spoken, as aresult of familiarity with speech or of mental peculiarity; --opposed to eye-minded.
Outside of the uterus, or womb. Extra-uterine pregnancy (Med.),a condition of pregnancy in which the fetus is not in the uterus, butin the Fallopian tube or in the abdominal cavity.
Full of daring; adventurous. [Archaic] T. Campbell.
To rip open; todisembowel. [Obs.] Sir. T. Brown.
A chitinous structure above the nervous cord in the thorax ofcertain Crustacea.
A colorless, aromatic, liquid hydrocarbon, C10H12O2 resemblingthe phenols, and hence also called eugenic acid. It is found in theoils of pimento and cloves.
Same as Eclampsia.
A cincture. [Poetic]The vast encincture of that gloomy sea. Wordsworth.
A wink; a token. Shak.
Of the Hedgehog family; like, or characteristic of, a hedgehog.
A bay. [R.]The embayment which is terminated by the land of North Berwick. SirW. Scott.
See Hermitage.
Sharp-sighted as an eagle. "Inwardly eagle-eyed." Howell.
In an explosive manner.
A genus of water lilies, growing in India and China. The onlyspecies (E. ferox) is very prickly on the peduncles and calyx. Therootstocks and seeds are used as food.
To improve. [R.] Swift.
The faculty possessed by all substances capable of self-nourishment of manifesting the nutritive acts by changes of form, ofvolume, or of structure. Syd. Soc. Lex.
Epileptic.
Issuing forth; effluent.
To pare off, as nails, the hoof, etc. [R.]
One who, or that which, excavates or hollows out; a machine, asa dredging machine, or a tool, for excavating.
To make fierce. [Obs.] Spenser.
A body which passes to the positive pole in electrolysis.
Creation; a doing. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
The quality of being done or devised extempore [Obs.] Johnson.
Hebrew. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to the interior of the stomach; -- applied to a modeof budding from the interior of the gastric cavity, in certainhydroids.
A mineral of a brownish red color and vitreous luster,consisting chiefly of the silicates of iron, zirconia, and lime.

One moved or actuated by enthusiasm; as: (a) One who imagineshimself divinely inspired, or possessed of some special revelation; areligious madman; a fanatic. . A prefix from the latin preposition, ex, akin to Gr. 'ex or'ek signifying out of, out, proceeding from. Hence, in composition,it signifies out of, as, in exhale, exclude; off, from, or out. as inexscind; beyond, as, in excess, exceed, excel; and sometimes has aprivative sense of without, as in exalbuminuos, exsanguinous. In somewords, it intensifies the meaning; in others, it has little affect onthe signification. It becomes ef- before f, as in effuse. The form e-occurs instead of ex- before b, d, g, l, m, n, r, and v, as inebullient, emanate, enormous, etc. In words from the French it oftenappears as es-, sometimes as s- or é-; as, escape, scape, élite. Ex-,prefixed to names implying office, station, condition, denotes thatthe person formerly held the office, or is out of the office orcondition now; as, ex-president, ex-governor, ex-mayor, ex-convict.The Greek form 'ex becomes ex in English, as in exarch; 'ek becomesec, as in eccentric.

That portion of the Christian church which prevails in thecountries once comprised in the Eastern Roman Empire and thecountries converted to Christianity by missionaries from them. Itsfull official title is The Orthodox Catholic Apostolic EasternChurch. It became estranged from the Western, or Roman, Church overthe question of papal supremacy and the doctrine of the filioque, anda separation, begun in the latter part of the 9th century, becamefinal in 1054. The Eastern Church consists of twelve (thirteen if theBulgarian Church be included) mutually independent churches(including among these the Hellenic Church, or Church of Greece, andthe Russian Church), using the vernacular (or some ancient form ofit) in divine service and varying in many points of detail, butstanding in full communion with each other and united as equals in agreat federation. The highest five authorities are the patriarch ofConstantinople, or ecumenical patriarch (whose position is not one ofsupremacy, but of precedence), the patriarch of Alexandria, thepatriarch of Jerusalem, the patriarch of Antioch, and the Holy Synodof Russia. The Eastern Church accepts the first seven ecumenicalcouncils (and is hence styled only schismatic, not heretical, by theRoman Catholic Church), has as its creed the Niceno-Constantinopolitan (without the later addition of the filioque,which, with the doctrine it represents, the church decisivelyrejects), baptizes infants with trine immersion, makes confirmationfollow immediately upon baptism, administers the Communion in bothkinds (using leavened bread) and to infants as well as adults,permits its secular clergy to marry before ordination and to keeptheir wives afterward, but not to marry a second time, selects itsbishops from the monastic clergy only, recognizes the offices ofbishop, priest, and deacon as the three necessary degrees of orders,venerates relics and icons, and has an elaborate ritual.
