To remove; to banish; to withdraw; to avoid; to eloign. [Obs.]From worldly cares he did himself esloin. Spenser.

One of the letters in the New Testament which were addressed totheir Christian brethren by Apostles. Epistle side, the right side ofan altar or church to a person looking from the nave toward thechancel.One sees the pulpit on the epistle side. R. Browning.
That which makes the eyes open, as startling news oroccurrence, or (U. S. Slang), a drink of liquor, esp. the first onein the morning.
Compelled; forced; not voluntary. "Enforced wrong." "Enforcedsmiles." Shak.-- En*for"ced*ly, adv. Shak.
A list of jurors; a panel. [Obs.] Cowell.
One who balances himself in unnatural positions and hazardousmovements; a balancer.When the equilibrist balances a rod upon his finger. Stewart.
Red, or reddish; blushing. Johnson.
A genus of palms.
Extirpator. [Obs.] Bacon.
To envelop. See Inwrap.
To fix by the root; to fix fast; to implant deep. Shak.
Diffusing a flood of light; shining; luminous; beaming; bright;splendid. "Effulgent rays of light." Cowper.
Pertaining to ecchymosis.
A kind of uptight piano.

To surpass others in good qualities, laudable actions, oracquirements; to be distinguished by superiority; as, to excel inmathematics, or classics.Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel. Gen. xlix. 4.Then peers grew proud in horsemanship t' excel. Pope.
To make or become enthusiastic. [Slang]
Ale. [Obs.] Shak.
A figure oMust I give way and room to your rash choler Shall I be frighted whena madman stares Shak.
The act or practice of using to the best effect. [R.] H.Spenser.
Full of entreaty. [R.] See Intreatful.
The act of embroiling, or the condition of being embroiled;entanglement in a broil. Bp. Burnet.
To hasten; to expedite. [Obs.] "To expediate their business."Sir E. Sandys.
Serving for example or pattern; exemplary. [Obs.] Hooker.
The quality of being extraordinary. [R.] Gov. of the Tongue.
Eruptive. [R.] R. A. Proctor.
Being, or having its origin, within the external surface of thebody; -- especially applied to feelings, such as hunger, produced byinternal disturbances. Opposed to epiperipheral.
Relating to elves.
To lament in an elegy; to celebrate in elegiac verse; tobewail. Carlyle.
In an epidemic manner.
One versed in entomology.
A yew. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Master; sir; -- a title of a Turkish state official and man oflearning, especially one learned in the law.
Full of exciting qualities; as, an exciteful story; excitefulplayers. Chapman.
Exasperated; imbittered. [Obs.] Shak.Like swallows which the exasperate dying year Sets spinning. Mrs.Browning.
Relating to, or aiding in, the formation of an embryo; as,embryoplastic cells.
Producing epilepsy or epileptoid convulsions; -- applied toareas of the body or of the nervous system, stimulation of whichproduces convulsions.

A colorless, gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H4, forming an importantingredient of illuminating gas, and also obtained by the action ofconcentrated sulphuric acid in alcohol. It is an unsaturated compoundand combines directly with chlorine and bromine to form oily liquids(Dutch liquid), -- hence called olefiant gas. Called also ethene,elayl, and formerly, bicarbureted hydrogen. Ethylene series (Chem.),the series if unsaturated hydrocarbons of which ethylene is the type,and represented by the general formula CnH2n.

Extended or contracted as much as possible; -- said ofintervals; as, an extreme sharp second; an extreme flat forth.Extreme and mean ratio (Geom.), the relation of a line and itssegments when the line is so divided that the whole is to the greatersegment is to the less.-- Extreme distance. (Paint.) See Distance., n., 6.-- Extreme unction. See under Unction.
Same as Electrogeny.
The plant eyesight (euphrasia officionalis), formerly regardedas beneficial in disorders of the eyes.Then purged with euphrasy and rue The visual nerve, for he had muchto see. Milton.
The state or quality of being exemplary; fitness to be anexample.
Relating to emigration.

To go beyond; to proceed beyond the given or supposed limit ormeasure of; to outgo; to surpass; -- used both in a good and a badsense; as, one man exceeds another in bulk, stature, weight, power,skill, etc. ; one offender exceeds another in villainy; his rankexceeds yours.Name the time, but let it not Exceed three days. Shak.Observes how much a chintz exceeds mohair. Pope.
That exaggerates; enlarging beyond bounds.-- Ex*ag"ger*a`ting*ly, adv.
A builder. [Obs.] Bailey.
To stain or cover with blood; to make bloody, or of a blood-redcolor; as, an ensanguined hue. "The ensanguined field." Milton.
Heating; warming. [Obs.] Holland.
More than usual; extraordinary; more than sufficient;measureless. "The exceeding riches of his grace." Eph. ii. 7.-- Ex*ceed"ing*ness, n. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
The capability of flying off in fumes or vapor. [Obs.] Boyle.
The state or rank of an ensign.
Capable of being enticed.
An instrument for describing ellipses; -- called also trammel.
Emotiveness. Hickok.
Epidermal. [R.]
One who emends or critically edits.
Embracing the whole circle of learning, or a wide range ofsubjects.
An electress. Bp. Burnet.
See Ern, n. Sir W. Scott.
One who enjoins.
To put into a kennel.
The act of increasing, or state of being increased;augmentation; aggravation; as, the enhancement of value, price,enjoyments, crime.
A man who manages, or waits on, an engine.
Capable of being erased.
Capable of being explicated; that may be explained or accountedfor; admitting explanation.It is not explicable upon any grounds. Burke.

A division of time characterized by the prevalence of similarconditions of the earth; commonly a minor division or part of aperiod.The long geological epoch which stored up the vast coal measures. J.C. Shairp.

That expands, or may be expanded; extending; spreading;enlarging. Expanding bit, Expanding drill (Mech.), a bit or drillmade adjustable for holes of various sizes; one which can be expandedin diameter while boring.-- Expanding pulley (Mach.), a pulley so made, as in sections, thatits diameter can be increased or diminished.
The state of being elated.
Same as Incumbrancer.
One who gathers, or deals in, eggs.
Deserving to be execrated; accursed; damnable; detestable;abominable; as, an execrable wretch. "Execrable pride." Hooker.-- Ex"e*cra*ble*ness, n.-- Ex"e*cra*bly, adv.
The quality or state of being suitable for exportation.To increase the exportability of native goods. J. P. Peters.

To stand under the eaves, near a window or at the door, of ahouse, to listen and learn what is said within doors; hence, tolisten secretly to what is said in private.To eavesdrop in disguises. Milton.
Not within of pertaining to the same province or jurisdiction.Ayliffe.
Journeying; itinerant; -- formerly applied to judges who wenton circuit and to bailiffs at large. Mozley & W.
Of the nature of execration; imprecatory; denunciatory. C.Kingsley.-- n.
To excrete; to throw off through the pores; as, fluids areexcerned in perspiration. [R.] Bacon.
Formed of pure fire or light; refined beyond aërial substance;pertaining to the highest and purest region of heaven.Go, soar with Plato to the empyreal sphere. Pope.Empyreal air, oxygen gas.
The insertion of a letter or a sound in the body of a word; as,the b in "nimble" from AS. nemol.
A picture which represents the Savior as given up to the peopleby Pilate, and wearing a crown of thorns.
The representation of any quantity by its appropriatecharacters or signs. Past expression, Beyond expression, beyond thepower of description. "Beyond expression bright." Milton.
An ethereal or spiritlike state. J. H. Stirling.
Keratin.
See Eddish.

To surround; to encompass; to encircle; to hem in; to be roundabout; to involve or envelop.Dwelling in a pleasant glade, With mountains round about environed.Spenser.Environed he was with many foes. Shak.Environ me with darkness whilst I write. Donne.
See Ect-.
Escutcheon. [Obs.]
A liquid obtained from fat, or fat fish, by pressure.
The peculiar smell and taste arising from products ofdecomposition of animal or vegetable substances when burnt in closevessels.
Endemic. [R.]
State of being endeared.
Pertaining to, or employed in, the expiration or emission ofair from the lungs; as, the expiratory muscles.

To reason earnestly with a person on some impropriety of hisconduct, representing the wrong he has done or intends, and urginghim to make redress or to desist; to remonstrate; -- followed bywith.Men expostulate with erring friends; they bring accusations againstenemies who have done them a wrong. Jowett (Thuc. ).
To charm; to bewitch. [Obs.] Heywood.
The act of expunging or erasing; the condition of beingexpunged. Milton.
Tending to draw out; extractive.
A variety of squash with small egg-shaped fruit.
A woman skilled in equestrianism; a horsewoman.
See Eiliad.
The act of evincing or proving, or the state of being evinced.
Encumbrance. [R.]
To entangle. [Obs.] Spenser.
That may be exacted; repairable. [R.] A. Smith.
The theory of, or belief in, evolution. See Evolution, 6 and 7.
See Else. [Obs.]
Having no ribs or nerves; -- said of a leaf.
Characterized by extensive reading or knowledge; wellinstructed; learned. "A most erudite prince." Sir T. More. "Erudite .. . theology." I. Taylor.-- Er"u*dite`ly, adv.-- Er"u*dite`ness, n.
The quality or state of being exchangeable.The law ought not be contravened by an express article admitting theexchangeability of such persons. Washington.
Any insect of the genus Forticula and related genera, belongingto the order Euplexoptera.
A native or inhabitant of Exeter, in England.
One who exports; the person who sends goods or commodities to aforeign country, in the way of commerce; -- opposed to importer.
The act or operation of burning up. Bailey.
Equally radical. [R.] Coleridge.
A brood of eels. [Prov. Eng.]
Gently boiling or bubbling, by means of the disengagement ofgas
Tending or serving to eradicate; curing or destroyingthoroughly, as a disease or any evil.
He (or she ) goes out, or retires from view; as, exit Macbeth.
The interval of an octave.
Effluence.
A flying off in small particles, as heated iron or fermentingliquors; a sparkling; scintillation. Sir T. Browne.
To spit out; to discharge from the throat by hawking andspitting. [Obs.] Cockeram.

To make experiment; to operate by test or trial; -- often withon, upon, or in, referring to the subject of an experiment; with,referring to the instrument; and by, referring to the means; as, toexperiment upon electricity; he experimented in plowing with ponies,or by steam power.

A name given to various roots, tubers, or pods grown under oron the ground; as to:(a) The esculent tubers of the umbelliferous plants Bunium flexuosumand Carum Bulbocastanum.(b) The peanut. See Peanut.
Pertaining to, or containing, exposition; serving to explain;explanatory; illustrative; exegetical.A glossary or expository index to the poetical writers. Johnson.
To confine in a cage; to coop up. Shak.
Set with small spines or prickles.
An iron needle for piercing the cartridge of a cannon beforepriming.
To take out the bowels or entrails of; to disembowel; toeviscerate; as, exenterated fishes. [R.]Exenterated rule-mongers and eviscerated logicians. Hare.
One versed in electro-biology.
Belonging to the electro-chronograph, or recorded by the aid ofit.
To swathe; to envelop, as in swaddling clothes. Shak.
To cause to burst forth; to eject; as, to erupt lava. Huxley.
A wandering; a roving about. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Formerly, a measuring rod an ell long.
A ball and socket joint, or the kind of articulationrepresented by such a joint. See Articulation.

An East Indian long-tailed bearded monkey (Semnopithecusentellus) regarded as sacred by the natives. It is remarkable for thecaplike arrangement of the hair on the head. Called also hoonoomaunand hungoor.
To run out or forth; to extend. [Obs.] Harvey.
Disembowelment.
One who gathers eggs; an eggler.
One who makes, or talks in, enigmas. Addison.
The state of being equivocal.
To excavate. [Obs.] Cockeram.
A heap; accumulation. [R.]
Having a yellow color; pertaining to, derived from, orresembling, euxanthin. Euxanthic acid (Chem.), a yellow, crystalline,organic acid, extracted from euxanthin.
A warehouse; a magazine for depositing goods, stores, etc.; amart or place where merchandise is deposited; as, an entrepôt forshipping goods in transit.
One who eyes another. Gayton.

A compound machine by which any physical power is applied toproduce a given physical effect. Engine driver, one who manages anengine; specifically, the engineer of a locomotive.-- Engine lathe. (Mach.) See under Lathe.-- Engine tool, a machine tool. J. Whitworth.-- Engine turning (Fine Arts), a method of ornamentation by means ofa rose engine.
One who studies or writes upon ethology.
Having the form of ether.
One who electrotypes.
Variant of Engine. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Certain constitutions or decretal epistles, not at firstincluded with others, but subsequently made a part of the canon law.
A curve traced by a point in the circumference of a circlewhich rolls on the convex side of a fixed circle.
A prefix signifying between, among, part.

The hardened parts of the external integument of an animal,including hair, feathers, nails, horns, scales, etc.,as well as thearmor of armadillos and many reptiles, and the shells or hardenedintegument of numerous invertebrates; external skeleton;dermoskeleton.

To come against face to face; to meet; to confront, either bychance, suddenly, or deliberately; especially, to meet in oppositionor with hostile intent; to engage in conflict with; to oppose; tostruggle with; as, to encounter a friend in traveling; two armiesencounter each other; to encounter obstacles or difficulties, toencounter strong evidence of a truth.Then certain philosophers of the Epicureans, and of the Stoics,encountered him. Acts xvii. 18.I am most fortunate thus accidentally to encounter you. Shak.
A word expressing outcry; an interjection; a word expressingpassion, as wonder, fear, or grief.
Enlargement or extension of business transaction; esp.,increase of the circulation of bank notes.
To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to makefurious.
The act of poisoning. Bacon.
Act of eluding; adroit escape, as by artifice; a mockery; acheat; trickery.
Epidermal. [R.]
Something offensive to the eye or sight; a blemish.Mordecai was an eyesore to Haman. L'Estrange.
The yew. [Obs.] Dryden.
The doctrine of Eutyches and his followers.
One of the orders of Nemertina, characterized by the presenceof a peculiar armature of spines or plates in the proboscis.
To puzzle. [Archaic] Sir T. Browne.
The art or process of engraving by means of electricity.
To guard as a churchwarden does. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
The difference between the approximate result and the trueresult; -- used particularly in the rule of double position.
Beyond the material world. "An extramundane being." Bp.Warburton.
Resembling epilepsy; as, epileptoid convulsions.
To force or let out of the proper vessels or arteries, asblood.
To affect excessive refinement in language; to be overnice inexpression.
Honorably discharged from the performance of public duty onaccount of age, infirmity, or long and faithful services; -- said ofan officer of a college or pastor of a church.
To entice. See Inveigle.
The candlefish. [Written also oulachan, oolacan, and ulikon.]See Candlefish.
Inflammation of the endocardium.

A genus of papaveraceous plants, found in California and uponthe west coast of North America, some species of which producebeautiful yellow, orange, rose-colored, or white flowers; theCalifornia poppy.
Having a fanlike tail; belonging to the Eurhipiduræ, a divisionof Aves which includes all living birds.
Designed to be executed or carried into effect in time to come,or to take effect on a future contingency; as, an executory devise,reminder, or estate; an executory contract. Blackstone.

A plant which increases in size by internal growth andelongation at the summit, having the wood in the form of bundles orthreads, irregularly distributed throughout the whole diameter, notforming annual layers, and with no distinct pith. The leaves of theendogens have, usually, parallel veins, their flowers are mostly inthree, or some multiple of three, parts, and their embryos have but asingle cotyledon, with the first leaves alternate. The endogensconstitute one of the great primary classes of plants, and includedall palms, true lilies, grasses, rushes, orchids, the banana,pineapple, etc. See Exogen.
To form as an effigy; hence, to fashion; to adapt.[He must] effigiate and conform himself to those circumstances. Jer.Taylor.
To furnish with battlements; to fortify as with battlements.[Archaic]To embattail and to wall about thy cause With iron-worded proof.Tennyson.
To force; to constrain; to compel to yield. [Obs.] Spenser.

Spirit. Esprit de corps (, a French phrase much used by Englishwriters to denote the common spirit pervading the members of a bodyor association of persons. It implies sympathy, enthusiasm, devotion,and jealous regard for the honor of the body as a whole.
Capable of being extirpated or eradicated; as, an extirpableplant. Evelyn.
The act of unsheathing.
To bring as, to educate a child; to educate the eye or thetaste.
To remove the kernel form.
Pertaining to Queen Elizabeth or her times, esp. to thearchitecture or literature of her reign; as, the Elizabethan writers,drama, literature.-- n.
Under the power of enchantment; possessed or exercised byenchanters; as, an enchanted castle.
One of a coterie who exclude others; one who from real ofaffected fastidiousness limits his acquaintance to a select few.
The quality of being elfish.
To remove without cutting (as a tumor).
A group of Rhizopoda having a distinct nucleus, as the am
A genus of fishes. See Saury.
Tending to fish out; searching out [R.] Carlyle.
To boil with anger; to effervesce. [Obs.] Spenser.
Full of error; wrong. Foxe.
Once more; again; -- used by the auditors and spectators ofplays, concerts, and other entertainments, to call for a repetitionof a particular part.
A facsimile plate made by electrotypy for use in printing;also, an impression or print from such plate. Also used adjectively.
A mode of etching upon metals by electrolytic action.
That may be explored; as, an explorable region.
An instrument for measuring the degree of rarefaction of aircontained in the receiver of an air pump. [Spelt also elaterometer.]

Denoting a mere result or consequence, as distinguished fromtelic, which denotes intention or purpose; thus the phrase so that itwas fulfilled," is ecbatic; if rendered "in order that it might be."etc., is telic.
Tending to exclude; causing exclusion; exclusive.
Pertaining to, or composed of, ectoplasm.
Capable of being moved by entreaty; pitiful; tender. Milton.
Having or producing nine pistils or styles; -- said of a floweror plant.
Making or containing excuse or apology; apologetical; as, anexcusatory plea.
To sweep over or across; to pass over rapidly. [R.] Thomson.
Formed, or deposited, by the action of wind, as dunes. Eolianattachment, Eolian harp. See Æolian.
Tending to make dry; having the power of drying.
To make search; to try to find something. [Obs.] -- v. t.
Allopathy; -- a term used by followers of Hahnemann, orhomeopathists.
Georgia; -- a nickname.
Same as Euthanasia.
Connected with, or pertaining to, excretion.
An instrument for copying drawings on the same or a differentscale; a form of the pantograph.
In an endless manner.
One who enjoys.
Susceptibility to emotion. G. Eliot.

Having all the sides equal; as, an equilateral triangle; anequilateral polygon. Equilateral hyperbola (Geom.), one whose axesare equal.-- Equilateral shell (Zoöl.), one in which a transverse line drawnthrough the apex of the umbo bisects the valve, or divides it intotwo equal and symmetrical parts.-- Mutually equilateral, applied to two figures, when every side ofthe one has its equal among the sides of the other.
To surround. [Obs.] Shak.
A substitution, as of one part of speech for another, of onegender, number, case, person, tense, mode, or voice, of the sameword, for another.
One who has been excommunicated.
Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- saidof external parasites.
A bishop. [Obs.] Milton.
Having a disposition for enterprise; characterized byenterprise; resolute, active or prompt to attempt; as, anenterprising man or firm.-- En"ter*pri`sing*ly, adv.
That refractive condition of the eye in which the rays of lightare all brought accurately and without undue effort to a focus uponthe retina; -- opposed to hypermetropia, myopia, an astigmatism.
Same as Aitchbone.
A dissertation or digression appended to a work, and containinga more extended exposition of some important point or topic.
A fever of one day's continuance only.

A tree of the genus Ulmus, of several species, much used as ashade tree, particularly in America. The English elm is Ulmuscampestris; the common American or white elm is U. Americana; theslippery or red elm, U. fulva. Elm beetle (Zoöl.), one of severalspecies of beetles (esp. Galeruca calmariensis), which feed on theleaves of the elm.-- Elm borer (Zoöl.), one of several species of beetles of which thelarvæ bore into the wood or under the bark of the elm (esp. Saperdatridentata).-- Elm butterfly (Zoöl.), one of several species of butterflies,which, in the caterpillar state, feed on the leaves of the elm (esp.Vanessa antiopa and Grapta comma). See Comma butterfly, under Comma.-- Elm moth (Zoöl.), one of numerous species of moths of which thelarvæ destroy the leaves of the elm (esp. Eugonia subsignaria, calledelm spanworm).-- Elm sawfly (Zoöl.), a large sawfly (Cimbex Americana). The larva,which is white with a black dorsal stripe, feeds on the leaves of theelm.

To enter by gradual steps or by stealth into the possessions orrights of another; to trespass; to intrude; to trench; -- commonlywith on or upon; as, to encroach on a neighbor; to encroach on thehighway.No sense, faculty, or member must encroach upon or interfere with theduty and office of another. South.Superstition, . . . a creeping and encroaching evil. Hooker.Exclude the encroaching cattle from thy ground. Dryden.
A species of primrose. See Auricula.
Excellently; eminently; exceedingly. [Obs.] "This comes offwell and excellent." Shak.
Air. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The act of entombing or burying, or state of being entombed;burial. Barrow.
The removal by operation of a portion of a limb; particularly,the removal of a portion of a bone in the vicinity of a joint; theact or process of cutting out.
To tune; to intone. Chaucer.
Outreaching; expansive; extended, superficially or otherwise.Men and gods are too extense; Could you slacken and condense Emerson.
Having equal legs or sides; isosceles. [R.] "Equicruraltriangles." Sir T. Browne.
In the way of epigram; in an epigrammatic style.
Pertaining to etymology, or the derivation of words.-- Et`y*mo*log"ic*al*ly, adv.
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
To set on fire. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having nine petals, or flower leaves.
The inward part of a building; the interior. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Removal to a distance; withdrawal. [Obs.]
With economy; with careful management; with prudence inexpenditure.
To immure. [Obs.]
Omission; a figure of syntax, by which one or more words, whichare obviously understood, are omitted; as, the virtues I admire, for,the virtues which I admire.
The act of administering a remedy.
Of or pertaining to England, or to its inhabitants, or to thepresent so-called Anglo-Saxon race. English bond (Arch.)
A follower of Eudoxius, patriarch of Antioch and Constantinoplein the 4th century, and a celebrated defender of the doctrines ofArius.
Causing hunger; eating; corroding. [Obs.] Wiseman.
One who goes upon an expedition. [R].
The deep sensitive and vascular layer of the skin and mucousmembranes.-- En`de*ron"ic, a.
Elegiac verse.
See Eclectic.
A female or hen eagle. [R.] Sherwood.
Tending to raise, or having power to elevate; as, elevatoryforces.
A figure by which permission is either seriously or ironicallygranted to some one, to do what he proposes to do; e. g., "He that isunjust, let him be unjust still."
One who, or that which, extends or stretches anything.
Exchange. [Obs.]
See Escaloped.
Belonging to the euphuists, or euphuism; affectedly refined.
Belonging to an enneagon; having nine angles.
To make new. [Obs.] Skelton.
State of being eminent; eminence. "Eminency of estate."Tillotson.
In an elvish manner. Sir W. Scott.
Earshot. Marston.
A name originally given (from its red acid) to the metalvanadium. [R.]
One who exacts or demands by authority or right; hence, anextortioner; also, one unreasonably severe in injunctions or demands.Jer. Taylor.
See Inwall. Sir P. Sidney.
Embattled. [Obs.]
The branching forth, as of trees.
Having equanimity.
One who enumerates.
To make feeble; to deprive of strength; to reduce the strengthor force of; to weaken; to debilitate.Enfeebled by scanty subsistence and excessive toil. Prescott.
Without cost or expense.
A full or additional explanation; exegesis.
Epithelioid.
One who works in ebony.
See Earth light, under Earth.
To move as an eddy, or as in an eddy; to move in a circle.Eddying round and round they sink. Wordsworth.
Demonstrative warmth or cordiality of manner; display ofenthusiasm.
The mouth of a river, or place where its waters are discharged.[R.]
The use of expressions susceptible of a double signification,with a purpose to mislead.There being no room for equivocations, there is no need ofdistinctions. Locke.
To frighten; to scare. [Obs.] Spenser.
A feasting to excess. [Obs.]
Relating to objects situated within the eye; esp., relating tothe perception of objects in one's own eye.
Tending to excite; containing excitement; excitative.
A supporter of extreme doctrines or practice; one who holdsextreme opinions.
Fertilized by the agency of insects; -- said of plants in whichthe pollen is carried to the stigma by insects.
Serious. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pain in the intestines; colic.
A group which includes the typical Isopoda.
Any parasite which lives in the internal organs of an animal,as the tapeworms, Trichina, etc.; -- opposed to ectoparasite. SeeEntozoön.-- En`do*par`a*sit"ic, a.
See Cerumen.
In an ecclesiastical manner; according ecclesiastical rules.
Of maximum fusibility; -- said of an alloy or mixture which hasthe lowest melting point which it is possible to obtain by thecombination of the given components.
A prefix signifying within. See Ento-.
The line of works which forms the main inclosure of a fortressor place; -- called also body of the place.
To cover or deck with flowers. [Poetic]These odorous and enflowered fields. B. Jonson.
The coloring matter within the cells of plants, whether green,red, yellow, or any other color.
A believer in egoism.
A room in a public building, furnished with seats.

The "falling sickness," so called because the patient fallssuddenly to the ground; a disease characterized by paroxysms (orfits) occurring at interval and attended by sudden loss ofconsciousness, and convulsive motions of the muscles. Dunglison.

An inodorous exudation, usually in the form of yellow tears,produced chiefly by the African Euphorbia resinifrea. It was formerlyemployed medicinally, but was found so violent in its effects thatits use is nearly abandoned.
To put upon the back or outside of anything; -- the olderspelling of endorse. [Obs.] Spenser.
To wrap up; to envelop. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who enchases.
To make a park of; to inclose, as with a fence; to impark.[Obs.]
A treatise upon, or description of, the intestines; enterology.
To offer incense to or upon; to burn incense. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Indorser.
A salt of elaidic acid.
Relating to enstatite.
One of the clergy who reads the epistle at the communionservice; an epistler.
Obsolete; out of use; state; insipid. [Obs.]
A lamb just brought forth; a yeanling. Shak.
The ratio of the distance between the center and the focus ofan ellipse or hyperbola to its semi-transverse axis.

To exercise one's self, as under military training; to drill;to take exercise; to use action or exertion; to practice gymnastics;as, to exercise for health or amusement.I wear my trusty sword, When I do exercise. Cowper.
An exemplar; also, a copy of a book or writing. [Obs.] Donne.
Feeding on horseflesh; as, equivorous Tartars.

The superficial layer of cells lining the alimentary canal andall its appendages, all glands and their ducts, blood vessels andlymphatics, serous cavities, etc. It often includes the epidermis (i.e., keratin-producing epithelial cells), and it is sometimesrestricted to the alimentary canal, the glands and their appendages,-- the term endothelium being applied to the lining membrane of theblood vessels, lymphatics, and serous cavities.
Considered as pure entity; abstracted from all circumstances.Ellis.-- En"ti*ta*tive*ly, adv.
A prerogative given to the eldest coparcener to choose firstafter an inheritance is divide. Mozley & W.
Inclined to exult; characterized by, or expressing, exultation;rejoicing triumphantly.Break away, exultant, from every defilement. I. Tay;or.
A morbid displacement of parts, especially such as iscongenial; as, ectopia of the heart, or of the bladder.
A religious organization of Methodist young people, founded in1889 at Cleveland, Ohio, and taking its name from John Wesley'sbirthplace, Epworth, Lincolnshire, England.
Empire; sovereignty; dominion. [Archaic] Shak.Struggling for my woman's empery. Mrs. Browning.
An old form of Elf.
A nuptial song, or poem in honor of the bride and bridegroom.The kind of poem which was called epithalamium . . . sung when thebride was led into her chamber. B. Jonson.
See Edentate, a.

A nobleman of England ranking below a marquis, and above aviscount. The rank of an earl corresponds to that of a count (comte)in France, and graf in Germany. Hence the wife of an earl is stillcalled countess. See Count.
To give the etymology of; to trace to the root or primitive, asa word. Camden

A rare metallic element associated with several other rareelements in the mineral gadolinite from Ytterby in Sweden. Symbol Er.Atomic weight 165.9. Its salts are rose-colored and givecharacteristic spectra. Its sesquioxide is called erbia.
Serving to dissolve or attenuate viscid matter, and so toremove obstructions; deobstruent.-- n.
The slender, hollow thread of a nettling cell or cnida. SeeNettling cell. [Written also ecthoræum.]
Extrinsic.-- Ex*trin"sic*al*ly(#), adv.
An empiric.
Pertaining to an ephor.

A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering forthe back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps orbrooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of thesame stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plainlinen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. Thebreastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.Exodus xxviii. 6-12.
Espial. [Obs.]
The science of the dissection of insects.
A monster, half maid and half serpent.
See Shallot.
Clammy. [Obs.]
To make sober. [Obs.]Sad accidents to ensober his spirits. Jer. Taylor.
Elicited; drawn out; made real; open; evident. [Obs.] "Anelicit act of equity." Jer. Taylor.

The sunlight reflected from the earth to the moon, by which wesee faintly, when the moon is near the sun (either before or afternew moon), that part of the moon's disk unillumined by directsunlight, or "the old moon in the arms of the new."

To rise out of a fluid; to come forth from that in whichanything has been plunged, enveloped, or concealed; to issue andappear; as, to emerge from the water or the ocean; the sun emergesfrom behind the moon in an eclipse; to emerge from poverty orobscurity. "Thetis . . . emerging from the deep." Dryden.Those who have emerged from very low, some from the lowest, classesof society. Burke.
In an evangelical manner.
The act of giving shape or form. [Obs.] Ray.
The epidermis.
Examination; inquiry. [R.] "A critical examen of the twopieces." Cowper.
To make bitter or sad. See Imbitter.

A moving of the mind or soul; excitement of the feelings,whether pleasing or painful; disturbance or agitation of mind causedby a specific exciting cause and manifested by some sensible effecton the body.How different the emotions between departure and return! W. Irving.Some vague emotion of delight. Tennyson.
To fix the value of; to rate; to appraise.
Making no effort. Southey.
Having some of the forms, such as drapery or the like, toosharply defined. "An edgy style of sculpture." Hazlitt.
Stored or furnished with wine. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Service performed only under inspection, or the eye of anemployer.Not with eyeservice, as menpleasers. Col. iii. 22.
Relating to oleic acid, or elaine. Elaidic acid (Chem.), afatty acid isomeric with oleic acid, and obtained from it by theaction of nitrous acid.
One who is versed in the theories of, or who advocates andpromotes, education.
Similar, but not superposable, i. e., related to each other asa right-handed to a left-handed glove; -- said of certain hemihedralcrystals.
To inclose, as in a box; to imbox.
The internal or principal branch of the locomotive appendagesof Crustacea. See Maxilliped.

No longer capable of producing young, as an animal, or fruit,as the earth; hence, worn out with age; exhausted of energy;incapable of efficient action; no longer productive; barren; sterile.Effete results from virile efforts. Mrs. BrowningIf they find the old governments effete, worn out, . . . they mayseek new ones. Burke.
Arising from the pleurapophysis of a vertebra. Owen.
One who explores; one who examines closely; a searcher.
Bleeding at the nose.
To make hungry.Those animal passions which vice had . . . enhungered to feed oninnocence and life. J. Martineau.
The act of electrizing; electrification.

In accord, harmony, or sympathy; having a mutual, esp. aprivate, understanding; of a hypnotic subject, being in such a mentalstate as to be especially subject to the influence of a particularperson or persons.
A species of deer (Elaphurus Davidianus) found in china. Itabout four feet high at the shoulder and has peculiar antlers.
The membrane lining the inner surface of the uterus, or womb.
A figure by which the same word or clause is repeated afterintervening matter. Gibbs.
In an American college, an optional study or course of study.[Colloq.]
One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, theender of my life.
Relating to Elohim as a name of God; -- said of passages in theOld Testament.
Very desirable. [Obs.] Bailey.
In or of the country. [R.]Epichorial superstitions from every district of Europe. De Quincey.
Without or above example. [R.]
Sight of the eye; the sense of seeing; view; observation.Josephus sets this down from his own eyesight. Bp. Wilkins.
Without effect or advantage; useless; bootless. Shak.-- Ef*fect"less*ly, adv.
To utter ejaculations; to make short and hasty exclamations.[R.] "Ejaculating to himself." Sir W. Scott.
The buffalo nut. See under Buffalo.
A representation of things beyond natural life, in expression,beauty, power, vigor.
To form a circle about; to inclose within a circle or ring; tosurround; as, to encircle one in the arms; the army encircled thecity.Her brows encircled with his serpent rod. Parnell.
Contemporaneous. [Obs.] Boyle.
The formation of an involute by unwrapping a thread from acurve as an evolute. Hutton.
To denounce evil against, or to imprecate evil upon; to curse;to protest against as unholy or detestable; hence, to detest utterly;to abhor; to abominate. "They . . . execrate their lct." Cowper.
An expedient. [Obs.]A like expediment to remove discontent. Barrow.
A garden plot, usually about half an acre. [Cape Colony]
To utter words or syllables articulately.
To form; to shape. [Obs.]Efforming their words within their lips. Jer. Taylor.
Constituting an object of expectation; contingent. Expectativegrace, a mandate given by the pope or a prince appointing a successorto any benefice before it becomes vacant. Foxe.
The act of embalming. [R.] Malone.
Having the anterior scute
Pertaining to, or situated near, central or deep parts; inner;-- opposed to ectal. B. G. Wilder.
To make better. [Obs.]

A circle, whose center moves round in the circumference of agreater circle; or a small circle, whose center, being fixed in thedeferent of a planet, is carried along with the deferent, and yet, byits own peculiar motion, carries the body of the planet fastened toit round its proper center.The schoolmen were like astronomers which did feign eccentries, andepicycles, and such engines of orbs. Bacon.
Like endothelium.
A circle around whose circumference a planet or the center ofann epicycle was conceived to move uniformly; -- called alsoeccentric equator.
A person employed in the express business; also, the driver ofa job wagon. W. D. Howells.
New York; -- a nickname alluding to its size and wealth.
The delicate bands of connective tissue among nerve fibers.
An assembly room in dwelling of the Pueblo Indians. L. H.Morgan.
In a lump; as a whole; all together. "Movement of the ossiclesen bloc."  Nature.
To exude. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Having an escutcheon; furnished with a coat of arms or ensign.Young.
Expansive; diffusive. [R.]
State of being without or beyond a thing; foreignness. [Obs.]
The common sainfoin (Onobrychis sativa), an Old Worldleguminous forage plant.
The quality of being exact; exactness.
Same as Æneid.
To rive; to cleave. [Obs.]
To swell or heave like a [R.] Lisle.
A bag filled with earth, used commonly to raise or repair aparapet.
Pertaining to, or effected by means of, electrotypy.
Belonging to the Heath family, or resembling plants of thatfamily; consisting of heats.
Possessing electrical polarity; positively electrified at oneend, or on one surface, and negatively at the other; -- said of aconductor.
To make pale. [Obs.]No bloodless malady empales their face. G. Fletcher.
To envenom. [Obs.]
Having no albumen about the embryo; -- said of certain seeds.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a horse.The shoulders, body, things, and mane are equine; the head completelybovine. Sir J. Barrow.
Epigastric.
The art or process of gilding copper, iron, etc., by means ofvoltaic electricity.
Same as Ectopia.
To shelter. [Obs.]
The act of enthralling, or state of being enthralled. SeeInthrallment.
Thrown into ecstasy; transported; enraptured. Shak.
Plumpness of person; -- said especially of persons somewhatcorpulent.
Quality of being explicable.

Prepared by means of heat; burned in. Encaustic painting (FineArts), painting by means of wax with which the colors are combined,and which is afterwards fused with hot irons, thus fixing the colors.-- Encaustic tile (Fine Arts), an earthenware tile which has adecorative pattern and is not wholly of one color.
Force; strength; power. [Obs.]A petty enterprise of small enforce. Milton.
To dispossess by a judicial process; to dispossess by paramountright or claim of such right; to eject; to oust.The law of England would speedily evict them out of their possession.Sir. J. Davies.
A seething; digestion. [Obs.] Burton.
. Capable of being excoriated.The scaly covering of fishes, . . . even in such as are excoriatable.Sir T. Browne.
A swelling or rising. [R.] Cotgrave.

A style of engraving in relief by means of voltaic electricity.A picture is drawn on a metallic plate with some material whichresists the fluids of a battery; so that, in electro-typing, theparts not covered by the varnish, etc., receive a deposition ofmetal, and produce the required copy in intaglio. A cast of this isthen the plate for printing.
One who rides on horseback; a horseman; a rider.
One whi gives evidence.
A brittle gem occurring in light green, transparent crystals,affording a brilliant clinodiagonal cleavage. It is a silicate ofalumina and glucina.
The whole; all the parts taken together.
The operation of making an incision into the esophagus, for thepurpose of removing any foreign substance that obstructs the passage.[Written also oesophagotomy.]
Digging up.
Of the same or like sound.
Same as Æolipile.
The office or the province of an exarch. Jer. Taylor.
See Exosmose.
To move; to rouse; to excite. [Obs.]
One who, or that which, elaborates.
Ensuing; following.
See Luxe.
To render smooth; to polish. [Obs.]
Epigæous. [R.]
A snatching away. [Obs.] Cockeram.
To mew or coop up. [Obs.] Shak.
Ease; pleasure. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An enthusiast. [R.] Gauden.
To wash out. [R.] Arbuthnot.
Capable of effervescing.
The reflux of tide water; the retiring tide; -- opposed toflood tide.
See Electuary.
Entreaty. [Obs.] Fairfax.
To infold, as in a mist.
Equality. [Obs.] Bacon.
In an eager manner.
One who pillages; a plunderer; a pillager. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
Equal in measure but not admitting of superposition; -- appliedto magnitudes; as, a square may be equivalent to a triangle.
Of or relating to the ectoderm.
Shaped into one; tending to, or formative into, unity. [R.]Coleridge.
Pertaining to the segment between the ceratobranchial andpharyngobranchial in a branchial arch.-- n.
That may be enforced.
The act of entrancing, or the state of trance or ecstasy.Otway.
Plumed. [R.]
One who emboldens.
Shining. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
Causing fear; eerie. [Scot.]
The act of excusing; seizure by law. [Obs.] Ayliffe.

A speech or short poem addressed to the spectators and recitedby one of the actors, after the conclusion of the play.A good play no epilogue, yet . . . good plays prove the better by thehelp of good epilogues. Shak.
Exhalation. [Obs.]
A prefix or combining form signifying pertaining toelectricity, produced by electricity, producing or employingelectricity, etc.; as, electro-negative; electro-dynamic; electro-magnet.

Seriousness; reality; fixed determination; eagerness;intentness.Take heed that this jest do not one day turn to earnest. Sir P.Sidney.And given in earnest what I begged in jest. Shak.In earnest, serious; seriously; not in jest; earnestly.
The sea holly. See Eryngo.
A female emulator. [R.]
Exclamatory. Earle.-- Ex*clam"a*tive*ly, adv.

Characterized by abundance or superabundance; plenteous; rich;overflowing; copious or excessive in production; as, exuberantgoodness; an exuberant intellect; exuberant foliage. "Exuberantspring." Thomson.-- Ex*u"ber*ant*ly, adv.
The state of being elementary; original simplicity;uncompounded state.
A figure by which the same word is used both at the beginningand at the end of a sentence; as, "Rejoice in the Lord always: andagain I say, Rejoice." Phil. iv. 4.
A stairway or incline arranged like an endless belt so that thesteps or treads ascend or descend continuously, and one stepping uponit is carried up or down; -- a trade term.
In an evident manner; clearly; plainly.Before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth. Gal.iii. 1.He has evidently in the prime of youth. W. Irving.
See Eclecticism.
Serving to unfold or explain; tending to lay open to theunderstanding; explanatory. Sir W. Hamilton.
Pertaining to an epitaph; epitaphian.-- n.
That of the pericardium which forms the outer surface of theheart; the cardiac pericardium.
Burnt to cinders. [R.]
Ointment for the eye.
Producing exhaustion; as, exhausting labors.-- Ex*haust"ing, adv.
One who embellishes.
Resembling, or covered with, a sleeve; -- said of the chiefwhen lines are drawn from the middle point of the upper edge upperedge to the sides.
An epidemic disease.
One who effects.
To decompose by the direct action of electricity. Faraday.
Same as Armed, 3.
Serving to palliate; palliative. Dunglison.
See Ingraft. Shak.
See Embryo.
Encyclopedic.
A making clear; the act of elucidating or that whichelucidates, as an explanation, an exposition, an illustration; as,one example may serve for further elucidation of the subject.
A kind of small, portable, cooking apparatus for which heat isfurnished by a spirit lamp.There should certainly be an etna for getting a hot cup of coffee ina hurry. V. Baker.
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or affected with, an ægilops,or tumor in the corner of the eye.
Pertaining to an embolism; produced by an embolism; as, anembolic abscess.
The quality worthy or qualified to be chosen; suitableness;desirableness.
Ethyl. [Obs.]
One who makes excerpts; a picker; a culler.
Inflammation of the brain.-- En`ceph*a*lit"ic, a.
See Exsection.
In an egoistic manner.
A mineral occurring in transparent emerald green crystals. Itis hydrous arseniate of copper.

Tending to elude; using arts or deception to escape; adroitlyescaping or evading; eluding the grasp; fallacious.Elusive of the bridal day, she gives Fond hopes to all, and all withhopes deceives. Pope.-- E*lu"sive*ly, adv.-- E*lu"sive*ness, n.
One addicted to egotism; one who speaks much of himself ormagnifies his own achievements or affairs.
Same as Indorse.
To moisten and rub (a diseased part) with a liquid substance,as with spirit, oil, etc., by means of a cloth or sponge.
One the Echinoidea.
In an ethnological manner; by ethnological classification; as,one belonging ethnologically to an African race.
An Armenian. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The modified condition of a nerve, when a constant current ofelectricity passes through any part of it. See Anelectrotonus, andCatelectrotonus.
An unlawful diminution of the possessions of another.
Having power, or intended, to make expiation; atoning; as, anexpiatory sacrifice.
See Epizoic.
To furnish or adorn with a border; to imborder.
A favorite; a paramour; an ingle. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
One who explains or elucidates; an expositor.
Exaltation. [Obs.] Barrow.
Deprivation of authority or dignity; degration. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
A small circle; a ring. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
An officer whose duty it is to observe what escheats have takenplace, and to take charge of them. Burrill.
See Ægilops.
A gradual oxidation from exposure to air and moisture, as inthe decay of old trees or of dead animals.
Forming no part of the dowry; as, extradotal property.
To vie; to emulate; to strive. [Obs.] Spenser.
A projection on the outer side of the distal end of thehumerus; the external condyle.
Facing outwards, or away from the axis of growth; -- said esp.of anthers occupying the outer side of the filament.
To inclose in a chest. Vicars.
An agreeable combination of sounds; euphony.
A write of elegies. T. Warton.
A speech or writing in commendation of the character orservices of a person; as, a fitting eulogy to worth.Eulogies turn into elegies. Spenser.
The outer coat of the anther.
Epibolic invagination. See under Invagination.
That property of a body by which it occupies a portion ofspace.
A perfumed powder sprinkled upon the body to mask the odor ofsweat.
To take with toils or bring into toils; to insnare. [R.]Entoiled in woofed phantasies. Keats.
One who enforces.
The abnormal change of an irregular flower to a regular form; -- considered by evolutionists to be a reversion to an ancestralcondition.
To gird; to encompass. Shak.
Situated on the receptacle or disk of a flower.
To make a gallant of. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A hard tumor developed from the gums.
Having no aril; -- said of certain seeds, or of the plantsproducing them.
A gallery in a church, where persons watched all night.
Expansible.Ether and alcohol are more expansile than water. Brande & C.
Without palpi.

One who enchants; a sorcerer or magician; also, one whodelights as by an enchantment.Like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing. Shelley.Enchanter's nightshade (Bot.), a genus (Circæa) of low inconspicuous,perennial plants, found in damp, shady places.
To stray. [Obs.] Daniel.
Remaining unwithered through the winter, or retainingunwithered leaves until the leaves of the next year are expanded, aspines cedars, hemlocks, and the like.
A lock or curl of hair near the ear; a lovelock. See Lovelock.
One who etches.
Smallness; meagerness; slenderness; fineness, thinness. [R.]Paley.
A curious fungus of the genus Geaster, in which the outercoating splits into the shape of a star, and the inner one forms aball containing the dustlike spores.
To exterminate; to destroy. [Obs.] Shak.
See Entozoa.
A drug, as ergot, which by exciting uterine contractionspromotes the expulsion of the contents of the uterus.
See Scot, a tax. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to exhortation; hortatory. Holinshed.
One who is versed in elocution; a teacher of elocution.
That branch of electrical science which treats of electricityin motion.
To wait; to stay. [Obs.] Sandys.
Sending out; emitting; as, emissive powers.
Serious. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To form an estimate; to have regard to the value; to consider.[Obs.]We ourselves esteem not of that obedience, or love, or gift, which isof force. Milton.
An apparatus for determining the amount of oil contained in anysubstance, or for ascertaining the degree of purity of oil.
To state in enlarged form; to develop; as, to expand anequation. See Expansion, 5.
To milk out; to drain. [Obs.] Bailey.
Same as Edentate, a.
A kind of discarder.
One of the bones of either the forearm or shank, theepipodialia being the radius, ulna, tibia, and fibula.
To surround with a halo.
One who by gradual steps enters on, and takes possession of,what is not his own.
To give forth effluvium. [R.] "An effluviating power." Boyle.

A colorless crystalline substance, C4H6.(OH)4, of a sweet,cooling taste, extracted from certain lichens, and obtained by thedecomposition of erythrin; -- called also erythrol, erythroglucin,erythromannite, pseudorcin, cobalt bloom, and under the name phyciteobtained from the alga Protococcus vulgaris. It is a tetrabasicalcohol, corresponding to glycol and glycerin.
Agitation. [Obs.] Bailey.

A bringer of the glad tidings of Church and his doctrines.Specially: (a) A missionary preacher sent forth to prepare the wayfor a resident pastor; an itinerant missionary preacher. (b) A writerof one of the four Gospels (With the definite article); as, the fourevangelists, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. (c) A traveling preacherwhose efforts are chiefly directed to arouse to immediate repentance.The Apostles, so far as they evangelized, might claim the tittlethough there were many evangelists who were not Apistles. Plumptre.
Other; one or something beside; as, Who else is coming Whatelse shall I give Do you expect anything else "Bastards and else."Shak.
Such a due mixture of qualities in bodies as constitutes healthor soundness. Quincy.
A slight convex swelling of the shaft of a column.
Belonging to ecclesiology.
Endurance. [Obs.] South.
The principle or process of forming from given components theeutectic alloy, or alloy of maximum fusibility.
To blind. [Obs.] Cockeram.

To clear from alleged fault or guilt; to prove to be guiltless;to relieve of blame; to acquit.He exculpated himself from being the author of the heroic epistle.Mason.I exculpate him further for his writing against me. Milman.
Of or pertaining to the episternum.
The office of an emissary.
Relating to evolution. "Evolutional changes." H. Spenser.
To move with passion; to affect strongly. See Impassion. [Obs.]Those sights empassion me full near. Spenser.
Same as Epilogize.
To become pale through disease or absence of light.
Castration. [Obs.]

A judicial writ of execution, by which a defendant's goods areappraised and delivered to the plaintiff, and, if no sufficient tosatisfy the debt, all of his lands are delivered, to be held till thedebt is paid by the rents and profits, or until the defendant'sinterest has expired.

A mass, usually of soft iron, but sometimes of some othermagnetic metal, as nickel or cobalt, rendered temporarily magnetic bybeing placed within a coil of wire through which a current ofelectricity is passing. The metal is generally in the form of a bar,either straight, or bent into the shape of a horseshoe.
